div.head: THE AVTHORS EpiÅ¿tle Introductory to the Reader.
div.p: ALthough that man be the moÅ¿t perfect & abÅ¿olute of all other cretures, neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e, Å¿o weake is he by Nature, & Å¿o Å¿ubiect to infinite infirmities, that Diuine Hippocrates hath urged him, to be euen Å¿icknes it Å¿elfe from his very birth: He is not fit (Å¿aith he) to bee imployed in any buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e while be Å¿ucketh: becauÅ¿e h â¢ e wholly depends vpon the helpe of another: afterward when he comes to more yeares, hee grows Å¿tubborne, and vnruly, and wants a M â¢ Å¿ter to giue him inÅ¿truction: Againe, when he is growne to the prime of his age, hee becomes audacious and proud. At last in his declining time, he falls into miÅ¿ery, hauing nothing left him, but the remembrance of his labours ill beÅ¿towed.

Pliny noteth, and experience Å¿hews it to be true that the ill Å¿ent only of a Candle new put foorth, is enough to deÅ¿troy a child in the mothers wombe, Å¿o that Å¿hee may be forced to fall in trauaile, and be deliuered before her time, vnleÅ¿Å¿e her Å¿trength be the greater to reÅ¿iÅ¿t the
offence. And although the child Å¿tay the full time that nature hath prefixed him: yet commonly he is not able to get foorth, or come Å¿afely into the Worlde (yea though the birth be naturall) without the helpe not onely of the Mother, and himÅ¿elfe: but alÅ¿o of the Mid-wife and other women about her ready to receiue and cheriÅ¿h him: And which is worÅ¿t of all; if he be placed awry, or elÅ¿e be weake and faint, or elÅ¿e if the midwife be at the fartheÅ¿t of her skill; then if they will Å¿aue the child, and Å¿o conÅ¿equently the mother from death: they muÅ¿t call a Chirurgion to deliuer her, and bring the child into the world: which (that I may touch it by the way without taxing any) is commonly done too late eyther through the wilfulneÅ¿Å¿e of the kinÅ¿folks, or obÅ¿tinacy of the Midwiues.

But grant that the childe comes into the world of it Å¿elfe, without the helpe either of Chirurgion or Midwife: yet (as it is commonly Å¿aid) he drawes his death after him: the which may be plainely perceiued by the cryes and laments which he maketh as Å¿oone as he Å¿eeth the light, as if hce craued for helpe and Å¿uccour. For if he Å¿hould continue in that caÅ¿e that hee comes from his mothers wombe, clogged with his bed or after-birth, without doubt this bedde being putrified, would infect the child, and at length kill it. BeÅ¿ides, oftentimes if there were not helpe to make a free paÅ¿Å¿age, in the fundament, yard, or other naturall places, that are Å¿ometimes cloÅ¿ed vp, there could neither Å¿uÅ¿tenance be receiued, nor excrements expelled, which would cauÅ¿e the child to be Å¿tifled, and choked vp.

Many times alÅ¿o the head, and other parts of the bodie,
(as the bones and legges) happen to be ill Å¿hapen, yea broken and out of ioint, which would neuer come of themÅ¿elues, into their proper and naturall place. There, then is it neceÅ¿Å¿ary that the Chirurgion vÅ¿e his helpfull and skilfull hand: So that euery man may plainly Å¿ee the neceÅ¿sity and Antiquity of this worke: Å¿ince that the firÅ¿t practiÅ¿e in Chirurgery, that euer was done in the world, was the Omphalotomia, or cutting of the Nauell, which Adam and Eue practiÅ¿ed on their firÅ¿t child.
TheÅ¿e therefore are the Motiues that haue induced me to publiÅ¿h this diÅ¿courÅ¿e, and therin to treat of Å¿uch diÅ¿eaÅ¿es as happen to women with child.

And heerein I haue endeuoured to helpe them both in their naturall, and extraordinary trauaile: and to eaÅ¿e them in all Å¿uch accidents, as may happen vnto them in their childbed: being the rather incited thereunto, by reading the complaints of Women, related by Soranus. O malÃ¨ occupatum virorum genus! occidimur nos non morimur: & ab illis qui inter vos peritiÅ¿Å¿imi exiÅ¿timantur perperam curatae. Vos de qualibet leuiÅ¿Å¿imÃ¢ veÅ¿tratum affectionum, libros ex libris facientes, bibliothecas Voluminibus oneratis; de noÅ¿triÅ¿ intereÃ diris et difficillimis cruciatibus nullÃ¢ vel exiguÃ¢ mentione facta.

O men, how ill doe you beÅ¿tow your time, and paines! Alas, wee women die not, but are tormented euen to death: For thoÅ¿e that are accounted the moÅ¿t expert and skilfull among you, take not that care of vs which they Å¿hould: you fill whole Libraries with large volumes & writings of euerie light and triuiall diÅ¿eaÅ¿e of your
owne making little or no mention at all, of our cruell and inÅ¿upportable torments.

I had purpoÅ¿ed aboue fifteene yeares Å¿ince, to haue written Å¿omwhat concerning this Å¿ubiect in my books of Chirurgery: but hauing more maturely conÅ¿idered thereof, I thought it fitter to write a TreatiÅ¿e of it by it Å¿elfe: which it deÅ¿erueth both for the difficultie of the Å¿ubiect, and for the variety of the matter which I was deÅ¿irous to obÅ¿erue therein: And indeede this worke excelleth all other, which are practiÅ¿ed vppon the body of man: whether ye reÅ¿pect the Antiquity, NeceÅ¿si â¢ y, or dexterity thereof.
For the Antiquitie: without doubt the firÅ¿t worke in Chirurgery, that euer was in the worlde, was the cutting of the Nauell which, (as is Å¿aide before) Adam practiÅ¿ed vppon his firÅ¿t borne.
Concerning the neceÅ¿sity: Å¿ome perhaps may obiect, that the bringing a bed of women, is not Å¿o neceÅ¿Å¿ary a worke as theÅ¿e following:

To Å¿tay the fluxe of bloud, whether it bee in veine or Arterie; to vÅ¿e the Trepan; to open the Empyema, or Å¿uppuration in the breaÅ¿t; to cut one that hath the DropÅ¿ie; or to let bloud skilfullie: For the fluxe of bloud it may bee further Å¿aide, that vnleÅ¿Å¿e it bee Å¿topped by leeÅ¿ing the bloud, the life alÅ¿o is endangered. But we muÅ¿t conÅ¿ider, that the bloud oftentimes Å¿taying of it Å¿elfe, and experience euidently Å¿hews, that nature, which is wiÅ¿e and prouident doth commonly reÅ¿traine, and Å¿top it. I haue beene preÅ¿ent in many skirmiÅ¿hes, (yet farre enough out of gunÅ¿hot, where I haue dreÅ¿Å¿ed many that were wounded,
who haue had the great veÅ¿Å¿els in many parts of their bodies cut, and bruiÅ¿ed, hauing loÅ¿t much bloud vppon the hurt, and yet it hath Å¿topped and Å¿tayed of it Å¿elfe. Some wil Å¿ay, that he who hath his Å¿cull cl â¢ ft by a wound is in danger of death, if the bloud that is Å¿hed vpon the Membrane, be not taken foorth by the meanes of the Trepan; For this bloud would be wholly putrified, and withall, corrupt the braine, the chiefe inÅ¿trument of life, and whoÅ¿e vÅ¿e is more then neceÅ¿Å¿ary. NotwithÅ¿tanding wee Å¿ee, that in many, the filth and ma â¢ ter comes foorth by the NoÅ¿e, Eares, and mouth, without being trepanned, yea, that it paÅ¿Å¿eth euen through their bones. Wee may Å¿ay the like of Å¿uch which haue the DropÅ¿ie, or Empyema, the breaÅ¿t of the one is full of Corruption, & the others belly full of water: they both choake and Å¿tifle, vnleÅ¿Å¿e the Chirurgion make inciÅ¿ion: in the one making a ParacentoÅ¿is, in the other opening the Pleura.

Yet neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e we Å¿ee, that he which hath an Empyema or Å¿uppuration doth oftentimes expell the matter, and filth, by the mouth or vrine (the waies beeing manifeÅ¿t, by which nature doth vnburthen her Å¿elfe) and he that hath the DropÅ¿ie auoideth the water, eyther by vrine, or Å¿toole, yea, and by Å¿weat, or by Å¿ome little vent which Nature makes in Å¿ome part of the body, as in the Nauell or legges: which we obÅ¿erue by daily experience in many men: and therefore wee may perceiue, that theÅ¿e practiÅ¿es are not alwaies, Å¿o neceÅ¿Å¿ary, and requiÅ¿ite.

For letting bloud; you will Å¿ay, that hee hazards his life, (and that Å¿odainely) who beeing oppreÅ¿Å¿ed, and
troubled with a great paine of his head or Å¿ide, is not Å¿peedily let bloud? becauÅ¿e the bloud that boyleth in his veines, striueth onely to come foorth; I will anÅ¿were: that Nature very often Å¿ends it foorth by the NoÅ¿e, Mouth, Eies, and Eares: by Å¿toole alÅ¿o, and other parts, disburthening her Å¿elfe to the Å¿icke Mans eaÅ¿e and profit: But It is not Å¿o in the deliuery of women; for if the entrance of the wombe be cloÅ¿ed, (as it is Å¿eene in diuers) whether it be naturally, by reaÅ¿on of a Å¿trong and thicke membrane, which Å¿hutteth vp the paÅ¿Å¿age: or other wiÅ¿e, becauÅ¿e Å¿ome Å¿carre happening there, hath hardned, and Å¿hrunke vp the Å¿ides of the necke of the Å¿aid wombe: it would be impoÅ¿sible that nature Å¿hould euer be able to Å¿eparate, and breake through th â¢ Å¿e impediments: for as for the one, it is hard for a penne or quill to paÅ¿Å¿e there, and for the other, you cannot put in a Å¿mall probe through the little hole which is in the middeÅ¿t of the membrane. And yet I haue had the experience thereof in two women, which were neuer the leÅ¿Å¿e with child, as I will Å¿hew more at large heereafter. So that either the Chirurgions helpe muÅ¿t bee vÅ¿ed, or elÅ¿e both the Mother and the child would die miÅ¿erablie.

Some may obiect vnto mee, that the Mother might open the paÅ¿Å¿age her Å¿elfe by tearing the parts Å¿o bound by the Å¿carre, & breaking through the Å¿aid membrane? But what will you anÅ¿were me, for her which hath her child turned awry and lies double in her wombe, and falleth into a ConvulÅ¿ion, or fluxe of bloud, or both together. The Mother not being able eyther to turne it, or pull it foorth, eÅ¿pecially if the head of it bee intangled
and faÅ¿tned betweene the bones of os Pubis, Å¿o that it is impoÅ¿sible to turne it, Å¿afe and Å¿ound, except the Chirurgion vÅ¿e his induÅ¿try and skill.

Now for the dexteritie: there is no compariÅ¿on betweene this and other practiÅ¿es; for there be no workes to be done in Chirurgery; where it is not neceÅ¿Å¿ary, to haue the benefit either of daylight or candle light, and the part which is to be handled, and dreÅ¿Å¿ed muÅ¿t be apparent and laid open to the eye.

Whereas contrariwiÅ¿e in this worke as well by reaÅ¿on of the company preÅ¿ent, as alÅ¿o, least the woman Å¿hould be afraid, the very entrance, whereby hee Å¿hould put in his hand, they are conÅ¿trained to hide: and then his hand being there, he muÅ¿t Å¿earch for the child) howÅ¿oeuer it be placed) not being able to Å¿ee it. And if there be found two, three, or foure Children, yea, Å¿ometime fiue (as Albertus Magnus reporteth, hee Å¿aw in Germanie, a Woman that brought foorth to the number of threeÅ¿core and fiue children, beeing deliuered euerie yeare of fiue) then (I Å¿ay) I leaue you to iudge what skill and dexteritie the Chirurgion ought to vÅ¿e in Å¿eeking them one after another if they come amiÅ¿Å¿e.

On the other Å¿ide, as often as a woman is well deliuered by the helpe and hand of the Chirurgion, there life is giuen to two, to wit: to the Mother and the childe. And therfore as this worthy man Å¿aith, In partu inuocatur dei auxilium: quaeritur enim & parturientis & naÅ¿centis Å¿alus. When a woman is in trauaile, they call vppon God for helpe: becauÅ¿e they deÅ¿ire to Å¿aue both the Mother and the child. Now in all other practiÅ¿es, though they attaine to their wiÅ¿hed end, yet can
there bee but one onely Å¿aued at once. Whereby it may be iudged, that this practiÅ¿e is both for the Antiquitie, NeceÅ¿sitie, and dexterity thereof, the moÅ¿t laudable and commendable of all others.

To make the which more eaÅ¿ie, and the better to inÅ¿truct the young Chirurgion: I haue gathered together all that I could poÅ¿sibly, out of that which I haue obÅ¿erued this forty yeares and aboue, wherein I haue practiÅ¿ed it, and Å¿eene it practiÅ¿ed, in the greateÅ¿t families both within, and without this Kingdom, where, thanks be to God, good vÅ¿e hath beene made of me. And withall I haue not refuÅ¿ed nor diÅ¿dained to go vnto the meanest, mooued partly by Charity, and partly to make my Å¿elfe more and more experienced therein.

Hauing then conferred together, what eyther the Graecians and Latines both ancient and Moderne haue written, with that I haue beene able to obÅ¿erue: and hauing reduced it all into one, I haue put it into French in fauour of thoÅ¿e who are not Å¿o well learned, and haue not the knowledge of the Greeke or Latine tongues.

Some will Å¿ay (to diminiÅ¿h that little honor, which I might get by this my labour) that the Ancients haue written the greateÅ¿t part heereof. But they Å¿hall learne from the mouth of this great Oracle, That there is no leÅ¿Å¿e witte and vnderÅ¿tanding required, to bee able to iudge of Sciences formerly written, then to bee the firÅ¿t Authors of them.

I know Moreouer, that in the Doctrine, and much more in the phraÅ¿e, Å¿ome will find many things to be reprehended. But I intreat the Reader, that he would receiue it in as good part as I offer it him: and likewiÅ¿e
exhort others, (that are more experienced, then I am: to doe better. Let them Å¿hew me my faults friendly; and I will not refuÅ¿e, willingly to retract them: after the example of that diuine Hipocrates, who freely confeÅ¿Å¿ed his, Å¿aying openly, that he had gotten more diÅ¿honor, then either glory, or credit, by practiÅ¿ing of PhiÅ¿icke.

div.head: The TranÅ¿lators Preface.
div.p:
THus far hath the Authour pleaded for him Å¿elfe, whom while I TranÅ¿late, leaÅ¿t the fault be tranÅ¿lated vpon me, I will Å¿peake Å¿omewhat for my Å¿elfe, before I be accuÅ¿ed: leaÅ¿t when I am accuÅ¿ed, there be no bodie to Å¿peake for me: If therefore it be thought preiudiciall, either to the literarie common-wealth of PhyÅ¿icke, that I haue exported and made common a commoditie, which the learned would haue had priuate to themÅ¿elues: or if I haue been oftenÅ¿iue to Women, in proÅ¿tituting and divulging that, which they would not haue come to open light, and which beÅ¿ide cannot be expreÅ¿t in Å¿uch modeÅ¿t termes, as are fit for the virginitie of pen & paper, and the white Å¿heetes of their Child-bed. I muÅ¿t (as well as I can) defend my Å¿elfe from theÅ¿e imputations, and Å¿hew my care to keep both learning and modeÅ¿tie illibate, and inuiolable. FirÅ¿t then, I haue done no more in this, then the Author hath in his French Copie, which is
common to be had and read in that vulgar tongue: In defence of which, and this the Å¿hadow therof, I muÅ¿t Å¿ay that it is not writ Å¿o much for the learned (who notwithÅ¿tanding, if they haue not the french, may make vÅ¿e of this) as for the Chirurgions, & Midwiues, who are called to this kinde of employment. As for women (whom I am moÅ¿t afraid to offend) they muÅ¿t be content to haue their infirmities detected, if they will haue helpe for them, which I wiÅ¿h might not come to any eare or eye, but to thoÅ¿e which they themÅ¿elues would haue acquainted therewith, and as well for their Å¿akes, as mine owne Å¿atisfaction: I haue endeuoured to be as priuate and retired, in expreÅ¿sing al the paÅ¿Å¿ages in this kind as poÅ¿sibly I could.

And with this I hope all good Gentlewomen will reÅ¿t Å¿atisfied: to whom I wiÅ¿h all happineÅ¿Å¿e of increaÅ¿e, and all increaÅ¿e of happineÅ¿Å¿e, that they may haue a good houre for this buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e, and for all other Contentments, many good daies and yeares.

div.head: The Å¿ignes to know whether a woman be with childe, or no. CHAP. I.
div.p:

And wee haue Å¿eene the experience hereof in Å¿ome women, which were (without all queÅ¿tion) thought to be Å¿o great, that the Midwife was euen ready to receiue the child:A Å¿tory. who notwithÅ¿tanding haue beene freed and acquitted heereof either by their naturall purgings and euacuations, or by voiding of water, or elÅ¿e expelling of winde. The which hapned vnto Mad. P. to her great griefe, who was deliuered of certaine gallons of water, when Å¿he thought aÅ¿Å¿uredly that Å¿he had beene with childe. I Å¿aw the contrary happen to the daughter of M. Marcel: who was iudged
by foure of the chiefe PhyÅ¿itians, and as many Chirurgions, and two Midwiues, not to haue beene with childe; and yet being dead, there was found in her body, a child betweene Å¿ix and Å¿euen months old. And of late memorie, Å¿ome of the moÅ¿t expert PhyÅ¿itians, and Chirurgions of our time,Another. vndertooke the cure of an honeÅ¿t woman; and from the third vntill the eighth moneth of her time, adminiÅ¿tred vnto her infinite many CliÅ¿ters, Apozemes, Potions, Fomentations, and Iniections, and yet could not they prouoke her naturall Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e, much leÅ¿Å¿e cauÅ¿e her to be deliuered. At length in the ninth moneth, Å¿he thinking that Å¿he had had the Chollicke, was brought a bed of a faire daughter, being verily perÅ¿waded euen then when Å¿he was in trauaile that Å¿he was not with child, as Å¿he had aÅ¿Å¿ured vs, all the time that Å¿he went. Directions for the Chirurgion.So that a Chirurgion being called to giue his opinion of the conception of a woman, whether it be in a iudiciall, or priuate caÅ¿e, muÅ¿t be very warie and circumÅ¿pect what iudgement he giues herein.
The ancient and moderne writers haue left Å¿ome Å¿ignes whereby we may foretell it, which are collected from the Husband, from the Wife, from the Child, and from the Midwife.

As for thoÅ¿e Å¿ignes which are taken from the Man, they are theÅ¿e:Signes of coÌ ception taken from the man If he finde an extraordinarie contentment in the companie of his Wife; and if he feele at the Å¿ame time a kind of Å¿ucking or drawing at the end of his yard; if he returne from the field of nature, not ouer-moyÅ¿t, theÅ¿e are Å¿ignes that
a woman may haue conceiued.Experiment. And by theÅ¿e obÅ¿eruations I haue knowne men which haue aÅ¿Å¿ured their Wiues that they haue got them with child, as Å¿oone as they haue had their company.

Signes taken from the woman.The Å¿ignes which are taken from the Woman are more manifeÅ¿t and certaine: and although the greateÅ¿t part of them bee found in Women and Maids, which cannot haue their naturall courÅ¿es: yet neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e all theÅ¿e Å¿ignes ioyned together, a man may preÅ¿ume as farre of them as arte wil permit, and they be theÅ¿e: If Å¿he receiued an extraordinarie delight in the companie of her Husband: if from her naturall parts (whether they continue dry or moiÅ¿t) there iÅ¿Å¿ue or flow nothing forth, becauÅ¿e it is no neceÅ¿Å¿arie conÅ¿equence, that thoÅ¿e parts Å¿hould alwaies remaine dry, Å¿ince the Matrice retaineth onely that, which is fit for the conformation of the child. LikewiÅ¿e, if at the Å¿ame time Å¿he hath a kind of yawning, and Å¿tretching, and feeles within her a Å¿haking or quiuering (Å¿uch as we commonly find preÅ¿ently vpon making of water) which runneth through the whole body, with a kind of chilneÅ¿Å¿e, and is felt chiefely betweene the Å¿houlders and the backe, with Å¿ome paine about the Nauell, and a rumbling or diÅ¿quietneÅ¿Å¿e in the neather belly, which hapneth, becauÅ¿e the Matrice Å¿hrinks it Å¿elfe together,The wombe Å¿huts it Å¿elfe to entertaine and embrace the matter of generation which it hath drawne and Å¿uckt in, feeling thereby a kind of tickling. Againe, if within few dayes Å¿he falles a vomiting, and Å¿pitting, diÅ¿taÅ¿ts her meate, groweth dull, careleÅ¿Å¿e, and
qualmiÅ¿h, longeth after Å¿trange things, finding her belly fallen, and growne flat, according to the French prouerbe.

Which makes them oftentimes to complaine and Å¿ay they be quite fallen away. Then not long after her belly Å¿wells and growes bigger; her hips and raines are inlarged; her courÅ¿es appeare not, which Å¿hould flow at certain times,Some women when they be with child haue their courÅ¿es. (although Å¿ome haue them wheÌ they be with child.) LikewiÅ¿e if towards the Å¿econd month her eyes grow hollow & wan, her eye-balls Å¿hew leÅ¿Å¿e: the lids be looÅ¿e, limber, and Å¿oft: the veines in the corners of her eyes more Å¿wollen, and bigger then ordinarie. Hippocrates. For as H â¢ ppocrates Å¿aith, if thou canÅ¿t not finde by any meanes whether a woman be with child, or no, her very eyes wil tell thee: for their eyes be more hollow, and Å¿unke inward; and the white is turned bluiÅ¿h: the veines and arteryes of their neck are puÅ¿t vp, and more apparent then vÅ¿ually: their breÅ¿ts grow big, and hard, with Å¿ome paine and pricking, hauing alÅ¿o milke within them: the nipple waxeth firme, and hard: red, if it be a boy; and Å¿ometime blackiÅ¿h, if it be a wench, which hapneth about the third or fourth moneth, when they begin to quicken.

Signes taken from vrines.Some iudge of their being with child by the vrine, as if it be white, and clearely mingled with little moates, and that at the top there is perceiued
as it were a little cloud like to the Rainebow; or of an Opall colour, At the bottome there appeares a certaine thicke Å¿ediment, which beeing Å¿haken, Å¿preads it Å¿elfe into little flocks, like to carded wooll. Experiment of Fernelius.
Fernelius makes this triall, which is, to take equall quantities of the womans vrine, and of white wine and to Å¿hake them well together, if this mixture looke like the broth of Beanes, it is a Å¿igne Å¿he is with child.

Hippocrates. Hydromell is made of hony and water boiled together. Hippocrates Å¿ets downe diuers experiments, as to giue the woman Hydromell to drinke made with raine water at night when Å¿he goes to bed, or elÅ¿e Hony and AnniÅ¿Å¿eed beaten and diÅ¿Å¿olued in water. If Å¿he be with child, Å¿he will feele great paines and griping in her belly, (vnleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿he be vÅ¿ed to Å¿uch kind of drinke, Auicen. as Auicen Å¿aith.) BeÅ¿ides, if Å¿he receiue below any Å¿trong or Å¿tinking oder or Å¿mell, her clothes being well wrapped cloÅ¿e about her, and the Å¿ent pierce not vp into her noÅ¿e, Å¿he hath conceiued: As alÅ¿o, hauing ouer night put vp a cloue of Garlicke, if in the morning the Å¿auour or taÅ¿te come not into her mouth.

TrueÅ¿t Å¿ignes gathered from the Child.But theÅ¿e Å¿ignes are not Å¿o certaine, the trueÅ¿t and Å¿ureÅ¿t are thoÅ¿e which are collected from the child, when he begins to Å¿tirre and mooue, which commonly happens in the third and fourth moneth. Another certaine Å¿igne may be perceiued by the Midwife,Signes gathered by the Midwife. who putting vp her finger into the wombe to touch the inner orifice thereof, if the woman be with child Å¿he Å¿hall finde it Å¿o cloÅ¿e Å¿hut, that the point of a needle will Å¿carÅ¿e enter therein, yet Å¿oft, and without any hardneÅ¿Å¿e, which alÅ¿o will bee drawn vpward being Å¿hrunke and as it were truÅ¿Å¿ed vp, becauÅ¿e the body of the Matrice doth gather it Å¿elfe together to embrace the Å¿eed, which is the reaÅ¿on that the Midwife can very hardly come to reach it with her finger.

Some women when they be with child hate the companie of their husbands: which quality is Å¿aid alÅ¿o to be in brute beaÅ¿ts when they be great with yong, who commonly Å¿hun the company of the Male. And Å¿urely there be certaine times and Å¿eaÅ¿ons of the yeare proper for brute beaÅ¿ts to couple, but man (as Pliny Å¿aith) hath neither time nor Å¿eaÅ¿on limited him, neither day nor howre appointed him, that Å¿o he might haue his deÅ¿ire at all times: which hath been thus ordained by nature, as being more fit, and neceÅ¿Å¿ary for man to multiplie in his kind he being (the liuely image of God, and made to behold his glory) then for brute beaÅ¿ts, which were created onely for the vÅ¿e of man.

I know well the anÅ¿were that thoÅ¿e two noble Ladies, Poppea the daughter of Agrippina, A pleaÅ¿ant anÅ¿were. and Iulia the daughter of Augustus made concerning this matter. The one Å¿ayd, that brute beaÅ¿ts cannot taÅ¿te the delight which women receiue that are with child, becauÅ¿e they are without reaÅ¿on: and

div.head: The Å¿ignes whereby to know whether a woman be with child of a boy or a wench. CHAP. II.
div.p: HAuing Å¿hewne the meanes to know whether a woman be truely conceiued, it will not be from the purpoÅ¿e to handle this queÅ¿tion for the Å¿atisfaction of Å¿ome curious minds, who as Å¿oone as the Chirurgion hath giuen his cenÅ¿ure that a woman is with child, demaunds preÅ¿ently of him whether it will be a boy,The difference of Å¿exe is hard to foretell. or a wench? But as it is very hard to know at the firÅ¿t whether the woman be with child or no, Å¿o by great reaÅ¿on muÅ¿t it needs be farre more difficult to diÅ¿cerne, and diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h the difference of the Å¿exe, and to determine whether it will be a boy or a wench.

I know there are Å¿ome that boaÅ¿t they can certainely do it, but for the moÅ¿t part it hapneth rather by chance, then through either arte or skill. And for proofe thereof, I haue Å¿hewed them a child newly come from the mothers wombe, onely laying my hand vpon the priuie parts, yet durÅ¿t they not be Å¿o bold as giue their opinion thereof, Å¿aying, that it were more eaÅ¿ie to iudge of it when it was in the wombe, Å¿eeing that from thence might be gathered many euident Å¿ignes: but wee muÅ¿t account the greateÅ¿t part of them to be vncertaine,
as we haue formerly Å¿aid. NeuertheleÅ¿Å¿e, to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h the Male from the Female, we will preÅ¿ently Å¿hew all the marks which we euer knew, or could obÅ¿erue, either out of the ancient, or moderne writers.

And firÅ¿t of all, yong women commonly are with child rather of a boy then of a wench, becauÅ¿e they be hoter then the elder women, which was obÅ¿erued by AriÅ¿totle, who Å¿aith farther, Aristotle. that if an aged woman which neuer had children before, chance to conceiue, one may be Å¿ure it will be a wench. The like hapneth (as Å¿ome write) to women, which conceiue when the winde is in the South, who for the moÅ¿t part bring forth daughters, and when the Northwind bloweth, Å¿onnes.ObÅ¿eruation.

Hippocrates Å¿aith, Hipp. Aph. that a woman which goeth with a boy hath a good colour, for a woman in her caÅ¿e, but if it be of a wench, Å¿he will haue a worÅ¿e complexion. LikewiÅ¿e if the right breaÅ¿t be harder and firmer, the nipple hard, red, and more eminent, the milke white and thicke, which being milked or Å¿pirtled againÅ¿t a Å¿leeke-Å¿tone, or Å¿ome Å¿uch Å¿mooth thing, continues in a round forme like a pearle,Signes of a boy. and being caÅ¿t euen into water it diÅ¿Å¿olueth not, but Å¿inks directly to the bottome: and if you make a cake with the Å¿aid milke and flower, and in the baking it continues firme, and cloÅ¿e, it is a Å¿igne the woman is with child of a boy. Againe, Å¿he that goeth with a boy, hath the right Å¿ide of her belly bigger, and more copped, and there the child Å¿tirreth ofteneÅ¿t. This motion commonly at Å¿ixe
weekes is Å¿carÅ¿e Å¿enÅ¿ible, but at two months and a halfe more manifeÅ¿t. The Male child lyeth high aboue the Nauell by reaÅ¿on of his heate, and the Female at the bottome of the belly, becauÅ¿e of her coldnes and weight. They which be with child of a boy are more quicke and nimble in all their actions, and be in better health of body, without being Å¿ubiect to many infirmities, which commonly happen to women with child of a wench.

An honeÅ¿t Gentlewoman aÅ¿Å¿ured me that Å¿he had made triall of this receipt, which is,An experiment. to take an equall quantitie of Claret wine, and of vrine made in the morning, put them together into a glaÅ¿Å¿e, and let them Å¿tand a whole day, if there appeare in the bottome a groÅ¿Å¿e cloud, thicke like to Beane-broth, it is a Å¿igne the woman is with child of a boy, if it appeare in the middeÅ¿t, it is Å¿igne of a wench, if there be nothing found in the bottome but the ordinary reÅ¿idence of vrine, it Å¿hewes Å¿he is not with child at all.

An experiment likewiÅ¿e may be made out of the practiÅ¿e of Liuia, Another experiment of Liuia. the Mother of the Emperour Tiberius, who being with child, and deÅ¿irous to know with what Å¿he went, tooke an egge from vnder a Henne that Å¿ate, and kept it warme Å¿o long in her hands, till at laÅ¿t a Cock-Chicken was hatched out of it, whereby Å¿he knew that Å¿he Å¿hould haue a Å¿onne, which proued to be Tyberius the Emperour, as Suetonius reporteth.

Heere will it not be beÅ¿ide our purpoÅ¿e to Å¿et downe what Hippocrates writes in his booke de Å¿uperfaetatione, The meanes how to bege â¢ a Å¿onne, or a daughter. of the meanes how to get a man or woman-child. div.head: The Å¿ignes whereby to know that a woman goeth with two children. CHAP. III.
div.p:
To know whether a woman will bring two children. THe Å¿ignes that a woman hath conceiued two children, doe Å¿eldome appeare before the third or fourth moneth, which then is knowne, both by the mouing of the children, and alÅ¿o by the greatnes and Å¿welling of the womans belly. div.head: Of falÅ¿e Conception. CHAP. IIII.
div.p: WOmen are oftentimes deceiued in reckoning themÅ¿elues with child, for they thinke themÅ¿elues with child when it is nothing but the Å¿topping of their naturall Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e, which keepeth not due courÅ¿e. Some haue a falÅ¿e conception, which is as it were the beginning of Mola. Others haue the Mola it Å¿elfe, which we commonly call the Moone-calfe.

FalÅ¿e conception is a lump of fleÅ¿h gathered together commonly like to the gizard of a fowle,What a falÅ¿e conception is. which is bigger or leÅ¿Å¿er according to the continuance of it, which nature commonly expelleth in the Å¿econd, third, or fourth month. But the Mola is farre bigger, and continues a yeare or two, yea ten or twelue, and Å¿ometime as long as the woman liues. Of this Mola there be two kinds, the one may be called a true, the other a falÅ¿e one.Mola is either true, or falÅ¿e. The true Mola is fleÅ¿hy, being nothing elÅ¿e but an vnprofitable maÅ¿Å¿e, without Å¿hape or forme, hard and firme, bred within the Matrice, and cleauing to the Å¿ides thereof. The falÅ¿e Mola is of three Å¿orts, the one windy, being a collection of groÅ¿Å¿e winds: the Å¿econd watriÅ¿h, or a heaping together of waters: the
third humorall, or a meeting of many humors. All three contained within the capacitie of the womb, which doth make them differ from the Å¿welling, hardnes, or Scyrehus of the Å¿aid wombe, or from any fleÅ¿h, water, or humor, which may chance to cleaue to, or touch the outward part thereof. TheÅ¿e are often bred together with the child,Mola bred together with the child. but then they cauÅ¿e death, either for that the child is deceiued of his nouriÅ¿hment which is carried to the Mola; or becauÅ¿e he wanting roome, cannot grow and come to perfection.

Hippocrates.
Hippocrates Å¿aith, that there be Å¿ome liuing and Å¿ome dead Moles. The dead are like to the falÅ¿e burthens, Å¿o called, becauÅ¿e women carry them not long, as being but lightly tyed and faÅ¿tned to the Å¿ides of the Matrice. Sometime they are deuided into diuers Å¿euerall pieces, Å¿o that Nicholas Nicolus Å¿aith, he Å¿aw a woman which caÅ¿t forth nine of them in one day, the leaÅ¿t whereof waighed foure pound. The quicke and liuing Moles are they which wholy cleaue to the wombe, and continue with the woman euen to her death.

CauÅ¿e of the fleÅ¿h Mole.The cauÅ¿e of the fleÅ¿hy Mole according to the ancient writers cannot wholly proceede from the woman, but the man muÅ¿t adde Å¿omewhat thereunto. Galen holdeth, that it is bred when the mans Å¿eed is weake, barren, imperfect, or in little quantitie; and for the moÅ¿t part choked through the abundance of the menÅ¿truous bloud, which is groÅ¿Å¿e and thicke, vnfit for the framing of a child, Å¿o that in Å¿tead thereof is bread a lumpe of fleÅ¿h that by
little and little increaÅ¿eth, being wrapped in his owne membrane, which nature effecteth, as deÅ¿irous to bring forth any thing rather then to be idle.

The windie Mole is ingendred through want of heate in the Matrice, and other parts adioyning,Windie Mole. as the Liuer and Spleene, whereby much wind is bred and Å¿hut vp in the emptineÅ¿Å¿e of the wombe. It may alÅ¿o come from without, as in women newly deliuered, and in Å¿uch which hauing had their naturall courÅ¿es in great abundance, doe venture too Å¿oone into the cold aire.

The watry Mole proceeds from the abundance of watrie Å¿howres which is Å¿ent from the Liuer,Watry Mole. or the Spleene, or other parts thereabouts; or elÅ¿e through the weakenes of the Matrice, which cannot aÅ¿Å¿imilate the bloud that is brought to nouriÅ¿h it, part whereof is turned into water, and being not voided, Å¿tayeth in the wombe.

The humorall Mole is bred by reaÅ¿on of too much moiÅ¿ture, as of Å¿erious, or whayiÅ¿h humors,Humorall of the whites, or watriÅ¿h euacuations, which come downe through the veÅ¿Å¿els of the Matrice, and are Å¿tayed in the concauitie thereof.

FalÅ¿e conception hath Å¿ome common Å¿ignes with the true, as Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ion of the naturall courÅ¿es,Common Å¿ignes. depraued appetite, diÅ¿taÅ¿tfulneÅ¿Å¿e, vomiting, Å¿welling of the belly and breaÅ¿ts, Å¿o that it is very hard to diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h the one from the other. But theÅ¿e that follow are more proper to the falÅ¿e,Signes of falÅ¿e conception. then the true birth: for (as Hippocrates Å¿aith) In falÅ¿e conception, or Mola, the face is commonly puft vp, their
breaÅ¿ts which were Å¿wollen at the beginning, doe fall, and dayly wax Å¿oft, limber, and lanke, and without milke. In the end, the face, breaÅ¿ts, armes, thighes, and legs grow leane and thin: true it is, that they Å¿well towards night, like thoÅ¿e that haue the dropÅ¿ie, the belly riÅ¿eth and groweth quickly, and withall very hard, for the moÅ¿t part of an equall roundneÅ¿Å¿e, with diuers pricking paines in the bottome of the belly that neuer ceaÅ¿e, which makes them that they can hardly walke, being hindred as it were with a heauie burthen, and hauing oftentimes a windineÅ¿Å¿e in the wombe, as AhaÅ¿is reporteth.

Signes from the motion.The Å¿aid Hippocrates obÅ¿erueth, how that by the motion it may eaÅ¿ily be knowne, for in true conception the male child beginneth to Å¿tirre at the end of the third moneth, or Å¿ooner; and the female at the third or fourth moneth: and where there is no Å¿uch quickning, we muÅ¿t obÅ¿erue whether there be any milke in the breÅ¿ts, if there be none found, it is a Å¿igne that it is a Mole.The child moueth of it Å¿elfe, and not the Mole. BeÅ¿ide, the mother feeleth the child moue euery way, both on the right Å¿ide, and on the left, as much aboue, as below, and in the middle, without any helpe. But in falÅ¿e conception, though there be Å¿ome motion, it is not animall, but proceedeth rather from the expulÅ¿iue facultie of the Mother then of the Mole, which hauing no liuing Å¿oule endeuoureth not of it Å¿elfe to come forth, neither prouoketh the wombe as the child doth, who hauing neede of aire to breath in, Å¿eekes after it. But this is a moÅ¿t euident Å¿igne when
the woman lyes downe on either Å¿ide, for then Å¿he feeles it fall like a boule, and is not able to vphold, or Å¿tay it; yea, and being laid on her backe, if her belly be preÅ¿Å¿ed or cruÅ¿hed, it will remaine in the place whither it is thruÅ¿t, without comming backe againe. Now that which moÅ¿t aÅ¿Å¿ureth vs, is,True Å¿ignes. when the nine moneths are paÅ¿t, and the woman not deliuered, but her belly growes bigger, and Å¿welleth more and more, and all the other parts grow leane and leÅ¿Å¿e, this is a Å¿ure Å¿igne of a Mole, though there be Å¿ome women that haue borne their children ten, yea, eleuen moneths.

The Å¿ignes of the windy Mole are theÅ¿e,Signes of the windy. the belly is equally Å¿wollen and Å¿tretched like a bladder, Å¿ofter then in the fleÅ¿hy Mole, and chiefely neere the groine and neather belly, which being Å¿truck vpon Å¿oundeth like a Tabour: Å¿ometime it decreaÅ¿eth, and otherwhile it Å¿welleth more: it is Å¿ooner bred and increaÅ¿ed then the fleÅ¿hy or watery, and Å¿tretches the belly as though it would teare it, which is not proper to the fleÅ¿hy.

As for the watery and humorall,Signes of the watry and humorall. the Å¿ignes are almoÅ¿t alike, the belly growes big, and riÅ¿eth by little and little. If you touch it with your finger Å¿ometimes the print thereof will remaine behind: it is euen, without any hardneÅ¿Å¿e. It is true, that the woman lying on her backe, her flancks are fuller and bigger then the middle and bottome of the belly, which waxe flat, the water and humor running froÌ one Å¿ide to the other; and in Å¿haking the belly, they feele a Å¿wimming and floting of water.

Difference betweene the Watry and Humorall.This difference may be alÅ¿o added, that in the the watriÅ¿h the flancks, groine, and Å¿ometime the thighes are more diÅ¿tended and Å¿wollen then in the humorall, becauÅ¿e the wateriÅ¿h Å¿ubÅ¿tance Å¿tealeth thither Å¿ooneÅ¿t: beÅ¿ides, that which paÅ¿Å¿eth forth and bloweth below is cleare like water, without any ill Å¿mell; but that which floweth in the humorall is reddiÅ¿h, and like to the waÅ¿hing of fleÅ¿h, and of a bad Å¿ent. This alÅ¿o is to be obÅ¿erued, that in the falÅ¿e conception the naturall courÅ¿es flow not, and that the Nauell doth Å¿hew it Å¿elfe but little, or not at all, as it commonly doth when the Mother is with child. Concerning the cure thereof, I meane (god-willing) to handle it hereafter.

div.head: What dyet and order a woman with child ought to keepe. CHAP. V.
div.p: THat a woman with child may enioy her perfect health, Å¿he muÅ¿t diligently obÅ¿erue that which conÅ¿iÅ¿teth in the vÅ¿e of the Å¿ixe things not naturall, which are the Aire, Meate and Drinke, ExerciÅ¿e and ReÅ¿t, Sleeping and Waking, FulneÅ¿Å¿e and EmptineÅ¿Å¿e, and the PaÅ¿Å¿ions of the Minde.

Good Aire fit for a woman with childFirÅ¿t therefore Å¿he muÅ¿t dwell and liue in a good and well tempered Aire, which is neither too hote, nor too cold, or wateriÅ¿h: not Å¿ubiect to any foggie miÅ¿ts, or winds, and eÅ¿pecially the South-wind. For
(as Hippocrates Å¿aith) when thoÅ¿e winds doe blow vpon euery light occaÅ¿ion, women miÅ¿carrie. The Northwind alÅ¿o is hurtfull vnto them, for thoÅ¿e winds breed thin rheumes, diÅ¿tillations, & troubleÅ¿ome Coughs in great-bellyed women,The Cough naught for women with child. cauÅ¿ing them oftentimes to abort, or be deliuered before their due time. LikewiÅ¿e Å¿uch winds as bring with them ill Å¿mells and vapours, which being drawne in together with the Aire we breathe, into the Lungs, do many times breed very dangerous and troubleÅ¿ome diÅ¿eaÅ¿es. Aristotle Å¿aith,Bad Å¿mells to be auoided. that the Å¿mell of a Candle put forth, may cauÅ¿e a woman to abort, or looÅ¿e her fruite: wherefore Å¿he muÅ¿t beware of all ill Aire, and make her abode in houÅ¿es well and pleaÅ¿antly Å¿eated, Å¿hunning as much as may be poÅ¿Å¿ible all bad Å¿auours.

Concerning her Dyet,Her Dyet. Å¿he muÅ¿t vÅ¿e meates which be of good nouriÅ¿hment, and breede good iuice, moderately drying. The quantitie muÅ¿t be Å¿ufficient both for her Å¿elfe, and for her child, and therefore they are to be diÅ¿penced withall from faÅ¿ting at any time: for Å¿ometime too much abÅ¿tinence makes the child weake and Å¿ickly, and cauÅ¿eth him often to be borne before his time, Å¿eeking after nouriÅ¿hment, which he cannot find within his Mothers body. As alÅ¿o the too great quantity of meate his Mother takes, may often Å¿tifle him,Too much meate Å¿tifleth. or elÅ¿e make him grow Å¿o big, that he cannot keepe himÅ¿elfe in his place, which conÅ¿traines him either to come forth, or elÅ¿e makes him Å¿ickly, Å¿eeing that thoÅ¿e meates are corrupted wherewith he is nouriÅ¿hed
a fed. Hippocrates writeth in Epidem. that the SiÅ¿ter of Caius Duellius after Å¿he had eate her fill, aborted.

All meates which are either too hote, cold, or too moiÅ¿t, are to be auoided, and chiefely in the beginning of meales;Salt meates bad. as alÅ¿o thoÅ¿e which are too Å¿alt, or ouer-much Å¿piced; and likewiÅ¿e all baked meates are vtterly forbidden. Aristotle and Plinie write, that if a woman with child eate much Å¿alt meate, her childe will be borne without nayles; which Å¿hewes, that he will not be long liued. Her Bread muÅ¿t be of good Wheate, well kneaded, light, and alÅ¿o well baked.Fit meates. For her meate Å¿he may vÅ¿e Henne, Chicken, Capon, yong Pigeons, Turtle, PheaÅ¿ants, Larks, Partridge, Veale, & Mutton: and for Herbs, let her take LettuÅ¿e,Hearbs. Endiue, Borage, BugloÅ¿Å¿e, and Sorrell, abÅ¿taining from all raw Sallads. She may cloÅ¿e her Å¿tomacke after meate with Peares, or Quinces bak't or preÅ¿erued; as likewiÅ¿e with Cheries, or DamÅ¿ons. She muÅ¿t Å¿hun all diureticall things,Diureticall and windy meates are naught. which prouoketh either vrine, or the naturall courÅ¿es, and Å¿uch as are windie, as PeaÅ¿e and Beanes. NotwithÅ¿tanding, women with child haue oftentimes Å¿uch diÅ¿ordinate appetite, by reaÅ¿on of Å¿ome Å¿alt or Å¿harp humor which is contained within the membranes of the Å¿tomacke, that they deÅ¿ire to eate Coles, Chalke, AÅ¿hes, Waxe, Salt-fiÅ¿h raw, yea and vnwatred; and to drinke Veriuice, and Vineger, yea very dregs, Å¿o that it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible to hinder them from eating and taÅ¿ting them. But yet they muÅ¿t refraine and ouer-maiÅ¿ter themÅ¿elues
therein as much as they can, Å¿ince that Å¿uch foode may much hurt and hinder both their owne and their childs health. NeuertheleÅ¿Å¿e if they cannot forbeare, Å¿uffer them a little, and let them haue their longings, for feare leaÅ¿t it Å¿hould proue worÅ¿e with them.Accidents that may happen. For I haue Å¿eene many women which being hindered and forbidden froÌ vÅ¿ing Å¿uch traÅ¿h, haue preÅ¿ently fallen into trauell: and in others, their children haue carried the marks of Å¿ome of the things they Å¿o earneÅ¿tly deÅ¿ired and longed after. BeÅ¿ide, although that Å¿uch meates for the moÅ¿t part are very bad and contrary, Lib. 2. Aph. 38. Cibus & potus deterior, Å¿uauior tamen: melioribus quidem Å¿ed inÅ¿uauioribus eÅ¿t anteponendus. yet for the deÅ¿ire they haue to eate them they are digeÅ¿ted commonly without hurting the partie at all. Meate and drinke (Å¿aith Hippocrates) is better and fitter, though it be Å¿ome-what worÅ¿e, then that which is better, and not Å¿o agreeable and pleaÅ¿ing.

For her Drinke Å¿he may vÅ¿e Claret wine, mature,Her Drinke. and not too Å¿trong, which Å¿he muÅ¿t allay very well. For this Wine hath power to comfort and Å¿trengthen the Å¿tomacke, and all the other parts Å¿eruing for nouriÅ¿hment and generation: and if Å¿he cannot away with Wine, let her drinke Hydromell, or Barley-water well boyled.

Her Å¿leepe muÅ¿t be in the night,Her Sleepe. the better to digeÅ¿t the meate Å¿he hath taken: for watchings doe ingender crudities and diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, which cauÅ¿e vntimely births in Å¿tead of faire and goodly children; and chiefely, Å¿he muÅ¿t auoid Å¿leeping after dinner. But in the morning Å¿he may take her eaÅ¿e, as Å¿he Å¿hall thinke beÅ¿t, yet not turning (as Å¿ome great Ladies
do) the day into night, and the night into day.

ExerciÅ¿e.She may vÅ¿e moderate exerciÅ¿e, but violent motion looÅ¿neth the Cotiledons or veÅ¿Å¿els of the Matrice whereby the child receiues his nouriÅ¿hment. They muÅ¿t be forbid riding in Waggins or Coaches, eÅ¿pecially in the three firÅ¿t months: for as vpon a Å¿mall occaÅ¿ion we Å¿ee the fruits and flowers of trees do fall (as by Å¿ome little wind that Å¿hakes the tree, or the like,) Å¿o many times through a light cauÅ¿e women great with child,CauÅ¿es of Abortment. in Å¿tirring or moouing themÅ¿elues, yea, or but Å¿etting their foot awry, may be deliuer'd before their time.

It was not without good cauÅ¿e that the Romanes forbad their Wiues to ride in Coaches, the which alÅ¿o ought to be obÅ¿erued in theÅ¿e dayes, eÅ¿pecially by thoÅ¿e who are Å¿ubiect to take hurt, and therefore let them walke gently, taking an eÅ¿peciall heed and care to themÅ¿elues the firÅ¿t three moneths.

Great noyÅ¿es hurtfull.She muÅ¿t Å¿hun all great noyÅ¿e and Å¿ounds, as of Thunder, Artillery, and great Bells. Galen in his booke de Theriaca, Å¿ayth, that many women with child haue died with the very fright they receiued by a clap of thunder: and when Å¿he is afraid of hurting her Å¿elfe or falling into trauaile, let her be carried in a Chaire or Litter between two Å¿trong men, and chiefely two howres before meales: for as a woman may eaÅ¿ily looÅ¿e her burthen the firÅ¿t moneth, becauÅ¿e her child (though he be but little) is not yet firmely faÅ¿tned and tyed to the wombe, Å¿o likewiÅ¿e being great or big through his weight, he may fall downe, and come forth; wherefore all violent
exerciÅ¿e, and too much labour,Violent exerciÅ¿e hurtfull. is hurtfull and dangerous for her; as alÅ¿o to fret, chide, or laugh immoderately. The fourth, fifth, and Å¿ixth moneth Å¿he may vÅ¿e more libertie, the Å¿euenth and eight Å¿he muÅ¿t keepe herÅ¿elfe Å¿till and quiet, but when Å¿he is in her ninth moneth, then may Å¿he vÅ¿e more Å¿tirring, and exerciÅ¿e. And therefore is it that AriÅ¿totle in his Politicks appointeth,Sentence of AriÅ¿totle. that women with child Å¿hould not be Å¿edentary, nor liue too nicely, but that Å¿ince God hath bleÅ¿Å¿ed them to beare children, they Å¿hould dayly viÅ¿it the Temples of the Gods for their exerciÅ¿e.

The which Plato expreÅ¿Å¿ely commandeth in his Common-wealth, and by a kind of deuotion,Opinion of Plato. and religious pietie. But AriÅ¿totle in that place Å¿peaketh like a PhyÅ¿ition, as he Å¿heweth in his booke de Generatione. In the Countrey (Å¿aith he) where women accuÅ¿tome themÅ¿elues to labour, they are brought abed more eaÅ¿ily, and with leÅ¿Å¿e paine. In briefe, where women exerciÅ¿e themÅ¿elues,Women that labour are eaÅ¿ily deliuered. they are Å¿ooner deliuered, for their exerciÅ¿e conÅ¿umes the excrements, which idle and Å¿lothfull women gather and heape together.

In the firÅ¿t foure moneths Å¿he muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e abandon Venus for feare of Å¿haking the child,Venus forbidden. and bringing downe her courÅ¿es, which muÅ¿t alÅ¿o be obÅ¿erued in the Å¿ixth and eight moneth, but in the Å¿euenth and ninth Å¿he may boldly vÅ¿e it, eÅ¿pecially toward the end of the ninth moneth, which Å¿ome are of opinion will help and haÅ¿ten the deliuery.

Aristotle is of this opinion, (though herein he
contradicts the authority of Hippocrates,
Aristotles opinion.) The woman with child (Å¿aith he) ought not to haue the company of her husband. But Aristotle and Hippocrates may eaÅ¿ily be reconciled; the PhiloÅ¿opher meaneth, that they Å¿hould not embrace their wiues all the time of their being with child, but onely toward the time of their lying in, thereby to Å¿hake the child, and make him come the more readily forth; for comming into the world after this acte, he is commonly enwrapped and compaÅ¿Å¿ed with Å¿lime, which helpeth his comming forth.

Her belly muÅ¿t be Å¿oluble.It is alÅ¿o requiÅ¿ite that her belly be looÅ¿e, not retaining her excrements, and that Å¿he haue (if it be poÅ¿Å¿ible) euery day the benefit of Nature, which if it be not done naturally, it muÅ¿t be helpt, taking euery morning Å¿ome broth of Damaske-Prunes; AlÅ¿o Apples Å¿tued with Suger, and a little Butter, is very fit and good. She may vÅ¿e Broth wherein Borage, BugloÅ¿Å¿e, PurÅ¿lane, LettuÅ¿e, Patience, and a little of the herbe Mercury hath beene boyled. She may likewiÅ¿e take SuppoÅ¿itaries Å¿o they be not too Å¿harpe.CliÅ¿ters. CliÅ¿ters made of a Calues-head, or of a Sheepes-head, boyled with Annis-Å¿eed, and Fennil-Å¿eed, wherein Å¿ome courÅ¿e Suger, and oyle of Violets is diÅ¿Å¿olued, are very conuenieÌt, vÅ¿ing them neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e with diÅ¿cretion, leauing out all manner of ingredients which might cauÅ¿e a fluxe of the belly, Lib. 5. Aph. 34. Mulieri grauidae Å¿i aluus proÅ¿uÅ¿ior Å¿it, abortionis periculum imminet. Lib. 5. Aph. 21. for feare of Abortment, or being deliuered before their time, as Hippocrates Å¿aith.

NotwithÅ¿tanding the Å¿ame Hippocrates is of opinion, that women with child in caÅ¿es of neceÅ¿Å¿itie
may be purged from the fourth to the Å¿euenth moneth,A Woman with Child may be purged. but before and after thoÅ¿e times he admits it not, nay, he forbids it directly; which for all that the PhiÅ¿itions of our time obÅ¿erue not in caÅ¿es of danger, becauÅ¿e the Medicines we vÅ¿e in theÅ¿e dayes, as Rubarbe, Manna, CaÅ¿Å¿ia, and Tamarinds, are not Å¿o violent as thoÅ¿e that were vÅ¿ed by our Ancients, which were Hellebor, Scammony, Turbith, Coloquintida, or the like: and wee muÅ¿t take eÅ¿peciall care of giuing them any opening things which may either prouoke vrine,Opening medicines muÅ¿t be auoided. Lib. 5. Aph. 60. or their naturall courÅ¿es; for as the Å¿ame Author Å¿aith, It is impoÅ¿Å¿ible for the child to be healthfull if the mother haue her naturall Å¿icknes.

Bloud-letting is forbid them, vnleÅ¿Å¿e it be very needefull, eÅ¿pecially if the child be growne any thing big, becauÅ¿e he hath more neede of foode and nouriÅ¿hment, then at the beginning when he was little: for take away his Å¿uÅ¿tenance, and he will waxe leane and feeble, being oftentimes driuen for want thereof to Å¿eeke a paÅ¿Å¿age forth. NotwithÅ¿tanding there are Å¿ome women Å¿o Å¿anguine and full of bloud that we are forced to take Å¿ome of it away, leaÅ¿t the child be Å¿tifled with the ouer-great quantitie thereof, or when they fall into diÅ¿eaÅ¿es where it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary to open a veine.ConÅ¿iderations concerning Bloud-letting. The fitteÅ¿t time (if it be not in caÅ¿e of neceÅ¿Å¿itie) is from the fourth, to the Å¿euenth moneth. I haue Å¿eene a woman with child who for a PleuriÅ¿ie was let bloud eleuen Å¿euerall times, and yet Å¿tayed her full terme, and was well deliuered.

PaÅ¿Å¿ions of the mind.Now concerning the paÅ¿Å¿ions of the minde, a woman with child muÅ¿t be pleaÅ¿ant and merrie, Å¿hunning all melancholike and troubleÅ¿ome things that may vexe or moleÅ¿t her mind: for as Aristotle Å¿aith, A woman with child muÅ¿t haue a Å¿etled and quiet mind, which Auicen alÅ¿o counÅ¿elleth, that thoÅ¿e which haue conceiued, ought to be preÅ¿erued from all feare, Å¿adneÅ¿Å¿e, and diÅ¿quietnes of mind, without Å¿peaking or doing any thing that may offend or vexe them;An obÅ¿eruation. For great bellied women. Å¿o that diÅ¿creet women, and Å¿uch as deÅ¿ire to haue children, will not giue eare vnto lamentable and fearefull tales or Å¿toryes, nor caÅ¿t their eyes vpon pictures or perÅ¿ons which are vglie or deformed, leaÅ¿t the imagination imprint on the child the Å¿imilitude of the Å¿aid perÅ¿on or picture, which doing, women Å¿hall be Å¿ure to be well and happily deliuered, and that (With the help of God) they Å¿hall beare their burthen to the full terme, which Å¿hall be Å¿ent into the world without much paine, promiÅ¿ing them a happie and Å¿peedie deliuerie. To conclude, they muÅ¿t leaue off their Busks as Å¿oone as they perceiue themÅ¿elues with child, not lacing themÅ¿elues too Å¿traight, or cruÅ¿hing themÅ¿elues together,She muÅ¿t take need of lacing her Å¿elfe too hard. for feare leaÅ¿t the child be miÅ¿hapen and crooked, or haue not his naturall growth: and their garments muÅ¿t be rather light and thin, then heauie and cumberÅ¿ome.

div.head: How a woman muÅ¿t gouerne her Å¿elfe the nine moneths Å¿he goeth with child. CHAP. VI.
div.p: NOw I haue preÅ¿cribed what manner of life a woman ought to leade, while Å¿he is with child: Å¿he may obÅ¿erue (if it pleaÅ¿e her) this that followeth, though not Å¿o neceÅ¿Å¿ary, yet commodious and profitable both for the maintaining of her health, and preÅ¿eruation of her beauty. To the end then that her breaÅ¿ts after her deliuery, be neither too big and puÅ¿t vp,To preÅ¿erue the breaÅ¿ts. nor yet hanging downe like bags, and to preuent the danger that might happen vnto her, by the too great quantity of bloud, that is turned into milke, (which may be curdled, and Å¿o Å¿uppurate, and putrifie.) As Å¿oone therefore as Å¿he knowes her Å¿elfe to be with child, (as in the Å¿econd or third moneth) let her weare a chaine of gold about her necke. Some preferre a chaine of Å¿teele, or elÅ¿e a little gad of Å¿teele put betweene the two breaÅ¿ts, as likewiÅ¿e to put a piece of corke there, and to weare vnder her arme-pits two little pieces more of the Å¿ame. This Fomentation alÅ¿o is very good.

Take of Periwinckle, Sage, and ground-Iuy,A Fomentation. of each a handfull, Hemlocke halfe a Å¿mall handfull, boyle them in wine and water, and when you haue taken it from the fire put thereto a little roÅ¿e-vineger. And with this decoction warme, bath your
breaÅ¿ts in the morning with a cloth or Å¿pung dipt therein, a quarter of an houre, wiping and drying them afterwards with reaÅ¿onable warme clothes. The like may be done with the waters of the Å¿ame hearbs,What muÅ¿t be done, the 3. and 4. Moneth. and about the third or fourth moneth, when Å¿he feeles her Å¿elfe quicke, about which time her belly begins to Å¿well and grow big, Å¿he muÅ¿t weare a Swathe (made fit for the purpoÅ¿e) to Å¿upport her belly, being firÅ¿t annointed with this Liniment or Pomade, which Å¿he Å¿hall continue till the ninth moneth, to keepe her belly from being full of knottie and broken vaines, furrow'd and wrinckled, making it grow deformed, vnÅ¿eemely, and hanging downe lower then is fit, which hapneth by reaÅ¿on of the great burthen and weight of the child, that Å¿tretcheth and inlargeth the skinne thereof, and cauÅ¿eth them to indure great paine in their belly and groine.

The Pomade or Liniment approued. Take of Kids Å¿ewet, and the fat of a Sow, of each three ounces, of Capons and GooÅ¿e-greaÅ¿e, of each an ounce and halfe, cut them Å¿mall, and melt them in an earthen pot, putting thereto as much water as will Å¿uffiÅ¿e, then Å¿traine them through a cloth, and waÅ¿h them in water till they waxe very white, and haue loÅ¿t their Å¿auour. Afterward melt them againe in a double veÅ¿Å¿ell, adding thereto anounce of the marrow of a Hart, or Stag, then waÅ¿h it againe with RoÅ¿e-water, or other Å¿weet Å¿melling water, mingling therewithall (if you thinke fit, or that it will not be hurtfull to the wombe) two or three graines of Muske or Ciuet.

Some vÅ¿e this oyntment: Take dogs greaÅ¿e,Another Liniment- and the fat about a Å¿heepes kidney, of each two ounces, Spermaceti one ounce, oyle of Å¿weet Almonds an ounce and a halfe, the fats muÅ¿t be melted, prepared, and waÅ¿hed as before, then melted againe with the reÅ¿t, and waÅ¿hed with roÅ¿e or Å¿weet water.

Some take good Å¿tore of Sheepes-feet well bruÅ¿ed and broken in pieces, to the number of thirty or forty, and boyle them well in water, then taking off the fat, and marrow that Å¿wimmeth on the top, which they waÅ¿h well in common water, and take therof two ounces, of Ducks-greaÅ¿e as much,Another. Spermaceti one ounce, white Waxe Å¿ixe drams, melt them altogether in a double veÅ¿Å¿el, and waÅ¿h them in the aboue named waters.

Some Ladyes and Gentlewomen which loue not to rub their bellies euery morning with any of theÅ¿e liniments, weare thereon a Dog-skin, or Å¿ome other wel prepared and dreÅ¿Å¿ed, as followeth; and change it euery fifteene dayes, or according as it will laÅ¿t and continue, not taking it off, except it Å¿hriuell and grow wrinckled.

Take a Dog-skin, or Å¿ome other skin ready dreÅ¿Å¿ed to make gloues of, waÅ¿h it often in common water, afterward in RoÅ¿e-water, and dry it in the Å¿hade, and being thus dreÅ¿t and dryed, lay it in Å¿oke in theÅ¿e oyles and fats following:

Take of MeÅ¿ues oyntment of RoÅ¿es an ounce and halfe, oyle of Saint Iohns wort,The maner to prepare it. and of Å¿weet Alamonds, of each an ounce, freÅ¿h Butter, and Spermaceti, of each halfe an ounce, melt all theÅ¿e together
in a double veÅ¿Å¿el, and let the skin lie and Å¿oke in it, three or foure daies, mouing & Å¿tirring them together daily: then take it foorth, and Å¿pred, it in the aire, and let it lie there two or three daies till it haue Å¿ok't in all the oile, & become drie: then cut it to the forme & bigneÅ¿Å¿e of the belly, and Å¿o apply it.

The daintie and curious may vÅ¿e the former liniments and skin: they that haue not the meanes to do either,Another eaÅ¿ie to be prouided. let them; Take of freÅ¿h Butter well waÅ¿h't in common water, and then in RoÅ¿e-water, three ounces, oile of Å¿weet Almonds, one ounce, Spermaceti, halfe an ounce: and with theÅ¿e melted together, rub their belly.
ObÅ¿eruation.TheÅ¿e Ointments muÅ¿t be kept in a gally pot, and couered with RoÅ¿e water to keepe them from being muÅ¿tie.

Gouernment of the ninth Moneth.When the Woman is come to the ninth Moneth, hauing been in good health all the time of her going with child: Å¿he muÅ¿t continue the vÅ¿e of the aforeÅ¿aid Ointments, and muÅ¿t begin to vÅ¿e more exerciÅ¿e then Å¿he did before, walking gently before meales the firÅ¿t twelue or fifteene daies: and then afterward it will be good to vÅ¿e Å¿tronger exerciÅ¿e.

It will be very profitable for her (eÅ¿pecially after the ten or twelue firÅ¿t daies of the ninth moneth be paÅ¿t) to Å¿it in the decoction following, after the maner of a halfe Bath, Å¿ome quarter, or halfe an hower in the morning, and then being well dried, and laid to bed, let her be annointed behind, all along the lower part of her backe, and before, from
the Nauill downward; and chiefly vpon Os Pubis, and the groine, with the ointment following.

Take of Mallowes Althaea, with their roots,The Bath. Motherwort, of each two handfull, white Lilly roots, three ounces, Chamomill, and Melilot flowers, of each a good handfull, Lin-Å¿eed, Quince-Å¿eed, and Foenigreeke, of each an ounce: Boyle them all in Å¿ufficient quantitie of running water, for the Bath.

Take of Hensfat, three ounces, Duckes fat,The Ointment. an ounce and a halfe, freÅ¿h Butter, two ounces, LinÅ¿eed oile, an ounce and a halfe: Melt them all together, then waÅ¿h them verie well in Parietarie, and Mugwort water, adding thereto two ounces of the Muccilage of Althaea Roots. In which Å¿pace, let her take this drinke euery morning faÅ¿ting.A Drinke. Take of Oile of Å¿weet Almonds newly drawen without fire, an ounce, white Wine, halfe an ounce, Parietarie water, one ounce, mingle them together. Some haue found good by taking the yelke of an Egge, and drinking a draught of Hypocras after it.
Others take a little Wine and water, wherein Lin-Å¿eed hath been Å¿tieped.

Let this or the like order and gouernment be obÅ¿erued, for a Woman that is of a good habit of body, and who in her going with Child, hath not been Å¿ubiect to any Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e, or accident of moment: bearing her Children well, & without much paine.
But becauÅ¿e there be many, which are troubled with diuers accidents, which happen in their Childbearing, I thought good heere, to treat thereof briefly, before I Å¿peake of their Deliuerie.

div.head: Of many infirmities, which trouble Women while they are great with Child. CHAP. VII.
div.p:
A Woman muÅ¿t haue a care of her Beautie. IT becomes a Woman well at all times, and chiefly in her Child-bearing, and after her Deliuerie, to haue a care, as much as Å¿he can poÅ¿Å¿iblie, of the preÅ¿eruation of her Beautie: Å¿ince there is nothing that Å¿ooner decaies and Å¿poileth it, then the often bearing of Children.Health muÅ¿t be preferred. But as Health is more precious, and recommendable then Beautie: and Å¿eeing that a woman with Child may be troubled and oppreÅ¿Å¿ed with many accidents, and infirmities, during the nine Moneths Å¿he beares her child: it will be therefore verie neceÅ¿Å¿ary and profitable to Å¿eeke out the meanes to free and deliuer them thereof: For in looÅ¿ing the Mother, the life of the Child is alÅ¿o hazarded. Aristotle.
Aristotle in his booke De generatione Animalium, is of opinion, That bruit beaÅ¿tes going with young, are not Å¿ubiect to any diÅ¿eaÅ¿es: and contrariwiÅ¿e, that Women are verie often Å¿icke. Hippocrates Å¿aith, Hippocrates. That they be pale and wan, to Å¿hew that they are Å¿ubiect to many infirmities. In times paÅ¿t when men and women were Å¿old like Å¿laues, if there were any found that were with child, Å¿he was not warranted for whole and Å¿ound by him that fold her, Vitruuius. as Vitruuius writes in his Å¿econd book; becauÅ¿e they were troubled and Å¿ubiect to Å¿o many
diÅ¿eaÅ¿es. In the firÅ¿t three or foure Moneths Å¿uch infirmities chiefly happen for many cauÅ¿es. FirÅ¿t,Why women with Child are Å¿icke. becauÅ¿e they liue (as AriÅ¿totle Å¿aith) for the moÅ¿t part in idleneÅ¿Å¿e, and eate ill meates; which are turned into excrements, and breed many obÅ¿tructions, the fountaine and beginning of all diÅ¿eaÅ¿es: the Å¿econd is, the great Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ion and Å¿topping of bloud, whereof they were wont to be purged euery Moneth, before their being with Child; which runs to the Matrice to be voided, & find that accuÅ¿tomed paÅ¿Å¿age; which it had woont to haue: but being not able to get forth, and much leÅ¿Å¿e to be Å¿pent and digeÅ¿ted, by the Child (which is as yet but little) it returnes backe into the vaines, & chiefly thoÅ¿e which are neere the Å¿tomacke: and through the long continuance, is there corrupted, and changed, to be of a bad qualitie, whereof proceeds this depraued and diÅ¿ordinate appetite, which the Latins call Pica, or Malacia: Loathing of meat, Hicket, Vomiting,Diuers diÅ¿eaÅ¿es of women. Paines of the Å¿tomacke, Flanckes, and Belly, Ache of the backe, Hips, and Groine, difficultie of making water, Panting, and beating of the heart, with Sounning, the Cough, binding and Fluxe of the belly, Å¿welling of the Thighs, and Feet, and Å¿ometimes Abortment, not being able to beare their Children the full time: together with many other accidents; whereof we will Å¿peake hereafter, beginning with the Pica, which troubleth them oftneÅ¿t, and longeÅ¿t.

div.head: Of the diÅ¿ordinate longing called Pica. CHAP. VIII.
div.p: WEe commonly Å¿ay the appetite is depraued, when beyond meaÅ¿ure we couet to eate and drinke too much (in reÅ¿pect of what hunger naturally requireth:) Or when we deÅ¿ire, or long after meats, which are vnuÅ¿uall, and offend in qualitie, and are not dreÅ¿t and prepared as they ought.

Of this depraued Appetite there be diuers Å¿orts. The firÅ¿t is called Boulimos of the Greeks, Boulimos. and of the Latins, Fames vaccina, & appeteÌtia immodica. When they eate more then is requiÅ¿ite, not being able to Å¿atisfie themÅ¿elues. And if hunger vrge them farther, and grow greater, then it is called of the Latins Appetitus caninus,
Canina appetentia. or Fames inÅ¿atiabilis, and the partie eates, till he be full, euen to the throat, that he is conÅ¿trained to vomit, his Å¿tomacke being Å¿o ouercharged. But then preÅ¿ently he is driuen to eat againe, and then to vomit: from whence the Prouerbe is taken; He is returned like a Dog, to his vomit. The like hapneth for drinking, as for eating, which the Latins call Sitis immodica,
Sitis immodica. which is Å¿o great, that the tongue cleaues to the roofe of the mouth, not being able to eate or Å¿peake except the mouth be firÅ¿t moiÅ¿tned, and the tongue wetted. This accident is verie hard, yea, euen vnÅ¿upportable
to endure, the Å¿icke party taking no other delight but in drinking, and that often, and in great draughts. Men are more Å¿ubiect to this drougth then women: ContrariwiÅ¿e, Women, and chiefly thoÅ¿e with child, & Å¿uch as haue not their CourÅ¿es, or Wenches that are Å¿ubiect to the Greene Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e, are more troubled with this depraued or immoderate appetite, called Malacia, or Pica; hauing this name giuen it,From whence it is called Pica. either becauÅ¿e Pyes are troubled with this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, or elÅ¿e for that their feathers be of diuers colours, blacke and white, according to the varietie of things, which Women long after. This Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e hapneth when they deÅ¿ire to eate or drinke things, that are wholie contrarie to Nature, as eating of raw or burnt fleÅ¿h, yea, euen to long after Mans fleÅ¿h, AÅ¿hes, Coles, old Shoes, Chalke, Waxe, NutÅ¿hels, Morter, and Lime:Storie of Fernelius. as Fernelius witneÅ¿Å¿eth of a man, who being a long time deÅ¿irous to eat vnÅ¿lak't lime, at laÅ¿t deuoured thereof the bigneÅ¿Å¿e of ones fiÅ¿t; which helpt him, without doing him any harme, either in the Å¿tomacke, or guts. NotwithÅ¿tanding, not long Å¿ince, the daughter of M. Forges died, with eating the plaÅ¿tering of wals.

Sometimes cuÅ¿tome, which is a Å¿econd Nature, makes vs couet to eat Å¿uch contrarie things, as we deÅ¿ire, and the rather becauÅ¿e we haue commonly eaten thereof in our youth: There is found the contrarie hereof in Å¿ome, who abhor and loath good meates, which is imputed to the IdioÅ¿yncraÅ¿ie or particular conÅ¿titution of the perÅ¿on. Others haue
obÅ¿erued, that there are Å¿uch malignant humours Å¿ometimes bred in vs, that they are turned into poiÅ¿on, and make both theÅ¿e depraued appetites. As it is Å¿een by poiÅ¿ons taken inwardly, and applied outwardly, which make the like effect. The biting of the Å¿erpent Dipsas doth teÅ¿tifie the Å¿ame, which breedeth an intollerable and vnquenchable thirÅ¿t in him that hath been wounded by it.
Now therefore, leauing all theÅ¿e kinds of vitiated and depraued Appetites, we will onely Å¿peake of that wherewith great-bellied Women are troubled, which is called Pica.

Diuers cauÅ¿es of Pica.Some impute the cauÅ¿e of this Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e to certaine Crudities, and ill humours, which are contained in the whole habite of the bodie, and imparted to the mouth, or orifice of the Å¿tomacke. But the Å¿oundeÅ¿t opinion is, that the Å¿ides and tunicles of the Å¿tomacke, and orifice thereof, are infected, and Å¿tuffed with diuers excrements, and ill humours; and according to the qualitie they haue, the Woman with child,Wherefore they deÅ¿ire diuers things. longeth after the like: As if Melancholie abound, not burn't or aduÅ¿t; Å¿he longeth after Å¿harpe things, as Vineger, Citrons, and Orenges: if the Melancholie be aduÅ¿t, Å¿hee deÅ¿ireth Coles, AÅ¿hes, and PlaÅ¿tering: if the humour be Å¿alt, Å¿he coueteth Å¿alt meates, and Å¿o of the reÅ¿t. And Å¿urely it often happens, that they long for the like things as are in their Å¿tomackes. This maligne and bad humour, is ingendred (as we haue Å¿aid) through the retention of the naturall CourÅ¿es in women with Child, which flow backe into the Å¿tomacke.
In Å¿ome it beginneth the firÅ¿t weeks, yea,The beginning of the Pica. the verie firÅ¿t day; in others the thirtieth or fortieth day, and continues euen till the fourth moneth, and then ceaÅ¿eth: which commeth Å¿o to paÅ¿Å¿e, becauÅ¿e the Child is growen bigger, and hauing need of more NouriÅ¿hment, draw's to him a greater quantitie of bloud; the which he conÅ¿umes: and Å¿o by conÅ¿equent, it returnes backe no more into the Å¿tomacke. BeÅ¿ides alÅ¿o, this humour hath been much Å¿pent and voided, by the often vomitings which Women haue during the firÅ¿t moneths. And alÅ¿o becauÅ¿e the Childs haire is bred, and grown great,The breeding of the haire cauÅ¿eth the Pica. which Å¿ome hold to be partly a cauÅ¿e of this Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e. Plinie writes, That women with Child, feel themÅ¿elues worÅ¿e, when their Childs haire begins to come, and chiefly about the new of the Moone.

Now that we may preÅ¿erue them from this infirmitie, or at leaÅ¿t diminiÅ¿h it as much as may bee: Å¿he muÅ¿t chiefely vÅ¿e meats that breed good iuice;Their diet in Pica. and that in little quantitie, increaÅ¿ing it neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e as her bigneÅ¿Å¿e augmenteth, and the childe groweth: which at length waxing Å¿tronger and greater, will conÅ¿ume part of this great quantitie of bloud, and the reÅ¿t may bee put into the membranes which wrap and infold the childe, and to the maÅ¿Å¿e of bloud which is called the after-burthen, which is as it were the liuer of the Matrice.

Now concerning their meat and drinke: ConÅ¿idering that they that are Å¿icke of this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, and Å¿o infinitely diÅ¿taÅ¿ted, that often times they doe euen loath and abhorre good meats: therefore wee muÅ¿t
Å¿et an edge (as it were) on their appetite,Meats fit for thoÅ¿e that haue the Pica. varying their meats in as many faÅ¿hions as may be poÅ¿Å¿ible, thereby to make them the more pleaÅ¿ing and deÅ¿ireable.
Oliues and Capers, as likewiÅ¿e Å¿allades a little parboiled, are very good for them.
All meats that are either too fat, or too Å¿weet, bee naught, becauÅ¿e they Å¿tirre vp a deÅ¿ire of vomiting.
For their Å¿auces: they may vÅ¿e Veriuice, Orringes, Citrons, Pomegranats, and good RoÅ¿e viniger, all very moderately taken.

Auicen.
Auicen commendeth toÅ¿ted cheeÅ¿e, and Amylum dried: Aetius. which Aetius and OribaÅ¿ius doe allow, and eÅ¿pecially to thoÅ¿e that deÅ¿ire to eat earth, OribaÅ¿ius. and plaÅ¿tering of walles, Aegineta. or the like. Paulus Aegineta allowes them the vÅ¿e of muÅ¿tard, pepper, and cloues to make Å¿auce thereof, for the Å¿tirring vp of their appetite, and to helpe to digeÅ¿t the crudities contained within the Å¿tomacke: after meales Å¿he may eat bak't quinces, and roÅ¿ted filberds. For her drinke, Å¿he muÅ¿t vÅ¿e good clarret wine, well allaied: but if Å¿hee long for white, you may giue her leaue to drinke Å¿ome, Å¿o that it haue a little aÅ¿triction.

Much drinking is naught in the Pica.True it is, that the ouer great quantitie of drinke is hurtfull for her, by reaÅ¿on of the great waÅ¿hing which it might make in her Å¿tomacke: Å¿hee may take euery morning a draught of Wormewoodwine, or a little Å¿trong Hydromel, with a toÅ¿t of bread. The vÅ¿e of theÅ¿e Lozenges is much commended.

div.p: The Ancients, as Paulus and OribaÅ¿ius, exceedingly commend the decoction of Polypody, and Annis-Å¿eed, with Å¿uger of RoÅ¿es. They may vÅ¿e gentle fomentations to their Å¿tomackes, made of Wormewood, BalauÅ¿tia, Cumin, CytiÅ¿us, and Fennill-Å¿eed wherewith likewiÅ¿e may be made CataplaÅ¿mes for the Å¿ame vÅ¿e. div.p: They may vÅ¿e Galens Cerote for the Å¿tomacke, or that of Aecius, made with Quinces, Saffron, and a little oile of Spicknard.

Concerning generall purgations, which may euacuate downeward part of this Å¿uperfluitie, they muÅ¿t not be adminiÅ¿tred when a woman is yoong with childe,DiÅ¿cretion in purging. but with very great care, and good aduice, not vÅ¿ing any Å¿trong purgers. But if there bee need, and that the diÅ¿eaÅ¿e ceaÅ¿eth not by light medicines, then may be giuen a little infuÅ¿ion of Rubarbe, and a gentle decoction of Sene, taking the aduice of the learned PhyÅ¿itian. And therefore we muÅ¿t onely haue a regard to their vomiting, which at theÅ¿e times doth commonly moleÅ¿t and trouble them: taking heed of Å¿taying it, except it be immoderate (as Auicen Å¿aith) or too violent. Auicens precept. For otherwaies it helpeth to cure this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, euacuating part of thoÅ¿e ill humours whereby it is nouriÅ¿hed and increaÅ¿ed. And if wee perceiue Å¿he hath a deÅ¿ire to vomit, and that the expulÅ¿iue facultie be not Å¿trong enough to helpe it, let her take a little Hydromell warme; and if the matter in the Å¿tomacke be tough and clammie, adde thereto a little vineger, the better to attenuate, and cut it. I haue beene the longer in this Chapter, becauÅ¿e it is an accident that doth much annoy women with childe: thereby the better to inÅ¿truct the yoong Chirurgion, when there is no PhyÅ¿itian neere at hand.

div.head: Of DiÅ¿taÅ¿tfulneÅ¿Å¿e and Hicket. CHAP. IX.
div.p: MOÅ¿t women, as Å¿oone as they are with childe, be Å¿o diÅ¿taÅ¿ted, and doe Å¿o loath and abhorre meat, that they cannot endure either to eat, Å¿ee, or Å¿mell it, yea, and Å¿ome are Å¿icke euen with the very hearing of it named: which makes them goe often times two or three daies without any deÅ¿ire to eat. This diÅ¿eaÅ¿e hapneth vpon the Å¿ame reaÅ¿on we gaue before of the depraued appetite,The CauÅ¿e. becauÅ¿e the Å¿tomacke is filled and Å¿tuffed with diuers excrements (that oloy a great bellied woman) which by little and little are there gathered together, by the flowing backe of the courÅ¿es that be Å¿topped (which cannot bee put forth, much leÅ¿Å¿e conÅ¿umed by the little one) and Å¿o come into the Å¿tomacke, and fill it.

But when theÅ¿e corrupted,The Hicket. and ill humours abide longer in the Å¿tomacke, there happens another accident, commonly called the Hicket, or Yeaxing, which is a violent and conuulÅ¿iue motion of the Å¿tomacke, which Å¿eemeth to diÅ¿charge it Å¿elfe of thoÅ¿e bad humours, which are contained in the capacity and membranes thereof: and offend either in quantitie, or qualitie, or both together.DiÅ¿commoditie of the Hicket. From hence comes it that the Å¿tomacke willing to put them forth, caÅ¿ts vp with all the meat and food, the woman hath taken: to the preiudice of her Å¿elfe,
which cannot keepe any thing for her owne Å¿uÅ¿tenance) and of the Child, who cannot find Å¿ufficient bloud to nouriÅ¿h him: which at length makes them both weake, and cauÅ¿eth the Mother either to be deliuered before her time; or elÅ¿e to breed a faint and feeble Child, and oftentimes one that will be Å¿ickly all his life time.

Cure.For the remedying of this queaÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e, we muÅ¿t haue recourÅ¿e to thoÅ¿e medicines, written in the Chapter of depraued Appetite; Both for the dyet and remedies. And touching the Hicket, when it comes through emptineÅ¿Å¿e, or want of eating; then the woman muÅ¿t nouriÅ¿h her Å¿elfe, taking often good meat, and in Å¿mall quantitie, as yelkes of egs, cullis, veale, broth, hennes, and chicken: and let her belly be annointed with oyle of Å¿weet Almonds, and Violets. If the cauÅ¿e proceed of any Å¿harp or biting humour, it muÅ¿t be drawen and purged downward gently, as we haue Å¿aid already: or elÅ¿e by vomit,Straining bad for women with child. without much Å¿training Cow milke, and the milke of an AÅ¿Å¿e are verie much commended; as alÅ¿o the vÅ¿e of Å¿yrups of Violets, and Nenuphar are verie profitable.

The Hicket may alÅ¿o come of Å¿ome inflamation, that is in the Spleene, Liuer, or other bowels neere the Å¿tomacke, and Å¿o is impart to it: this hapning, it will be verie neceÅ¿Å¿arie to let her bloud: and that Å¿he vÅ¿e meats which moderately coole, as alÅ¿o medicines of the Å¿ame nature both inwardly and outwardly: conÅ¿ulting thereof with the PhyÅ¿itions.

div.head: Of the Vomiting which happens to Women with Child. CHAP. X.
div.p: THere be Å¿ome women, who as Å¿oone as they be with child, yea, the verie firÅ¿t daies, are Å¿ubiect to Vomit:Women with child Vomit often. caÅ¿ting vp Å¿tore of water and Å¿lime by the mouth: and this vomiting continueth euen till they are quicke with child: and with Å¿ome it remaineth all the time of their going: which I Å¿aw happen vnto a great Lady of this kingdome; who from the Å¿econd day after Å¿he had conceiued, vomited; and affirmed conÅ¿tantly that Å¿he was with child.

When this Vomiting hapneth,Vomiting muÅ¿t not be Å¿topt on the Å¿uddaine. it muÅ¿t not be Å¿taied Å¿odainly, if Å¿o be it continue gently, and without violence: for being Å¿topped, there is Å¿uch Å¿tore of humors heaped and gathered together in their Å¿tomacks, that they are ready to be Å¿tifled, or Å¿tuft vp; which being by little and little caÅ¿t vp without violence, they are much eaÅ¿ed: for by this euacuation of noyÅ¿ome excrements, the firÅ¿t region of the belly feels it Å¿elfe free, diÅ¿charged, and vnburthen'd of many long and grieuous paines.CauÅ¿e. The cauÅ¿e of this accident proceeds commonly of the abundance of humours gathered together in the Å¿tomacke: or elÅ¿e of Å¿ome Å¿harpe, and biting humour, that doth Å¿tir and prouoke it, and chiefly the vpper orifice thereof: aÅ¿well, by reaÅ¿on of the ill meats they eate, and that in great quantitie, as alÅ¿o becauÅ¿e they fill themÅ¿elues too much with good meat, which doth putrifie and corrupt, (the naturall
heat being weake) and requires rather to be caÅ¿t forth,Accidents of Vomiting. then kept in the bodie. But it hapneth oftentimes, that this Vomiting is Å¿o violent, that euen the meat and Å¿uÅ¿tenance which the Mother taketh, to nouriÅ¿h her Å¿elfe and the child is caÅ¿t vp, and then it muÅ¿t be remedied.

LikewiÅ¿e, if this accident come from Å¿ome weakneÅ¿Å¿e of the Å¿tomack, or by the default of the retentiue facultie, which is not able to retaine and kepe the meat, although it were of good iuice, and in finall quantitie: or by Å¿ome maligne vapour, which ariÅ¿eth from the wombe, by reaÅ¿on of the feed and naturall courÅ¿es retained; they maybe help'd by theÅ¿e meanes following.

FirÅ¿t, if the great quantitie of meates whether good or bad, which the woman hath taken, be the cauÅ¿e: then let her abÅ¿taine from eating them: obÅ¿eruing the aboue mentioned Dyet, vÅ¿ing good meats, and in little quantitie; thereby to roule it forth. If the ouermuch quantitie, or ill qualitie of Å¿harpe and biting excrements, be the cauÅ¿e, then muÅ¿t they be gently taken away and purged: NotwithÅ¿tanding, we muÅ¿t refraine from giuing them any purgations with Diagredium, or Coloquint: and alÅ¿o from Å¿uch as do much Å¿often and moiÅ¿ten, as CaÅ¿sia, Electuar. Lenitiuum, and the like: becauÅ¿e through their moiÅ¿ture, they relaxe the Å¿tomacke, and Å¿o conÅ¿equently, all the meanes, which haue correÅ¿pondence and traficke with the Matrice: for the Å¿imilitude of their neruous Å¿ubÅ¿tance.

Their purges therefore muÅ¿t be of Rubart infuÅ¿ion, and alÅ¿o in Å¿ubÅ¿tance, of the compound Å¿yrup of Cichory with Rubarbe; which beÅ¿ides that they euacuate, doe likewiÅ¿e coroborate and Å¿trengthen: as alÅ¿o of the Syrup of Damaske RoÅ¿es, Ma â¢ na, and other which with drawing away the water, doe dry withall. But aboue all pills are very fit for them, becauÅ¿e they dry; both for their forme, and alÅ¿o for the drying ingredients whereof they are compounded: as thoÅ¿e of Rubarb and Sene, made with a little conÅ¿erue of roÅ¿es,A good precept. adding thereto (if there be any Å¿uÅ¿pition of Å¿ome maligne or bad quality) a little of the confection of Hyacinthvs. This rule muÅ¿t be obÅ¿erued in the purging of women with child, and hereof muÅ¿t be had the counÅ¿el of the learned PhiÅ¿itian.
If Å¿ome maligne vapour be the cauÅ¿e; they muÅ¿t vÅ¿e cordials, as, a little confection of Hyacinthe, the electuary of Gemmis, theÅ¿e cordiall Lozenges, or the like.

div.p:
