div.head: CHAP. XV. of CoÅ¿tiuenes, wherwith women with child are troubled.
div.p: AMongÅ¿t many other accidents wherewith women with child are troubled, there are two, the one contrary to the other whereunto they be much Å¿ubiect: that is, either they are bound, and cannot go to the Å¿toole but with much inconuenience, and very Å¿eldome: or elÅ¿e they are alwaies looÅ¿e and Å¿ubiect to the fluxe.Contrary accidents in women with child. Both may put the woman in danger of miÅ¿carrying. For when Å¿he is bound, with much Å¿trayning, and that violently to vnburthen nature, the ligaments may bee looÅ¿ened, or Å¿ome veine opened: and cauÅ¿e fluxe of bloud: which may make her fall into trauaile, and therefore it is fit to prouide for it.

CauÅ¿e of CoÅ¿tiueneÅ¿Å¿e.The retention of the excrements, and coÅ¿tiuenes of the belly, may happen, either becauÅ¿e they haue vÅ¿ed to be Å¿o naturally, or by alteration, and change of yeares, for as Hippocrates Å¿aith, they who haue their belly moiÅ¿t in their youth, in their age will haue it hard and drie, and Å¿o contrariwiÅ¿e. This accident happens to others, becauÅ¿e the guts are not prouoked & Å¿tirred vp by the cliÅ¿ter of nature (which
is the gall,) that they may expell, and thruÅ¿t foorth their excrements. There might bee alledged many more reaÅ¿ons, which at this time I will leaue to Å¿peake of, and onely frame my Å¿elfe to that which moÅ¿t commonly is the cauÅ¿e of it in women with child, which is referred to two points,Other cauÅ¿es of CoÅ¿tiuenes either becauÅ¿e the guts are preÅ¿Å¿ed by the vneuennes of the wombe, which is too full, and beeing placed vpon them (and chiefly vpon the great gut) cruÅ¿hes and thruÅ¿ts them one againÅ¿t another, in Å¿uch Å¿ort, that they haue no meanes to inlarge and dilate themÅ¿elues, thereby to uoid the excrements contained within them. The other is becauÅ¿e the guts, and the excrements within them, are commonly very hard, and dried in women with child, through the great heate, that is in the intrailes, which makes them that they cannot eaÅ¿ily flow. The Å¿edentary life alÅ¿o, that women leade, is cauÅ¿e that their excrements are Å¿tayed, and gather themÅ¿elues together, by little and little, and at the length Å¿toppe vp the paÅ¿Å¿age. This accident brings vnto them, fluÅ¿hing in the face, headach, beating of the Arteries; yea and oftentimes an Ague.

For the curing of this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e a good order in dyet is verie needfull:Cure. vÅ¿ing meates that doe moiÅ¿ten, and keepe the guts Å¿upple, and Å¿lipperie, and withall Å¿often the excrements: which muÅ¿t bee done with very great diÅ¿cretion: for too much moyÅ¿ture may at length ouer much relaxe the ligaments of the the wombe, and of the child, and thereby haÅ¿ten the deliuery.

NotwitÅ¿tanding, a woman with child being too coÅ¿tiue, may vÅ¿e tender meats, as Veale, wherewith they may make Brothes,Brothes to looÅ¿en the belly. with Lettuce, Purcelane, Sorrell, Spinach, Beets, BugloÅ¿Å¿e, Violet leaues, and Å¿ometime a little of the herbe called Mercurie. Let them vÅ¿e Prunes, and bak't Apples. Some take two or three gulps of freÅ¿h water before their meales: but let them vÅ¿e gentle exerciÅ¿e to make their excrement follow the more freely. It is alÅ¿o verie fit for a woman with child, in the morning when Å¿he riÅ¿eth, and at night when Å¿he goeth to bed, to make proffer to vnburthen nature, without Å¿training her Å¿elfe, but verie gently. If for all this her belly will not be correÅ¿pondent; it will not be amiÅ¿Å¿e to giue her ClyÅ¿ters.

Women with great bellies are commonly Å¿ubiect thereto, becauÅ¿e of the meats they eat,Women with child are Å¿ubiect to looÅ¿eneÅ¿Å¿e of the belly. which are of ill iuice: whereby the Å¿tomacke being weakned,
and not able to concoct them, the expulÅ¿iue faculty is compel'd to thruÅ¿t them downward, halfe concocted, and indigeÅ¿ted: otherwiÅ¿e they are corrupted, and turned into Å¿ome maligne, Å¿harpe, and biting humours: as into fretting, choller rotten flegme, or melancholie, which doe corrode and Å¿tir vp the bowels, and Å¿o cauÅ¿e the fluxe of the belly.

The Cure.Concerning the cure of it, many conÅ¿iderations muÅ¿t be had. And firÅ¿t, it will be verie fit to know of what kind, the fluxe is, and what may be cauÅ¿e thereof. Now, all Fluxes of the belly muÅ¿t needs be one of theÅ¿e three; either Diarrhaea, Lienteria, or DyÅ¿enteria, which Å¿oeuer it be of theÅ¿e, if it proceed of a maligne, and putride humour, it muÅ¿t not be Å¿uddainly Å¿topped by aÅ¿tringent medicines, leaÅ¿t it happen vnto the woman with child, as it did vnto Smyrnia, A wotrhy Å¿torie. How to proceed therein.Now to know what kind of fluxe it may be, the Å¿tooles will Å¿hew and teÅ¿tifie. div.p:

div.head: The meanes to helpe women which cannot beare their Children the full time. CHAP. XVIII.
div.p:
OFtentimes it happens to women, that they cannot beare their burthen to the time prefixed by nature, which is the ninth moneth. This accident is called either a Å¿hift, or Å¿lipping away, or elÅ¿e Abortment, or (as our women call it) a miÅ¿chance: The Å¿hift is reckoned from the firÅ¿t day the Å¿eed is retained in the wombe, till Å¿uch time as it receiueth forme and Å¿hape, in which time, if it chance to iÅ¿Å¿ue and flow
foorth, it is a Shift. The Abortment hapneth after the fortieth day, yea, euen to the end of the ninth moneth. For the Abortment is a violent expulÅ¿ion, or excluÅ¿ion of the child already formed and endued with life, before the appointed time. But the Å¿liding away, or Å¿hift, is a flowing or iÅ¿Å¿uing of the Å¿eed, out of the wombe, which is not yet, either form'd, or endued with life.
ThoÅ¿e that haue been deliuered once before their time, for the moÅ¿t part they miÅ¿carie with the reÅ¿t of their children, about the Å¿ame time.

CauÅ¿es of Abortment.This accident may happen vpon diuers occaÅ¿ions, the which are either inward, or outward. The outward are, either an Ague, fluxe of bloud, or of the belly, vomiting, or any other Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e that may happen vnto a woman with child; as alÅ¿o leaping, daunÅ¿ing, riding in a Coach, too much Å¿tretching of her Å¿elfe, and the lifting, or carrying of any heauie burthen: the immoderate vÅ¿e of Venus, PaÅ¿sions of the mind, as choller, Å¿adneÅ¿Å¿e, longing after any thing; or the vÅ¿e of violent and Å¿trong medicines.

The inward cauÅ¿es are gathered from one of theÅ¿e three: either from the Mother, or things belonging to her,CauÅ¿es from the child. or from the child. ThoÅ¿e that are taken from the child, are, when he is either Å¿o weak and Å¿ickly, that he cannot be kept in the wombe, being not able to draw Å¿ufficient nouriÅ¿hment, and thereby doth decay and die: or elÅ¿e by being too big and large; Å¿o that the wombe is not capable to lodge and Å¿upport him: which maketh the veÅ¿Å¿els
of the wombe to bee relaxed and breake: then the entrance of the womb dilates it Å¿elfe, and the child commeth forth.

From the mother: when Å¿hee is eyther too Å¿mall,CauÅ¿es from the mother. or low of Å¿tature, which cauÅ¿eth that the child cannot grow in Å¿o little roome neither moue himÅ¿elfe or breath (although he breath onely by the arteries of the mother) her breaÅ¿t beeing Å¿o Å¿traight that it cannot be Å¿tretched or inlarged: or elÅ¿e becauÅ¿e Å¿he is too fat, which maketh the caule to preÅ¿Å¿e downe, and cruÅ¿h the Matrice, and cauÅ¿eth the Å¿eed to flow and iÅ¿Å¿ue forth before it be formed.Leannes cauÅ¿eth Abortment. A woman alÅ¿o that is too leane, and doth eate but little, Å¿eldome or neuer beares her child the full time. For if the mother be not well nouriÅ¿hed, much leÅ¿Å¿e can the child. Too much eating Å¿tifles the child: as likewiÅ¿e the vÅ¿e of vnholeÅ¿ome meates doth engender ill bloud in the mother: wherewith the childe beeing nouriÅ¿ht, in the ende languiÅ¿heth, whence followeth death. Another cauÅ¿e may bee the ouermuch fulneÅ¿Å¿e, and moiÅ¿tnes wherewith women abound,FulneÅ¿Å¿e is cauÅ¿e of Abortment. and chiefly in their womb, which oftentimes is ful, and ouerflowes with moÅ¿ture, and filleth the veÅ¿Å¿els of the wombe full of Å¿lime, whereby the inner orifice is inlarged, and dilated, vnable to Å¿upport, or keepe in the child. There may likewiÅ¿e bee ingendred Å¿ome Å¿harpe, and biting humors; wherwith the Matrice beeing Å¿tirred, or prouoked, while it endeuours to expell them, may thruÅ¿t out the child alÅ¿o.

This accident may alÅ¿o happen to thoÅ¿e that in
their child bearing are Å¿ubiect to haue their naturall courÅ¿es,They which haue their naturall courÅ¿es do often miÅ¿carry. as if they were not with child: which commeth to paÅ¿Å¿e, when nature Å¿triuing to put them forth, doth cauÅ¿e the child to be vntyed, and Å¿o he followeth the Purgings.

Things annexed to the mother which doe cauÅ¿e abortment.Concerning thoÅ¿e things which are annexed or belonging to the mother, I vnderÅ¿tand them to bee Å¿uch as may bee growne or contained within the womb, as Å¿ome impoÅ¿tume, Scyrrhus, or excreÅ¿ceÌce of fleÅ¿h, mole or falÅ¿e conception, therin contained, as alÅ¿o great Å¿tore of water, the which I Å¿aw, not long Å¿ince happen vnto an honeÅ¿t Gentlewoman, whoÅ¿e womb was Å¿o full of water in the eight moneth that the Orifice thereof was conÅ¿trained to open it Å¿elfe, and let them foorth, the which was in Å¿uch quantity, that it is incredible to bee reported, and Å¿ome Å¿ixe daies after, Å¿hee was deliuered, the wombe not being cloÅ¿ed againe.
As this accident is very dangerous, both for the mother and the child; Å¿o will it bee needfull to preuent, and remedy it with all Å¿peed poÅ¿Å¿ible.

Signes of abortment.FirÅ¿t we may know, that a woman is in danger to abort, or miÅ¿carry, when the milk in her breÅ¿ts doth flow and run forth in great quantity, her breÅ¿ts remaining limber and Å¿oft: and if Å¿he be with child of two children, and one breÅ¿t grow empty, it is Å¿igne Å¿he wil miÅ¿cary with one of them. For this Å¿heweth that the child doth loath & refuÅ¿e his nouriÅ¿hment: chiefly if the nipple haue gotten any ill colour, it is a Å¿igne that the Matrice is diÅ¿tempered according to Hyppocrates.

LikewiÅ¿e great paine of the backe, and thighs, which coms round to the groin, and bottome of the belly, doth oftentimes preÅ¿age the like. As alÅ¿o when there floweth out of the conduit of nature, firÅ¿t certain waters, then bloudy and Å¿limy matter, and laÅ¿t of all bloud.

To the end that it may be Å¿afely remedied,Cure of Abortment. there muÅ¿t reÅ¿pect be had to the cauÅ¿e: Now concerning the outward cauÅ¿es, as if the mother bee troubled with any Å¿icknes Å¿he muÅ¿t be handled as it is requiÅ¿ite and fit: Å¿hee muÅ¿t Å¿hunne all violent exerciÅ¿es, paÅ¿Å¿ions of the mind, and the too often vÅ¿e of Venus. And when it doth proceed from the fulneÅ¿Å¿e and aboundance of humors, & water: as it happeneth in full bodied young women, or which before their being with child were Å¿ubiect to Å¿ome euacuations (as bleeding at the noÅ¿e, Hemorrodes, or abundance of ordinary purgations, and whites) then will it alÅ¿o be very needful to purge, and let them bloud and before their beeing with child, to make them vÅ¿e the dyet:When the diet is neceÅ¿Å¿ary and eÅ¿pecially thoÅ¿e, that haue the ligaments of the womb looÅ¿e and Å¿oft, and the veÅ¿Å¿els full of thicke and Å¿limy matter: to whome likewiÅ¿e may be adminiÅ¿tred cleanÅ¿ing, & Å¿trengthening iniections, drying perfumes, Baths with Å¿ulphur, and emplaÅ¿ters for their backes, which Å¿hall heereafter be Å¿et downe.

Bloudletting fit for them that abort.And when they Å¿hall be gone about foure moneths and a halfe, it will be very fit to purge them gently, & let them bloud, the which may be done more plentifully and boldly (not all at once, but at Å¿undry times) in thoÅ¿e who before their being with child were vÅ¿ed to more copious and frequent euacuations. For experience doth Å¿hew, that by this meanes, thoÅ¿e which were wont to be deliuered before their time, haue not onely born their children to the ordinary time, but thereby alÅ¿o haue beene brought a bed more eaÅ¿ily, and with leÅ¿Å¿e pain and trouble.Store of nouriÅ¿hment choketh the child. So that the child Å¿hall neither be in daunger to bee Å¿tifled, by drawing more food then is needfull for his nouriÅ¿hment; nor of growing too big, by turning it into his owne Å¿uÅ¿tenance, which
might bee a meanes through his exceeding greatneÅ¿Å¿e to breake and teare the ligaments that Å¿upport him, or elÅ¿e, though he Å¿tay his ful time, (being thus big) that he Å¿hould not be able to come eaÅ¿ily into the world.

They that write the HiÅ¿tory of America doe tell the like, of the women in that country, which is; That as Å¿oone as they be deliuered, (they are Å¿o kind to their husbands, which tooke the paines to beget
the child) that they preÅ¿ently riÅ¿e vp and lay their husbands in their roome;Men that lye in. who are vÅ¿ed and attended, like women in childbed. And in this manner they be viÅ¿ited of all their friends, and kinsfolk, who bring them gifts and preÅ¿ents.

div.head: The office and duty of a Midwife, for the firÅ¿t time, Å¿he muÅ¿t obÅ¿erue in the trauaile. Chap. IIII.
div.p:
THe Woman that is ready to be deliuered being thus placed and laid in her bedde, muÅ¿t haue the Midwife neere vnto her: who ought firÅ¿t to aske of her woman, whether Å¿hee hath gone her full time, and bee ready to bee deliuered; and at what time Å¿hee conceiued; then muÅ¿t Å¿hee handle her belly, and marking it well, conÅ¿ider diligently whether the vpper parts Å¿eeme as if they were empty, and fallen, and the nether parts very bigge and full: which Å¿heweth that the child is Å¿unke downe. BeÅ¿ide, Å¿hee muÅ¿t aske her, whether Å¿hee haue any paines, and in what manner they bee,Signes o â¢

where they begin, and where they end: and whether they bee little or great, and frequent: whether they begin at the backe, running downe all along the belly, without Å¿taying at the Nauell: and chiefly if they run along the groine, and end in the bottom of the belly inwardly (that is in the inner necke of the womb) then it is a Å¿igne that Å¿he begins to fall in trauaile.
And for the more aÅ¿Å¿urance, let the Midwife thruÅ¿t vp her hand, being firÅ¿t annointed, either with freÅ¿h butter, hogs greaÅ¿e, or Å¿ome other ointment, which heere after Å¿hall be Å¿et downe. And if Å¿he perceiue that both the inner, and outward orifice of the wombe, be dilated and opened, it is a Å¿igne Å¿he begins to be in trauail, eÅ¿pecially if there flow or come forth by the Å¿aid paÅ¿Å¿age, any Å¿lime, or water: the which doe foreÅ¿hew, that the birth is at hand, as Hippocrat. Å¿aith, which if they be pale, it Å¿ignifies for the moÅ¿t part, it will be a wench: and if it be reddiÅ¿h that it is a Å¿onne. Now this Å¿lime commeth by the dilatation of the inner orifice, and from the membrane, that doth wrap and infold the child, which begins to breake. And alÅ¿o by reaÅ¿on of the veÅ¿Å¿els, and tyes which are looÅ¿ened from the Å¿ides of the wombe the which may be perceiued by the waters which will Å¿well, Å¿hewing like a bubble, or rather like a bladder full of water. And when the water begins to be thus gathered, there is no doubt to be made, but that the woman is in trauail: Hippocrates doth obÅ¿erue three Å¿orts of humors, that flow in the time of their trauaile: the firÅ¿t, is Å¿limy: the Å¿econd reddiÅ¿h: the third is the water wherein the child Å¿wimmeth, and heere endeth the firÅ¿t time, which the midwife muÅ¿t oberue.

div.head: Of the Second time that the Midwife muÅ¿t obÅ¿erue. CHAP. V.
div.p: WHen the waters are in this Å¿ort gathered together, by meanes of the throwes, which come by little and little:The placing of the Midwife. then the Midwife muÅ¿t place her Å¿elfe conueniently neere vnto the woman, Å¿itting in a chaire Å¿omewhat lower then the bed: and Å¿he muÅ¿t Å¿it in Å¿uch manner, that Å¿he may eaÅ¿ily put vp her hand (being firÅ¿t annointed) into thoÅ¿e parts, when need requires. And by this meanes, Å¿he may know,The mean â¢ to know h â¢â¢ the child commeth. whether the child come naturally, or no, for in feeling gently croÅ¿Å¿e the membrane, that containes the waters, Å¿he Å¿hall find, either the roundneÅ¿Å¿e of the childs head, or elÅ¿e Å¿ome vneuenneÅ¿Å¿e. If in feeling, Å¿he perceiue that there is any hard and equall roundneÅ¿Å¿e; it is moÅ¿t likely to be the childs headâª and that he comes naturally: but if Å¿he feele any vneuenneÅ¿Å¿e, the contrarie may be imagined.

When Å¿he perceiueth, that all comes well, and according to nature, the throwes increaÅ¿ing vpon the woman, and that the child doth Å¿triue and endeuour to come forth, and the wombe doth Å¿traine it Å¿elfe to be freed of this burthen; Then the Midwife muÅ¿t incourage the woman, entreating her to hold in her breath, by Å¿topping her mouth, and to Å¿traine downward, as though Å¿he would go to the Å¿toole: AÅ¿Å¿uring her, that Å¿he Å¿hall be quickly eaÅ¿ed
of her paine: and that her child is euen ready to come into the world, exhorting her to be patient, and promiÅ¿ing, that Å¿he Å¿hall haue, either a goodly Å¿onne, or a faire daughter, according as Å¿he knoweth her affection inclined.

And the Midwiues greateÅ¿t charge muÅ¿t be, that Å¿he doe nothing haÅ¿tily, or raÅ¿hly, or by force, to inlarge the paÅ¿Å¿age of the child: and much leÅ¿Å¿e, to let foorth the water, or to breake, and teare the membranes, that containe it: but Å¿he muÅ¿t expect till it breake of it Å¿elfe.

The water muÅ¿t not be let foorth.Some Midwiues either through ignorance, or impatience, or elÅ¿e by being haÅ¿tned to go to Å¿ome other womans labour, do teare the membranes with their nayles, and let foorth the water, to the great hurt and danger, both of the poore woman, and her child: who remaines drie, the water being iÅ¿Å¿ued, and voided before the appointed time; yea, oftentimes before the child be well turned, which hath been the death of many women, and children. But when the water, both by the indeuour of the Mother, and likewiÅ¿e of the child, Å¿hall be newly broken; then aÅ¿well the Midwife, as the reÅ¿t of the women preÅ¿ent, muÅ¿t more and more incourage the woman, eÅ¿pecially when her throwes increaÅ¿e; beÅ¿eeching her in the name of God, that Å¿he would farther them, as much as Å¿he can poÅ¿Å¿ibly. In the meane time, the Midwife muÅ¿t continually annoint the neather parts with butter, or Å¿ome other fats. And when the head doth offer it Å¿elfe to come foorth, Å¿he muÅ¿t receiue it gently
with both her hands: which being come Å¿oorth, and the womans throwes increaÅ¿ing, Å¿he muÅ¿t draw out the Å¿houlders handÅ¿omely, Å¿liding downe her finger vnder the childs arme-pits; taking the oportunitie and time when her throwes come faÅ¿teÅ¿t. And it is to be noted, that the throwes ceaÅ¿e verie little, or not at all, after the head and Å¿houlders be once come forth: NeuertheleÅ¿Å¿e, it will be very fit, to giue the poore woman a little breathing, intreating her, that Å¿he would be of as good cheare as Å¿he can. After this, the Midwife hauing drawen out the Å¿houlders, may eaÅ¿ily draw forth the reÅ¿t of the body: which muÅ¿t not be done either haÅ¿tily or raÅ¿hly.

But becauÅ¿e the child naturally doth come into the world, with the face downward: therefore when he is quite taken foorth, he muÅ¿t be turned vpon his backe: for feare leÅ¿t hee be Å¿tifled, or chok't.The Nauell Å¿tring muÅ¿t be vndone. And if his nauell-Å¿tring be woond about his necke, (as many times it happens) then muÅ¿t it be vnwoond. Oftentimes likewiÅ¿e, the child is Å¿o feeble, and faint, that there can Å¿carÅ¿ely be perceiued any breath, or life in him: and therefore he muÅ¿t haue a little wine Å¿pirted into his mouth, noÅ¿e, and eares, in that quantitie as Å¿hall be needfull. When he is come to himÅ¿elfe, and begins to crie, then the Midwife muÅ¿t follow the Å¿tring, wagging and Å¿haking it, thereby to draw, and bring foorth gently the after-birth, to which it is tyed:Meanes to draw forth the after-burthen. bidding the woman to cough, and likewiÅ¿e to hold Å¿ome Å¿alt in her hands, faÅ¿t Å¿hut together, and then blow in them.

In the meane time the Midwife, or Å¿ome other woman, muÅ¿t preÅ¿Å¿e gently with her hand, the top of the womans belly, Å¿troking it lightly downward: the after-burthen being come, it muÅ¿t be laid vpon the childs belly:What muÅ¿t be done to the child. and the child, together with the after-birth, muÅ¿t be wrapp'd vp handÅ¿omely in a bed, and a blanket, to be carried nearer the fire, couering the head with a linnen cloth fiue or Å¿ixe times double: and yet not expoÅ¿ing him Å¿odainly either to the fire-light, day-light, or candle-light, leÅ¿t by this Å¿odaine change his Å¿ight might be hurt: but his eies muÅ¿t be couered, that by little and little he may open them, and acquaint them with the light.
But as I Å¿aid before, the woman muÅ¿t be incouraged when the water doth iÅ¿Å¿ue foorth, and cauÅ¿ed to Å¿traine her Å¿elfe to be deliuered, that the child may follow the foreÅ¿aid water.

And they muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e obÅ¿erue diligently, whether the paines, be the paines of trauaile, or no: and whether the water be that, wherein the child Å¿wimmeth. For there be Å¿ome women that haue theÅ¿e waters iÅ¿Å¿ue out, and come away, long before they are ready to lie downe. Which I haue Å¿een happen vnto diuers women, and of late memorie to Mad. Arnault, A notable Å¿torie. who hauing gone Å¿ixe or Å¿euen moneths, and troubled with a great Colique, that had held her almoÅ¿t two moneths, and tooke her euery day at certaine howres: She being at her houÅ¿e in the Countrey, intreated me that I would come and Å¿ee her, and to haue
my aduiÅ¿e and counÅ¿ell, whether it were fit for her to come into the Citie; which I adiuÅ¿ed her to do: both becauÅ¿e of the great paines Å¿he had, as alÅ¿o for her exceeding greatneÅ¿Å¿e: being of opinion, that Å¿he might haue two children, as Å¿he had had, not aboue a yeare before. Being come to Paris, her Colique was Å¿omewhat mitigated, and a little while after Å¿he voided two or three gallons of water, without any paine, thinking verily then, that Å¿he was not with child: yet fiue daies after Å¿he was deliuered very happily, and with little paine, of a faire daughter, there following very little water, or none at all.

I Å¿aw another Ladie in whom theÅ¿e waters came away, aboue ten daies before her deliuerie, yet Å¿he kept not her bed, but followed her ordinarie buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e. And this is worth marking, that they may be carefull not to haÅ¿ten the deliuerie; except the paines be proper for trauaile, and Å¿uch as I haue already deÅ¿cribed.

div.head: The Third time that muÅ¿t be obÅ¿erued by the Midwife. CHAP. VI.
div.p:
AS Å¿oone as the child is borne, and that the Mother is deliuered of her after-birth, the Midwife Å¿hall cauÅ¿e her legs to be gently laid downe, taking away the peece of wood, that lay at her feet: and put a fine linnen cloth, or rather
a cleane Å¿punge, waÅ¿hed in warme water, and wrung out, betweene her thigh's, neare vnto her naturall parts, that the cold ayre may not get therein: and then muÅ¿t Å¿he take the child, together with the after-burthen, and carrie them to the fire, as hath been Å¿aid already.

And if it happen, that the after-burthen be long ere it come, or be drawen foorth; and that the child may not Å¿tay Å¿o long there, for danger to be Å¿tifled, and die, it being oftentimes verie weake. The midwife Å¿hall firÅ¿t tye, and then cut the childs Nauel-Å¿tring, to Å¿eperat him from the after-burthen: Which muÅ¿t be done in this manner.

How the Nauell muÅ¿t be tyed.She muÅ¿t haue in readyneÅ¿Å¿e, a good double thread, and a paire of Å¿harpe SciÅ¿Å¿ors: with the thread Å¿he muÅ¿t tye the Nauell a good inch from the childs belly with a double knot, or oftner: this knot muÅ¿t be neither too hard and Å¿traite, neither too looÅ¿e: for too Å¿traite tying, beÅ¿ide the extreame paine it cauÅ¿eth, makes that which is tyed fall off too Å¿oone, and that, before the Å¿car be growen betweene the liue and the dead part: And if it be tyed too looÅ¿e, thereof proceeds a fluxe of bloud from the vmbilicall veÅ¿Å¿els, which are not exactly cloÅ¿ed and Å¿topp't by the Å¿aid ligature: and therefore, a meane muÅ¿t be obÅ¿erued in doing it. Then being thus tyed,Where the Nauell muÅ¿t be cut. the Nauel-Å¿tring muÅ¿t be cut off an inch beneath the knot; And that the knot may not Å¿lip, nor the thred Å¿lide away, Å¿he muÅ¿t take a little fine linnen rowler dip't in oile of RoÅ¿es, wherewith Å¿he muÅ¿t wrap the reÅ¿t of the Nauell, and
with a little fine bumbaÅ¿t moiÅ¿tned in the Å¿ame oyle, Å¿he muÅ¿t lay it vpon the belly, that it be not cruÅ¿ht, when they dreÅ¿Å¿e and Å¿wath the child. By this ligature,The Nauell muÅ¿t fall of it Å¿elfe. that which is tyed will come to wither, and drie of it Å¿elfe, and Å¿ome foure or fiue daies after, more, or leÅ¿Å¿e, the dead part will fall from the quicke, which muÅ¿t not be forc'd or pluckt off in any caÅ¿e.

Some do obÅ¿erue, that the Nauell muÅ¿t be tyed longer, or Å¿horter, according to the difference of the Å¿exe, allowing more meaÅ¿ure to the males:The meaÅ¿ure in tying the Nauell. becauÅ¿e this length doth make their tongue, and priuie membres the longer: whereby they may both Å¿peake the plainer, and be more Å¿eruiceable to Ladies. And that by tying it Å¿hort, and almoÅ¿t cloÅ¿e to the belly in females, their tongue is leÅ¿Å¿e free, and their naturall part more Å¿traite: And to Å¿peake the truth,A common Å¿aying of Women. the GoÅ¿Å¿ips commonly Å¿ay merrily to the Midwife; if it be a boy, Make him good meaÅ¿ure; but if it be a wench, Tye it Å¿hort.

Hippocrates would haue them, in tying the Nauell, obÅ¿erue this that followeth.Precept of Hippocrates. If a woman (Å¿aith he) be deliuered with paine, and the child Å¿tay long in the wombe, and comes not foorth eaÅ¿ily, but with trouble: and chiefly if it be by the Chirurgians help, and inÅ¿truments: Å¿uch children are not long liued, and therefore there Nauell-Å¿tring muÅ¿t not be cut, before they haue either Å¿neez'd, piÅ¿s'd, or cried.

Anone after the Midwife hath cut the Nauell, Å¿he muÅ¿t wipe and make clean the child, not onely
his face, but his whole bodie, and the wrinkles and folds of the arme-pits, buttocks, and ioints, either with freÅ¿h Butter, or oyle of Å¿weet Almonds. Some do it with oyle of RoÅ¿es, others with oyle of Nuts, thereby to make the skin more firme, and to Å¿top the pores, that the outward ayre may not hurt him, and likewiÅ¿e to Å¿trengthen all his parts.
Auicens Method. Auicen boyleth RoÅ¿es and Sage in wine, and waÅ¿heth the child with a fine Å¿oft Spung dipt therein: and Å¿o continues it three or foure mornings when he is Å¿hifted.

The child being thus Å¿hifted and annoynted, and then well dried, and wrap't vp by the Midwife, or others:What muÅ¿t be giuen the child after he is borne. they muÅ¿t preÅ¿ently giue him a little wine and Suger in a Å¿poone, or elÅ¿e the bigneÅ¿Å¿e of a peaÅ¿e, of Mithridate, or Triacle, diÅ¿Å¿olued in a little wine, if it be Winter, and in Summer (by reaÅ¿on of the heat) with a little Carduus Benedictus, or Å¿ome other Cordiall water.

Auicen doth thinke it Å¿ufficient to giue them a little Hony: and to rub the top and bottome of the tongue with ones finger dip't in hony. And by this meanes, to Å¿ee whether they be tongue tyed, and Å¿o to cut the Å¿tring, if it be needfull.

div.head: of the Care that muÅ¿t be had of a Woman in Child bed. CHAP. VII.
div.p:
WHile the Midwife doth cut the childs Nauell, and make him cleane, the NurÅ¿e, or Å¿ome other that is preÅ¿ent, muÅ¿t haue an eÅ¿peciall Care of two things: The firÅ¿t is, To giue the woman in child-bed this drinke.
A Drinke for a woman in child-bed. Take oyle of Å¿weet Almonds newly drawen, two ounces, Syrup of Maidenhayre, one ounce, white Wine, water of Parietarie of the wall, and Carduus Benedictus, of each halfe an ounce,
Mingle them verie well together with much Å¿haking, and Å¿o let her drinke it. This medicine will mitigate and lenifie the paÅ¿Å¿age of the throat, and Trachaea Arteria, which haue been heated, and Å¿tretched with crying, and groning: And likewiÅ¿e it will help to prouoke the purgings, and hinder the pangs and gripings from being Å¿o violent.

2. The Å¿econd is, to cauÅ¿e a Å¿heep to be fleaed, and to wrap the womans backe and belly in the skin yet warme, thereby to Å¿trengthen and comfort, all thoÅ¿e parts, which haue been as it were diÅ¿iointed, and pull'd one from another, with much Å¿triuing in her trauaile. Auicen thinks it enough to lay vpon the womans belly, a Hares skin newly Å¿tript from the Hare being aliue.

Then the Midwife (if Å¿he be not buÅ¿ied about the Child) or Å¿ome other that looketh to the woman, Å¿hall applie beneath to the entrance of the naturall part, and about the bottome of her belly this medicine.

q.p: A Å¿trengthening Medicine. Take oyle of Hypericum, Saint Iohns Wart, two ounces, Oyle of RoÅ¿es, an ounce: Two whole egges, Mingle them well together and let them be applied as I Å¿hewd before with finelinnen clothes, or flaxe, likewiÅ¿e there muÅ¿t be laid vnder her hams, a little pillow doubled, to make her keepe her knees vp a little, and that her thighs & legs lie not Å¿traight down. Let her neither lye along, nor Å¿it vpright but keepe her Å¿elfe betweene both, hauing her heade and body rather a little raiÅ¿ed, then laidlow, that her purgings may the eaÅ¿ier come away.

div.p: After the skinne hath layen there two or three daies, the Midwife, or her nurÅ¿e Å¿hall take it away, and Å¿wath her belly, rubbing and anointing it firÅ¿t, with oile of Saint Iohns wort, Å¿weet Almonds, and RoÅ¿es, mingled together. For this Å¿wathing Å¿erues to keepe the Matrice in his place, and to driue downe gently her after-purgings, and alÅ¿o is a meanes to keepe out the aire, which otherwiÅ¿e might cauÅ¿e the woman to haue great paines and gripings.

The faÅ¿hion of the Å¿wath. The Å¿wath muÅ¿t bee made of linnen cloth foure times doubled, of the bredth of all ber belly; which muÅ¿t be put round about her backe & belly Å¿mooth without any pleat and wrinkle. And while they be about this, they muÅ¿t take an eÅ¿pecial care, that the
woman catch not cold, nor that the aire get not into her wombe, which being emptied of Å¿uch a burthen, will eaÅ¿ily receiue it,They muÅ¿t beware of taking cold. and this might bee a meanes to make it Å¿well, and puffe vp, and to Å¿hut the orifices of the veines, by which her purgings Å¿hould flow: the Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ion whereof doth cauÅ¿e paines, gripings, Å¿uffocation, an ague, and many other accidents.

Now when the woman Å¿hall be thus accommodated, Å¿he muÅ¿t be kept from Å¿leeping, though Å¿hee bee very deÅ¿irous thereof, and let her in the meane time be entertained with Å¿ome diÅ¿courÅ¿e, and let her nurÅ¿e looke to her breÅ¿ts, applying Å¿uch things thereunto, as Å¿hall be Å¿et downe in the third booke in their proper place.

After the woman hath beene kept three or foure houres from Å¿leeping, you may giue her Å¿ome broth made with a knuckle of Veale, or a Chicken,The woman in child bed muÅ¿t bee in quiet. or in Å¿tead thereof, a couple of yelkes of egges, and Å¿o let her take her reÅ¿t: and if Å¿he haue any deÅ¿ire to Å¿leep, Å¿hee may, which muÅ¿t bee Å¿ome three or foure houres after her deliuery, the dores and windowes of her chamber, being cloÅ¿e Å¿hut, not making any noiÅ¿e.

And Å¿o let this Å¿uffice, for the naturall trauaile or deliuery; wherein there hath beene no difficulty: the woman beeing neither much troubled, Gen. 3.15. nor hauing had any greate paines, but thoÅ¿e that are ordinary, and Å¿uch as God hath, which is, that In Å¿orrow a woman Å¿hould bring forth.

div.head: Of a painfull, and difficult deliuery with the cauÅ¿es thereof. CHAP. VIII.
div.p: WOmen are brough a bed very hardly, and with much paine, vppon diuers reaÅ¿ons, which is an occaÅ¿ion that many repaire vnto PhiÅ¿itians, and Chirurgions, to haue their helpe, Å¿ince there be few Midwiues found skilful, that can giue them much aide or Å¿uccour in theÅ¿e caÅ¿es.

CauÅ¿es of difficult deliueryA Chirurgion beeing called thither, ought diligently to inquire, what may be the cauÅ¿e, and conÅ¿ider carefully thereof: now the cauÅ¿e may be referred to foure things, either to the mother: or to the child: or to things that are annexed vnto the child: or elÅ¿e to outward things, and Å¿o accordingly muÅ¿t they frame the remedy.

CauÅ¿e from outward things.In the number of outward things I comprehend thoÅ¿e perÅ¿ons, that are about the woman in trauail, who if they be diÅ¿pleaÅ¿ing vnto her, are to be intreted gently to withdraw and abÅ¿ent themÅ¿elues. Whether it be by reaÅ¿on that the woman hath any feare, apprehenÅ¿ion, or any miÅ¿like and loathing vnwillling to haue them Å¿o neare her, when Å¿hee is in her trauaile, and anguiÅ¿h; or elÅ¿e being aÅ¿hamed to Å¿ee her Å¿elfe in that caÅ¿e.

Lib. 28. cap. 6.2 Pliny writeth that the ancients held an opinion that the deliuery might bee hindred and prooue
difficult:Opinion of Plyny. Story of Alcmena. if there were any in the womans chamber, which held her fingers lockt, or Å¿hut one within another: and produceth for an example Alcmena; who could not be deliuered of Hercules, but with much difficulty.

3 LikewiÅ¿e the outward aire being too cold, may hinder the deliuery becauÅ¿e it cooleth the woman,Coldnes or heate doth hinder the deliuery. Å¿hutting vp her body, and eÅ¿pecially thoÅ¿e parts, which ought to be inlarged, and dilated. As alÅ¿o the aire being too hot, Å¿pendeth the Å¿pirits, and makes the woman loÅ¿e her Å¿trength, remaining weake and feeble, and as it were fainting, without any power, or courage. And therefore the aire muÅ¿t be temperate, yet rather hot, then cold.

4 PleaÅ¿ing Å¿mels, (as of Muske, Ciuet,Effect of Å¿weet Å¿mels. Amber GriÅ¿e, or the like, if Å¿he haue Å¿uch about her, the vapour whereof, may Å¿trike vp into her noÅ¿e,) doe hinder the deliuery: becauÅ¿e they draw the wombe vpward.

If the cauÅ¿e of difficult deliuery be in the mother her Å¿elfe, it comes, either by reaÅ¿on of her perÅ¿on,CauÅ¿es from the Mother or her age, or her naturall diÅ¿poÅ¿ition, or of Å¿ome other accident Å¿he hath had or may haue: or by being deliuered before, or after her time.

1 Her perÅ¿on or body may be the cauÅ¿e thereof: as if Å¿hee be too fat and full: for in Å¿uch women I haue Å¿eene great Å¿tore of fat come down into their naturall parts, which Å¿topped the paÅ¿Å¿age.FatneÅ¿ â¢
âª And in others I haue Å¿eene the caule come downe, which did Å¿o preÅ¿Å¿e, and cruÅ¿h together both the inward and outward necke of the wombe, that it could very
hardly open it Å¿elfe, yea, and being dilated, and inlarged, did euen cloÅ¿e & preÅ¿Å¿e it together againe.
In Å¿ome I haue Å¿eene and felt part of the bladder preÅ¿ent it Å¿elfe at the entrance of the wombe.The Bladder.

A woman that is too leane and bare: as alÅ¿o one that is too little,LeaneneÅ¿Å¿e. may likewiÅ¿e bee deliuered with much difficulty. And when this happeneth, it cannot be remedied, as one would deÅ¿ire.

2 Now concerning their age: both they that are too yoong as being too Å¿traight: and alÅ¿o they that are old, hauing alÅ¿o their naturall parts too much Å¿hrunke together and dryed, and the bones too cloÅ¿ely ioyned together, & the cartilages very hard which cannot Å¿o well yeeld, and bee dilated, as in youth; I Å¿ay both of theÅ¿e bee deliuered with very much difficulty.
From her diÅ¿poÅ¿ition.3 Their naturall diÅ¿poÅ¿ition likewiÅ¿e may bee a cauÅ¿e that they are deliuered with much paine.

1 As if they be weake of conÅ¿titution, nice, tender, timerous, and afraid of paine: which makes them, that they will not force themÅ¿elues, nor make their paines and throws effectuall: and when the child is euen ready to come forth, they Å¿hrinke in themÅ¿elues, with the very feare they haue to feel Å¿uch paine.

2 Hippocrates Å¿aith that women, which haue an Ague when they are with child, Hippocrates. and become very leane without a manifeÅ¿t cauÅ¿e, doe bring foorth their children with great difficulty, paine, and danger: And if they doe miÅ¿carry or abort, then they are in danger of their liues. The Å¿ame Author Å¿aith,
that thoÅ¿e women which giue but little nouriÅ¿hment to their children, are Å¿ooner deliuered, Lib. de natura pueri. and contrariwiÅ¿e they that feede too much, are longer ere they be brought a bed.

3 They that haue beene troubled with any Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿es; as the bloudy fluxe or other fluxe of the belly, ConvulÅ¿ions, fluxe of bloud: or that haue any tumor, vlcer, or Å¿carre which hath happened by being heeretofore badly deliuered; or any other accident that hath made the necke of the wombe hard, cloÅ¿e and Å¿traight, which is a meanes that it cannot be dilated, and inlarged, or elÅ¿e which haue the entrance, or paÅ¿Å¿age Å¿topt with Å¿ome fleÅ¿h or membrane, that is naturall vnto them: that is to Å¿ay which they haue had from their birth: All theÅ¿e (I Å¿ay) are deliuered with great paine, and difficulty, yea and oftentimes doe loÅ¿e their liues thereby.

Now Å¿ome will thinke it very Å¿trange, and almoÅ¿t incredible, to find a woman that Å¿hould bee with child, and yet a maide,A thing worthy to bee obÅ¿erued. there being euen from her birth a membrane that Å¿toppeth the paÅ¿Å¿age, and hindreth the man from entring. Where as it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary for conception, that a woman Å¿hould haue the entire fruition or company of the man, and that he Å¿hould not onely enter within the outward paÅ¿Å¿age of the womb, but euen to the inner necke therof, to carry thether the Å¿eed, and there to mingle it with the womans. But Å¿tories in this kinde make vs beleeue the contrary; Å¿eeing there is no Å¿uch neceÅ¿Å¿ity that the mans Å¿eede Å¿hould be carried, and caÅ¿t Å¿o deepe. For in Å¿ome Women the wombe is Å¿o
greedy, and lickeriÅ¿h that it doth euen come down to meet nature, Å¿ucking, and (as it were) Å¿natching the Å¿ame, though it remaine only about the mouth and entrance of the outward orifice thereof.

A Å¿tory of Auerrhoes.
Auerrhoes tels a Å¿tory of a woman that became with child, onely by drawing in (as Å¿he bath'd her Å¿elfe) the Å¿eed of a man that was bathed in the Å¿aid Bath.

A true Å¿tory.The yeare 1607. in May, MaÅ¿ter de la Noue the Kings Chirurgion in Ordinary, and Å¿worne in the ChaÅ¿telet of Paris, was called to Å¿earch a yong Woman the wife of a Gold-Å¿mith, who had beene cited by her Husband to appeare before the Officiall of Paris: alleadging, that Å¿he was not capable nor fit by nature, to be married: which was an occaÅ¿ion that Germane HaÅ¿Å¿art a Midwife, and my Å¿elfe were Å¿ent for to Å¿earch her. Where wee found, that in the very entrance of the wombe, there was a membrane Å¿o Å¿trong, hard, and thicke, that a mans finger, (and much leÅ¿Å¿e the other part) was not able to breake it open; he hauing oftentimes made triall to doe it, whereby he had incurred a ParaphimoÅ¿is: And therefore it was concluded, that her husband had a iuÅ¿t cauÅ¿e to cite her, but yet for all this, that it was curable.

Whereupon her Husband thought good to call MaÅ¿ter de Levrye, and Pietre, Å¿worne Chirurgians at Paris: then we all there concluded with a generall conÅ¿ent, to make an inciÅ¿ion, of the Å¿aid Membrane, which was done; and dreÅ¿Å¿ed and healed, to her Husbands content: onely he was Å¿omwhat doubtfull
of that, which the Å¿aid de La Noue had obÅ¿erued, and told him, that his wiues belly was big, and that Å¿he was qualmiÅ¿h and diÅ¿taÅ¿ted, vomiting euery morning, which made him Å¿uÅ¿pect that Å¿he was with child: whereupon a Midwife tolde him that there was no likelihood, nay it was impoÅ¿Å¿ible to thinke that a yong woman of eighteene yeares of age Å¿hould be with child, her husband hauing neuer entred within her maiden cloiÅ¿ter: and that with threÅ¿hing onely at the barne doore, Å¿he could not be full. Whereupon MaÅ¿ter Pietre, was Å¿ent for, who though at firÅ¿t he could not be induced to beleeue it, yet at length, hauing well conÅ¿idered therof, gaue his iudgement, that Å¿hee was with childe, which proued true, for about Å¿ome foure Moneths after the inciÅ¿ion was made, Å¿hee was happily deliuered at her full time of a faire daughter.

Mad. Scaron Å¿ent for me, to helpe a Farmers wife,Another Å¿torie. that was great with childe, and ready to lye downe, who had had the outward orifice of her womb, for the Å¿pace of foure or fiue yeares, Å¿o perfectly cloÅ¿ed, glued and ioined together, that it was impoÅ¿Å¿ible to put a little probe therein: the which had happened vnto her, by beeing ill deliuered, by meanes whereof, the entrance of the outward necke of the wombe, had beene exulcerated, and the vlcers cicatriz'd, and the Å¿ides of the Å¿aid necke ioined together: and yet for all this Å¿he proued with child. At the time of her deliuery, by the aduiÅ¿e and councell of MaÅ¿ter Riolan, and Charles the Kings profeÅ¿Å¿ors in PhiÅ¿icke, and Regent Doctor in the faculty of PhiÅ¿icke
at Paris, Brunet, Paradis, Riollan, Fremin, Rabigois: and Serre (Queen Marguerites Chirurgion) Mitton, and Choffinet, MaiÅ¿ter Barber Chirurgions at Paris, Honore the Kings Chirurgion, and my Å¿elfe, I Å¿ay by the aduiÅ¿e of all theÅ¿e, there was an inciÅ¿ion made, then preÅ¿ently the Speculum dilatatorium was Å¿o wel applied, that al the Cicatrizes were inlarged, which Å¿ucceeded Å¿o proÅ¿perouÅ¿ly, that within three houres after, Å¿he was deliuered with much eaÅ¿e.

The deliuery that is too Å¿oone or too late, doth prooue difficult.4 The trauaile may likewiÅ¿e proue difficult, and painfull, when the woman is deliuered before or after her time; before her time, as when it comes in the Å¿ixth, Å¿euenth, or eighth Moneth: which happens when the wombe is too moiÅ¿t and weake, or elÅ¿e full, and as it were Å¿tuft with much Å¿lime, which doth Å¿o moiÅ¿ten the necke therof, that it is inlarged and dilated before the limited time. As alÅ¿o the veÅ¿Å¿els, to the orifices whereof, the after burthen is faÅ¿tned, do begin to be relaxed, which cauÅ¿eth that the child cannot be Å¿upported nor remaine in his naturall Å¿ituation. By which change, finding the inner orifice looÅ¿ened, and inlarged: and the membrane wherein the waters are contained, and in which the child Å¿wimmeth, to be very Å¿mall, and thinne: it begins to breake, which maketh the child out of order, and Å¿o cauÅ¿eth difficult deliuery. As alÅ¿o too much dryneÅ¿Å¿e,Effect of too much drines. as it were, want of nouriÅ¿hment, when the mother is not well nouriÅ¿hed, hauing not wherewith to Å¿uÅ¿taine the child, which makes the Å¿aid child, not hauing Å¿ufficient nouriÅ¿hment, to turne and winde himÅ¿elfe Å¿eeking about for it, and
caÅ¿ts it Å¿elfe downe, and vnlooÅ¿neth his bed (which is the after-burthen) from the Å¿ides of the wombe: and in the end breakes the membrane wherein the waters are contained, and Å¿triueth to come foorth, for the moÅ¿t part out of order. The like hapneth to them, that go till the tenth, or eleuenth moneth: becauÅ¿e the child through the length of time, that it Å¿tayeth in the mothers wombe, doth grow, and waxe bigger, though the parts of the mother, wherby the child (being thus big) is to come forth, and paÅ¿Å¿e through, are not increaÅ¿ed or inlarged at all; which cauÅ¿eth (the paÅ¿Å¿ages being not able to bee Å¿ufficiently dilated and widened) great anguiÅ¿h, and paine, to the mother eÅ¿pecially, Å¿hee beeing weakned in all her parts, that Å¿erue for the expulÅ¿ion, and bringing forth of the child: which among the reÅ¿t, are the Matrice, and the MuÅ¿cles of the vpper belly; which being Å¿tretched beyond meaÅ¿ure, through the greatneÅ¿Å¿e and bigneÅ¿Å¿e of the child, do inlarge the fibres, which cannot afterward be Å¿o eaÅ¿ily drawen together, hauing loÅ¿t their proper force, and Å¿trength.

And this may be manifeÅ¿tly perceiued,A good obÅ¿eruation. in thoÅ¿e that cannot make water; the bladder being too full, that although the paÅ¿Å¿age be opened by a probe, yet the Chirurgion is conÅ¿trained to preÅ¿Å¿e the belly, Å¿o to help the fibres of the bladder, to cloÅ¿e, and fould themÅ¿elues together. BeÅ¿ides, the child filling vp all the Å¿pace that is in the wombe, cannot help it Å¿elfe Å¿o well in thruÅ¿ting forward, being, as it were, fettred, and lock't faÅ¿t therein.

CauÅ¿es from the child.3. The like hindrance of deliuerie may proceed from the child, who hauing attained vnto the ninth moneth, is not able to come into the world, either through weakneÅ¿Å¿e, and feebleneÅ¿Å¿e; or becauÅ¿e he is not perfected, and ripened as he Å¿hould, and Å¿o hath not Å¿ufficient Å¿trength to diÅ¿Å¿olue the ligaments, and veÅ¿Å¿els: and to break aÅ¿under the membranes, wherein he is incloÅ¿ed: which cauÅ¿eth, that after he hath Å¿triued in the ninth moneth, and attempting it againe in the tenth,A double conflict of the child. he is not able to Å¿triue Å¿o luÅ¿tily for his comming foorth, hauing been weakned with forcing himÅ¿elfe the moneth before. And it is moÅ¿t certaine, that the childs Å¿taying, in the wombe after the ninth moneth, doth proceed onely from want of vitall heat, which is in the heart;Why the child is Å¿taid from comming foorth. or that he hath it not in Å¿ufficient quantitie to deÅ¿ire the Aire, which we draw in to coole vs: or that all the parts of his bodie, are not Å¿trong, and able enough, to draw vnto them Å¿ufficient nouriÅ¿hment.

Another cauÅ¿e of difficult deliuerie.This difficultie of deliuerie happens alÅ¿o, when the child is either Å¿icke, or dead; and is not able to help it Å¿elfe: as likewiÅ¿e, when he is too big in all his bodie, and chiefly in the head: or if he be a MonÅ¿ter, hauing two heads, two bodies, foure armes, or legs: or if they be Twins; th'one hindring the others comming foorth:Diuers Å¿ituations of the child. which will be euident by the bigneÅ¿Å¿e of the Mother: or if he be ill placed to come foorth, putting formoÅ¿t an arme, or a leg, or both; the Å¿houlder, buttockes, Å¿ide, or belly comming formoÅ¿t.

4 Now concerning that which is annexed to the child, the deliuerie proues difficult,CauÅ¿e from things annexed to the child. if the membranes, that containes the water, wheron the child doth floate, and Å¿wim, be firme, Å¿olide, and hard, that it cannot, but verie hardly be broken: or that the Å¿aid membrane be Å¿o thin, that it breakes too Å¿oone, and before the child be well turned, and ready to follow the Å¿aid water, which Å¿erues to carrie him, and make him come foorth the eaÅ¿ier: For the child that remaines drie, commeth into the world with much paine.

LikewiÅ¿e, if the after-burthen offer it Å¿elfe firÅ¿t, and that it Å¿top the paÅ¿Å¿age: or if there be a Mole, or falÅ¿e Conception; As alÅ¿o if the woman haue not been lately at Å¿toole, or made water:The retention of excrements hinders the deliuerie. the which is cauÅ¿e, that the great gut being full, may cloÅ¿e the necke of the wombe: as likewiÅ¿e the bladder being full may preÅ¿Å¿e it downe, becauÅ¿e it is placed betweene them both. Whence it is commonly Å¿aid in the prouerb; Que l'enfant eÅ¿t Å¿ituÃ© enter le boire, & le manger, which is; That the child is Å¿eated, between the meat, and the drinke. And therefore, all the aforeÅ¿aid accidents muÅ¿t be remedied accordingly.

div.head: The meanes to help Women that are deliuered with difficultie. CHAP. IX.
div.p:
THat a Woman,Direction for the Chirurgian. which is deliuered with difficultie, and much paine, may be help'd: the Chirurgian ought to know, what is the cauÅ¿e thereof, and from
whence this difficultie doth proceed: that he may the better cure it.

If it be, becauÅ¿e the Mother is to groÅ¿Å¿e, or fat, and chiefly in her naturall parts, as alÅ¿o if there be any Å¿tore of fat offer it Å¿elfe; (as I haue Å¿een it oftentimes happen in great Å¿triuing, and throwes,) yea, and that in Å¿uch Å¿ort, that it did euen Å¿top the paÅ¿Å¿age of the child; Then the Chirurgion, (as gently as he can poÅ¿Å¿ibly) muÅ¿t thruÅ¿t backe, and put aÅ¿ide with one hand, the Å¿aid fat, not tearing or hurting it,Meanes to help them that are too fat. leaÅ¿t it be Å¿poiled and corrupted afterwards; holding it Å¿till downe on the one Å¿ide, till the child be come foorth of the wombe, keeping it alwaies from falling downe into the paÅ¿Å¿age, and among the bones, when the child is readdy to come foorth.

ConÅ¿iderations for the Bladder.But when part of the bladder, is Å¿unke downe and relaxed, and is manifeÅ¿tly perceiued in the entrance of the wombe: then muÅ¿t he do the like, as he did to the fat, holding it aÅ¿ide vpward, with the flat of two or three of his fingers, vntill the childs head be paÅ¿t the Os Pubis. If he find then (as it may Å¿o come to paÅ¿Å¿e) that the Å¿aid bladder be full of vrine: the woman in trauaile not hauing made water,The woman muÅ¿t be prouoked to make water. a good while before; then muÅ¿t he cauÅ¿e her to make water, by putting a fit inÅ¿trument gently into the bladder. For it is Å¿een in Å¿ome, that the fibres,An ObÅ¿eruation. which doe contract the bladder, and make it driue out the vrine, are Å¿o weakned, and alÅ¿o the whole bodie thereof, that the vrine cannot come foorth.

Some women haue been deceiued,A thing worthy to be noted. by taking the Å¿aid bladder, thus full with vrine, for the waters which come before the child, cauÅ¿ing the Å¿aid bladder to be broken: the which is worthy of great conÅ¿ideration. AlÅ¿o the Å¿aid necke of the bladder may be Å¿top't, by reaÅ¿on of Å¿ome CarnoÅ¿itie, Inflammation, or Å¿tone,A notable Å¿torie. which I haue Å¿een an honeÅ¿t woman, there being a Å¿tone fallen down into the necke in her bladder, that Å¿topt her vrine, which being put aÅ¿ide by the probe, Å¿he made water: NeuertheleÅ¿Å¿e, when the child was ready to come foorth, the Å¿tone returning in to the Å¿aid necke of the bladder againe, did Å¿o fret and hurt it, through the long Å¿tay, that the childs head made in the paÅ¿Å¿age, that it grew to an ImpoÅ¿tume and Å¿uppuration, which made a little hole, through the which Å¿he hath long time made her water, not being able to hold or retaine it; which is a Å¿torie worthy to be mark'd. But as the vrine may be Å¿ometimes Å¿top't, Å¿o likewiÅ¿e the excrements of the great gut may be retained: which hapning, it will be more then neceÅ¿Å¿arie for the cure thereof, to giue the woman a ClyÅ¿ter, that may both vnload her, of her excrements,The excrements muÅ¿t be voided. and likewiÅ¿e help and make her deliuerie the more eaÅ¿ie.

I my Å¿elfe was preÅ¿ent at the trauaile of a poore Å¿icke woman,Another Å¿torie. that had not been at Å¿toole in ten daies before, whoÅ¿e great gut was Å¿o fild and Å¿tuft with excrements, as hard as a Å¿tone, that it was impoÅ¿Å¿ible for her to receiue a ClyÅ¿ter; and we were conÅ¿train'd, before Å¿he could be deliuered, to get
out all the Å¿aid excrements, otherwiÅ¿e it had been impoÅ¿Å¿ible, to haue taken foorth the child.

To help and Å¿uccour one that is lean and barren, or elÅ¿e of little Å¿tature, as alÅ¿o Å¿uch as are either too old, or too young: they muÅ¿t haue recourÅ¿e long before hand, vnto medicines that Å¿hall mollifie, moiÅ¿ten, and relaxe; not onely the membranes, which ought to be dilated and Å¿tretch'd, that they may be made more Å¿ouple and gentle; But likewiÅ¿e you muÅ¿t annoint the Cartilages, and Ligaments that ioine the Os pubis, Sacrum, Os Coccygis, and Ilium, which muÅ¿t be done with oyntments already Å¿et downe, and euen in the verie houre of the deliuerie, annoynt all the Å¿aid parts therewith.

Some miÅ¿like not, about the end of the ninth moneth, to bathe the woman, either with a generall or particular bath, as we haue heretofore appointed; as likewiÅ¿e to giue her, euery morning, eight or ten daies before her lying in, this Drinke.
A Drinke to make eaÅ¿ie the deliuerie. Take Oile of Å¿weet Almonds, drawen without fire, an ounce, water of Parietary, two ounces, mingle th â¢ m together, and let her drinke it.
The which I haue oftentimes tried in many women, and among the reÅ¿t, in Madame Capp, who before had been many times deliuered with much paine and Å¿orrow, of her children, dead. But Å¿ince I counÅ¿ell'd her to vÅ¿e this medicine, Å¿he hath been deliuered (thankes be to God) verie fortunately of many children liuing. The Å¿ame remedies do likewiÅ¿e Å¿erue for them, that haue any CalloÅ¿itie, or hardneÅ¿Å¿e, in the paÅ¿Å¿age of Nature.

The weake and dainty women muÅ¿t be fed with yelkes of egges, cullis, a toÅ¿t with wine and Å¿ugar,Remedy for the dainty. or Hyppocras: and that a little at a time, and often, you may alÅ¿o giue them a little confection of Alhermes diÅ¿Å¿olued, either in wine or Hippocras: Cinamon water alÅ¿o that is well made, and not too Å¿trong, is very fit and good.

And if the feare of the paine doth hinder the deliuery, then the woman muÅ¿t be incouraged,Fear of paine. telling her that Å¿hee Å¿hall bee quickly freed from this Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e, and that it is common vnto all women, to haue Å¿uch paines, cheriÅ¿hing her with good hopes, aÅ¿Å¿uring her that her trauaile will bee very eaÅ¿ie, and promiÅ¿ing her,A good deceit. that Å¿he Å¿hall haue either a Å¿onne or a daughter, according as you know Å¿he deÅ¿ires, as we haue Å¿aid before, flattering and Å¿oothing her as much as you can, without chiding or giuing her any croÅ¿Å¿e Å¿peeches at all.

The moÅ¿t grieuous and troubleÅ¿ome accident,CauÅ¿e of the moÅ¿t troubleÅ¿ome deliuery which a Woman can haue, that is in trauaile, is when there happens vnto her, any fluxe, of bloud, or ConvulÅ¿ions; for either of them kill both the Mother and the child inÅ¿tantly, eÅ¿pecially, if the fluxe of bloud continue long: becauÅ¿e through the great loÅ¿Å¿e of bloud (which is the liues treaÅ¿ure) the Å¿pirits and heate are diÅ¿Å¿olued.

And concerning ConvulÅ¿ions,Why ConuulÅ¿ions are dangerous. they are very dangerous; becauÅ¿e the braine beeing hurt, it cannot affoord Å¿uch Å¿tore of Å¿pirits as are needfull, for the reÅ¿piration of the Mother, and the child, who breath's onely by meanes of the Å¿pirits, that are imparted
vnto him by the Arteryes of his mother, which cauÅ¿eth him to bee choked and Å¿tifled. BeÅ¿ides, the great convulÅ¿ion, makes the Midrife, and the muÅ¿cles of the vpper belly, moue Å¿o violently, that the child is much Å¿haken, and puts both him and his mother in danger to be Å¿tifled, and die.

What muÅ¿t bee done in fluxes and convulÅ¿ions.Eyther of theÅ¿e accidents happening, or elÅ¿e both together, the mother and the child muÅ¿t bee Å¿uccoured without any delay, which Å¿hall bee done (to Å¿peake in a word) by deliuering her. And this ought to be done, either by the helpe of a Chirurgian, or elÅ¿e of a very skilfull Midwife.

Lib. de Å¿uper faetatione. A good Å¿entence of Hypocrates.
Hippocrates well obÅ¿erued it, when he Å¿aith. If in a difficult trauaile there happen a great fluxe of bloud, without any paine before the trauaile, then is there danger leÅ¿t the child come forth dead, or that he will not liue, and therefore Å¿he muÅ¿t bee Å¿odainely deliuered, the which wee haue oftentimes Å¿eene (to our great griefe) happen vnto diuers women, that haue died, through the obÅ¿tinaÅ¿y of their friends and kinsfolks; yea and Å¿ome alÅ¿o through their PhiÅ¿itians and Chirurgians feare, who delayed the time, thinking, and hoping that the fluxe would Å¿tay: telling them that the child came naturally, being well placed, with his head forward and that the mother Å¿hould bee deliuered euen of her Å¿elfe.

I know there be many, both PhiÅ¿itians and Chirurgians, that will appoint diuers inward, and outward medicines, yea to make reuulÅ¿ion and altar the courÅ¿e of bloud, will cauÅ¿e a vaine to bee opened
in the arme once or twice: rather then conÅ¿ent to this practize. But yet of all their medicines, I could neuer Å¿ee any that did good, but that in the end they were conÅ¿trained to vÅ¿e the hand: the which I counÅ¿ell to be done Å¿peedily, and chieflie if the mother be at her full time, and ready to lye downe; which may be both knowne of the woman, and alÅ¿o perceiued by the throwes Å¿hee hath, or which went before: as alÅ¿o by the dilatation of of the inner orifice of the wombe, which will be open: and likewiÅ¿e feeling with the finger, that the waters are gathered and ready to come and iÅ¿Å¿ue forth.A good obÅ¿eruation. And when the water Å¿hall bee broken and come away, then Å¿o much the rather muÅ¿t the child be taken out; though the woman haue not gone aboue foure, fiue, Å¿ixe, Å¿euen, or eight moneths.Sometimes the waters muÅ¿t bee let forth. And ye muÅ¿t note that if the Å¿aid water be not broken, and that the fluxe of bloud bee very great; then you Å¿hall let forth the water, by dilating, and Å¿tretching gently the inner orifice of the womb: thereby to draw forth the child, as we will Å¿hew heereafter.

But becauÅ¿e many women are Å¿ubiect to a fluxe of bloud, in their fourth, fifth, Å¿ixth, Å¿euenth,Caution concerning the fluxe of bloud or eighth moneth of child-bearing: being not as yet ready to bee deliuered: therefore the Chirurgion muÅ¿t obÅ¿erue from what place this bloud is Å¿ent, the which may be from the entrance or Vagina of the wombe, and not from within the body thereof, where the child is contained, and incloÅ¿ed, which may bee eaÅ¿ily perceiued, if the woman haue no throwes, or if the inner orifice of her wombe be not
open, but cloÅ¿e Å¿hut: then there is no likelihood of any deliuery towards, for bloud may iÅ¿Å¿ue and come from the Å¿aid outward necke,When they muÅ¿t not bee deliuered in a fluxe of bloud or Vagina, both in maide and woman with child: If it bee Å¿o, then it will not be needful, to meddle with Å¿uch women, or to force them at all, but onely you muÅ¿t proceed to medicines, that Å¿hall Å¿tay the Å¿aid fluxe of bloud. As wee will Å¿hew in the chapter of the after purgings that flow immoderately in women newly deliuered.

A worthy Å¿eÌ tence of Hippocrates. Lib. 1. de Morb. Mulier. It may alÅ¿o happen becauÅ¿e the woman is plethoricall, and full of bloud: In this caÅ¿e we muÅ¿t follow the opinion of Hippocrates, who Å¿aith, that if a woman that is in trauaile, cannot be deliuered, and that her paines continue many daies: if Å¿hee bee young, luÅ¿ty, and full of bloud you may let her bleed in the foot, if her Å¿trength will beare it.

Other accidents that may hinder the deliuery.But if Å¿he be troubled with any vlcer, tumor, excreÅ¿cence of fleÅ¿h, Hemorrhoides, inflammation, chapps, or the like, which may chance in the necke of the wombe; then Å¿hall Å¿he be handled, as we will Å¿hew in their proper places. All the which indiÅ¿poÅ¿itions may make the deliuery difficult, and cauÅ¿e, that the parts cannot be dilated, according as it is Å¿it and neceÅ¿Å¿ary, for the childs comming forth.

For remedying the deliuery, that is too Å¿oone, or too late: we muÅ¿t haue regard vnto the cauÅ¿e, and according thereto it muÅ¿t bee cured, and chiefly that, which Å¿hall concerne the mother; whereof we will treat, when we come to Å¿peake of the Abortment: it being my purpoÅ¿e in this place, to Å¿peake
onely of thoÅ¿e things which are fit, and ought to bee done in the time, and at the houre of the deliuerie.

Now for the comforting of a woman,Cure when the fault is froÌ the child. and eaÅ¿ing of her trauaile, when the difficulty doth proceede from the child; as when he is weake, tender, Å¿ickly, or dead: as likewiÅ¿e if he be too big, or a monÅ¿ter hauing two heads, or if he be ill turned, and that he offer himÅ¿elfe amiÅ¿Å¿e: then the Chirurgion in this caÅ¿e Å¿hall helpe, and Å¿et to his hand in this manner.

FirÅ¿t, if it be through the weakeneÅ¿Å¿e, or tenderneÅ¿Å¿e of the child being Å¿icke: the Chirurgion muÅ¿t not delay one minute of time,When the deliuery muÅ¿t be haÅ¿tned. to haÅ¿ten the deliuery, and he muÅ¿t incourage the woman to doe the like. If the head come firÅ¿t, then Å¿hall hee proceed therein gently, as in the naturall deliuery: applying beneath, and chiefly about the fundament, and os Pubis, which are the two vtmoÅ¿t parts of the naturall paÅ¿Å¿age, Å¿ome ointments with the fingers ends, Ointments made for the purpoÅ¿e. hauing his nayles pared very cloÅ¿e. For this annointing wil prouoke and Å¿tirre vp the Matrice, to thruÅ¿t out the child. The oyntment is this.

div.head: Of diuers deliueries wherein the operation of the hand is vÅ¿ed. And firÅ¿t what the Chirurgion ought to conÅ¿ider before hee Å¿ets to his hand. CHAP. X.
div.p: WHen the Chirurgion Å¿hall bee called to deliuer a woman that is in trauaile and cannot bee deliuered naturally: before he venter to doe any thing, he muÅ¿t conÅ¿ider two things:Two things muÅ¿t be conÅ¿idered in theÅ¿e deliueries. the firÅ¿t is to know whether the mother haue Å¿trength enough to endure the violence of Manuall operation: and hauing found that Å¿he is able, he muÅ¿t then Å¿earch, whether the child be dead, or aliue, for Å¿ometimes the child is taken dead, and Å¿ometimes aliue out of the mothers wombe.

Now as concerning the Mother:ConÅ¿iderations concerning the mother. FirÅ¿t the Chirurgion muÅ¿t behold her face, heare her Å¿peake, obÅ¿erue her doings, countenance, &behauiour, then preÅ¿ently muÅ¿t he feele her pulÅ¿e, which if he find to be equall, Å¿trong, not intermitting, and that Å¿he bee not much changed from her wonted diÅ¿poÅ¿ition? and likewiÅ¿e if the poore woman, her friends and kinsfolkes doe intreate him to helpe her, aÅ¿Å¿uring him, that Å¿he will courageouÅ¿ly endure; all that he
Å¿hall doe vnto her: then following the aduiÅ¿e of her kinsfolkes and friends,The mother doth hazard her life in the deliuery. he muÅ¿t go about it: foretelling them neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e; that this kind of practiÅ¿e is very dangerous, and that the mother venters her life, Å¿eeing that the child is either dead; or elÅ¿e likely to die, if he be not already.

But if the Chirurgion find, that her face and Å¿peach is decayed, and weakned, her countenance changed, her pulÅ¿e Å¿mall frequent, Å¿ometime intermitting and formicant: and that Å¿hee hath often Å¿wounings,Remedyes muÅ¿t not bee diÅ¿ â¢ amed. ConvulÅ¿ions, and cold Å¿weats: then hee muÅ¿t forbeare for feare leaÅ¿t hee be blamed, and thereby diÅ¿credit thoÅ¿e meanes which Å¿hould haue profited, and may alÅ¿o doe good vnto others.

Signes of the childs being aliue.Now you may know by theÅ¿e Å¿ignes whether the child be aliue, or dead. If the child Å¿tirre it is a Å¿igne he is aliue; which the Mother may coniecture, and alÅ¿o the Chirurgion, by laying his hand vpon her belly. And for the better aÅ¿Å¿urance heereof, hee muÅ¿t Å¿lide vp his hand into the Womans Matrice, and Å¿earch for the childs Nauell. If, in holding it betweene his fingers, he feele a beating of the Arteries, as alÅ¿o, if by laying his hand vpon the childs temples, or elÅ¿e handling the wriÅ¿t or Å¿ole of his foot he find, that the Arteries doe beate, and likewiÅ¿e, if in putting his finger into the childs mouth he perceiue that he either Å¿ucke, or wag his tongue, it is a Å¿igne that he is aliue.

Signes that the child is dead.ContrariwiÅ¿e, if the foreÅ¿aid things doe not concurre, and that the mother feele a heauineÅ¿Å¿e, and that in turning of her Å¿elfe, (whether it bee on the
right Å¿ide, or the left) the child doth fall like a boule, if her belly be cold, and that there comes an ill Å¿ent from her, if her breath Å¿mell Å¿trong, and her countenance look wanne, and of the colour of lead: and that the childs Nauell, or after birth offer it Å¿elfe formoÅ¿t, beÅ¿ides, if the chirurgion, putting his hand vp, findes the child to be cold, without pulÅ¿e, neither Å¿ucking, nor mouing his tongue: then I Å¿ay it may be iudged, that the child is dead.

But as the child may offer himÅ¿elfe, being dead,The child commeth after diuers faÅ¿hions. in diuers poÅ¿itions, or faÅ¿hion; So likewiÅ¿e muÅ¿t we vÅ¿e diuers conÅ¿iderations and meanes to draw him forth: as wee will more particularly Å¿hew heereafter.

div.head: The meanes to helpe a woman in trauaile, hauing withall a fluxe of bloud, or ConvulÅ¿ions. CHAP. XI.
div.p: WE haue Å¿hew'd you before, that a woman being in trauaile, and hauing either a fluxe of bloud, or ConvulÅ¿ions, Å¿he muÅ¿t be Å¿peedily helped, becauÅ¿e the deferring or delay thereof, will endanger her life.

Wherefore you muÅ¿t proceed heerein after this manner. And Å¿ince that in euery deliuery, the Å¿ituation is a matter of great conÅ¿equence,Situation fit in al deliueries. to make it the more facile and eaÅ¿y: therefore you muÅ¿t begin in this Å¿ort.

The right placing of them.FirÅ¿t the woman muÅ¿t be laid ouerthwart a bed, both for the better conueniencie of the Chirurgion, or Midwife, that Å¿hall deliuer her, and alÅ¿o that Å¿he may be held, and Å¿tayed behind the faÅ¿ter, by Å¿ome Å¿trong bodie,The commoditie thereof. Å¿o that Å¿he neither Å¿lip forward, nor backward, in the operation or drawing forth of the child. LikewiÅ¿e, there muÅ¿t be one on each Å¿ide of her to hold her knees and thighs firme, and to keep them aÅ¿under one from another: her knees muÅ¿t be bow'd, and her heeles drawen vpward, (as we haue Å¿aid before in the Naturall deliuerie,) her head muÅ¿t be laid vpon a boulÅ¿ter lying croÅ¿Å¿e the bed; her backe being a little raiÅ¿ed, and her hips lifted Å¿omewhat higher, with pillowes laid vnder them, and her hinder parts muÅ¿t lie within halfe a foot of the beds Å¿ide. She muÅ¿t haue a linnen cloth three or foure times double laid vpon her Å¿tomacke and belly, that may reach downe ouer her knees, euen to the middeÅ¿t of the leg: So that neither wind, nor cold may offend her, nor any of the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tants Å¿ee what the Chirurgion toucheth, or doth: and likewiÅ¿e, that the woman be not afraid of him, when he Å¿hall be about his buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e. And therefore Hippocrates for this reaÅ¿on, would haue the womans eyes Å¿hut or couer'd.

When the woman is thus placed, the Chirurgion muÅ¿t put vp his hand (being firÅ¿t annointed) into the firÅ¿t entrance of the naturall parts,The clots of bloud muÅ¿t be taken away. that he may take foorth all the clots of bloud, which he Å¿hall find there.

Then he muÅ¿t conÅ¿ider, whether the inner necke
be wide enough for him to thruÅ¿t in his hand, and to turne the childe, if it be needfull: Now if the inner necke be not Å¿ufficiently dilated,The inner neck may be dilated. then Å¿hall he, as gently as poÅ¿Å¿ibly he can, and without any violence (hauing firÅ¿t annionted all the parts thereof with freÅ¿h Butter, or Å¿ome ointment) Å¿tretch it by little and little, till he get in his hand: if the water be not broken, he need not be afraid to let it out: then preÅ¿ently if the child come with his head formoÅ¿t, he Å¿hall turne him gently to find his feet, which he may do more eaÅ¿ily, then if the waters had been let foorth before: becauÅ¿e, that much moiÅ¿ture doth make the child Å¿lide, and turne better, then when he is drie. And when he hath found one of his feet, he muÅ¿t draw it gently without violence, and tie about it a piece of riband, with a Å¿liding knot,How the feet may be found that he may put the foot in againe (leauing the riband hanging out) to make the more roome for his hand to goe in and Å¿earch for the other foot, which may be done by Å¿liding his hand al along the childes thigh. And hauing found them both, he Å¿hall draw them out gently in a direct line, giuing the woman a little breathing, and bidding her to Å¿traine her Å¿elfe when Å¿he feeles any throwes, or paines, then the Chirurgion (hauing in a readineÅ¿Å¿e a fine linnen cloth warme, he muÅ¿t wrap it about the childes thighs, for feare leaÅ¿t he Å¿lip out of his hand, if he tooke him naked) and Å¿o pluck gently, vntill his buttockes appeare, and the body with the head doth follow; obÅ¿eruing neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e, that his belly and breaÅ¿t be turned
