downeward, as we will Å¿hew hereafter more particularly.

Experience will make it manifeÅ¿t vnto vs, by the Å¿tories following, how neceÅ¿Å¿arie it is to deliuer a woman with child, when a fluxe of bloud, or conuulÅ¿ions do continue: and that Å¿he cannot be Å¿aued by ordinarie medicines.

A Å¿torie.The yeare 1599. Madam Simon yet aliue daughter to Mr. Pareus, CounÅ¿ellour, and chiefe Chirurgion to the King; being ready to lie downe was Å¿urpriÅ¿ed with a great flux of bloud, hauing about her Mad. la Charomie for her Midwife, and likewiÅ¿e Mr. Hautin the Kings PhiÅ¿ition in ordinarie, and Mr. Rigault Doctors of PhiÅ¿icke in Paris, and becauÅ¿e of great Å¿wounings that tooke her euery quarter of an houre through the loÅ¿Å¿e of bloud Å¿he had: Master Marchant my Å¿on in law and my Å¿elfe were Å¿ent for; But I finding her almoÅ¿t without pulÅ¿e, hauing her voice weake,The Chirurgion muÅ¿t foretell the danger. and her lips pale: I told her mother and her husband that Å¿he was in great danger of her life, and that there was but one way to Å¿aue her, which was, to deliuer her Å¿peedily: the which I had Å¿eene practized by the late Mr. Pareus her Father, who had cauÅ¿ed me to do the like, vnto a Gentlewoman of Mad. de Seneterre. Then her mother, and her husband earneÅ¿tly intreated vs to helpe her, and that they would put her into our hands to diÅ¿poÅ¿e of her. And Å¿o Å¿odainely, following the aduiÅ¿e of the PhiÅ¿itions, Å¿he was very happily deliuered of a liuely child.

Another Å¿torie.The yeare 1600. I was commanded to goe and
viÅ¿it a great Lady, that was taken with a great and violent flux of bloud, through a fright Å¿he had of a great thunder clap: being come vnto her,They muÅ¿t reÅ¿t in a flux of bloud. I found that her flux was much mitigated: but Å¿he being conÅ¿trained to goe twelue, or fifteene leagues from Paris, and fearing leaÅ¿t that the Å¿aid flux Å¿hould continue, Å¿he was brought thither by my Å¿onne in law Mr. Marchant by water: where Å¿he was no Å¿oner arriued, but her flux of bloud tooke her againe, which made him diÅ¿like it, and iudge that it would proue ill, contrarie to the opinion of MaÅ¿ter de la Riuiere, the Kings chiefe PhiÅ¿ition, who was there at the Å¿ame time: Whereupon, I was preÅ¿ently Å¿ent for in poÅ¿t together with MaÅ¿ter Renard the Kings PhiÅ¿ition. We being come thither, found things in better eÅ¿tate; and the Å¿aid MaÅ¿ter de la Riuiere, tooke leaue to goe towards the King. But on a Å¿odaine the Å¿aid flux began a freÅ¿h, which made them Å¿end for Mr. MareÅ¿cot, and Mr Martin, the kings PhyÅ¿itions, who notwithÅ¿tanding were not come before her deliuerie: which the kinsfolks & friends of the Å¿aid Ladie, and likewiÅ¿e Mr Renard, Mr Marchant, and my Å¿elfe, were of opinion to haÅ¿ten, becauÅ¿e of the great loÅ¿Å¿e of bloud Å¿he had, and the often Å¿wounning that tooke her: but as Å¿oone as Å¿he was deliuered, the flux of bloud ceaÅ¿ed.

The yeare 1603, Madame DanzÃ©, or Chece, The third Å¿torie. being in trauaile, was taken with the like flux of bloud, which held her from morning till eight or nine of the clocke at night; hauing with her the Queenes Midwife, Mad. BourÅ¿iere, MaÅ¿ter le Fieure, Riolan,
Le Moine, regent Doctors in the facultie of PhyÅ¿icke at Paris, and Mr de Sainct Germain maÅ¿ter Apothecarie, were called to looke vnto her; and becauÅ¿e Å¿he loÅ¿t much bloud, they called Mr HonorÃ© the kings Chirurgion, who being vnwilling to attempt any thing without my aduiÅ¿e, I was likewiÅ¿e Å¿ent for. And as Å¿oone as I was come, my opinion with the reÅ¿t of the companie was, to deliuer her: which was done by the Å¿aid HonorÃ©, the child liuing.

The fourth hiÅ¿torie.Of late memorie, Mad. Coulon (being aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿ted in her trauaile by Mad. la Charonne, a verie skilfull Midwife,) hauing a great flux of bloud; after that Mr Martin, Hautin, Cornuty, Pietre, the kings PhyÅ¿itions, and Doctors of Paris, had giuen her many things for the Å¿taying of the Å¿aid flux, in the end for feare leaÅ¿t by looÅ¿ing her bloud, Å¿he might alÅ¿o looÅ¿e her life, falling into a Å¿yncope: with their aduiÅ¿e Å¿he was deliuered, by the Å¿aid HonorÃ©, and preÅ¿ently her flux was Å¿taied.

An Admonition for young Chirurgions.But as theÅ¿e women and children aforeÅ¿aid haue been Å¿aued, by being deliuered in time: So likewiÅ¿e theÅ¿e following, loÅ¿t their liues, becauÅ¿e they were not Å¿uccoured, as Art and experience did require, their kinsfolks and friends being vnwilling to haue any go about it in due time: whereof theÅ¿e two hiÅ¿tories may beare witneÅ¿Å¿e.

Another Å¿torie. Mad. Vion being readie to be deliuer'd, fell into a great flux of bloud, and though Å¿ome were of opinion, to deliuer her without further delay; yet this being deferred vpon the counÅ¿ell of others,
who hop'd to Å¿tay the flux with ordinarie medicines, they Å¿uffered her to looÅ¿e her bloud, by little and little, and at laÅ¿t to looÅ¿e her life. The Å¿ame chance hapned to Madame GaÅ¿selin, who not hauing help in time, dyed euen as it was foretold, it would come to paÅ¿Å¿e; hauing loÅ¿t all her bloud, before Å¿he would giue her conÅ¿ent to be deliuer'd: which will be a good occaÅ¿ion, to admoniÅ¿h a young Chirurgion, neuer to defer this worke when he is called, and Å¿ees a great euacuation of bloud. It is now fiue and twentie yeares, Å¿ince I Å¿aw this practized, by the late Mr Pareus, and Mr Hubert, of whom, we are bound to acknowledge, and willingly confeÅ¿Å¿e, that we haue learned both this and many other experiments.

Mad. de Mommor, Another Å¿torie agreeing with this purpoÅ¿e. being about fiue and twentie yeares of age, and neere her time of deliuerie, one day found her Å¿elfe ill, about foure or fiue a clocke in the morning, neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿he roÅ¿e and went to Church, which was neere her houÅ¿e, her paine by fits began againe, and Å¿he fell into a continuall flux of bloud: At three daies end Å¿he was deliuered with great eaÅ¿e, without any help of the Midwife: and preÅ¿ently after, followed the after burthen: NeuertheleÅ¿Å¿e Å¿he died the Å¿ame day, at night: and was kept a prettie while by her friends, who could not perÅ¿wade themÅ¿elues, that Å¿he was dead: At laÅ¿t being opened by Mr Pineau, the kings Å¿worne Chirurgion at Paris, in the preÅ¿ence of Mr Faber, and Mr Baillou, regent Doctors of the facultie of PhyÅ¿icke, at Paris; her wombe was found
broken, and rent, right in that place, where the veine and arterie hypogaÅ¿tricke, aÅ¿cend toward the mid'Å¿t thereof; which likewiÅ¿e were diÅ¿Å¿olued, and gaue way to all that iÅ¿Å¿ue of bloud.

As for the convulÅ¿ions which commonly happen through the childs great Å¿triuing, when hee deÅ¿ires to come forth; and (not being turned aright) doth Å¿o extend the womb that the Å¿aid convulÅ¿ions, follow thereupon: here it is to be feared, leaÅ¿t all within, wil be torne and broken,Stories concerning convulÅ¿ions. and therefore it is conuenient to deliuer the woman, with all poÅ¿Å¿ible Å¿peed, which hath beene practized both by my Å¿elfe, and of late by MaÅ¿ter Binet a Å¿worn Chirurgion of Paris, a man of great experience, who being Å¿ent for by Doctor Bouuart, to deliuer Opportune Guerreau, the wife of SilueÅ¿ter the Printer: which had beene in labour from eight a clock in the morning, till nine at night: and finding her pulÅ¿e very weake and Å¿mall, as alÅ¿o the woman depriued of all Å¿ence and motion,The Chirurgions wiÅ¿dom at the firÅ¿t he was Å¿omwhat fearefull. But being intreated by her Husband, and fearing leaÅ¿t Å¿hee might either die Å¿uddenly, or elÅ¿e fall into convulÅ¿ions: he putting his hand into her wombe, found the childs head, (the water not being broke) which he let out, and preÅ¿ently deliuered her with much eaÅ¿e, and Å¿hee is yet liuing. Therefore wee need not expect, till the Å¿aid convulÅ¿ions grow Å¿tronger, for fear leaÅ¿t the wombe be broken, and torne through the great Å¿triuing of the child, when hee is not able to come foorth, as wee may plainely Å¿ee by the Å¿tories following.

The yeare 1607. the Å¿aid MaÅ¿ter Binet was Å¿ent for, together with de le Moine, A wonderfull Å¿tory. and Alton MaÅ¿ter Barber Chirurgion at Paris, to cut vp the dead body of Ione du Boys, and hauing opened her nether belly, found the child vpon the guts, who had bruÅ¿ed & broken the wombe, and paÅ¿Å¿ed quite through it, there being Å¿tore of bloud Å¿hed in the capacity of the Å¿aid belly.

MaÅ¿ter Pineau, Guerin, Another Å¿torie. and Launay Å¿worne Chirurgians of Paris, can beare me witneÅ¿Å¿e, that in opening a poore woman, that died in the HoÅ¿pitall of the Citty: we found her child Å¿wimming among the guts in her belly, the bottome of her Matrice being rent and torne.

div.head: The meanes to helpe a woman when her after-burthen comes for moÅ¿t. CHAP. XII.
div.p:
IF the after-burthen offer it Å¿elfe formoÅ¿t,When the after burthen comes formoÅ¿t, there is a fluxe of bloud. the moÅ¿t Å¿ure and ready way to helpe the Woman is to deliuer her Å¿peedily, becauÅ¿e moÅ¿t commonly there follows, a continuall fluxe of bloud. For that the orifices of the veines are opened, which are Å¿pread in the Å¿ides of the wombe, and there meet with the veÅ¿Å¿els of the afterburthen: and when the Matrice doth Å¿train and force it Å¿elfe, to put forth the child, then doth it thruÅ¿t out both the bloud that is contained therin, and that which is drawne thither, either by any
heat or paine. BeÅ¿ides, when the child is incloÅ¿ed in the wombe, and the orifice thereof, Å¿topt with the after-birth: then hee cannot breath any longer by his Mothers Arteryes,How the child is Å¿tifled. and Å¿o for want of helpe, he will be quickly choked, and euen Å¿wallowed vp in the bloud, which is contained in the wombe, and which iÅ¿Å¿ueth from the veynes that are open therein.

But before you attempt any thing, theÅ¿e two points muÅ¿t be obÅ¿erued: FirÅ¿t, whether the afterburthen bee come foorth but a little, or elÅ¿e very much: if it bee but little (when the mother is well placed) it muÅ¿t be thruÅ¿t,ObÅ¿eruatioÌs to draw forth the after burthen. and put backe againe with as much care, as may poÅ¿Å¿ibly be. And if the head of the child come firÅ¿t, let it bee placed right in the paÅ¿Å¿age, thereby to helpe the naturall deliuery, but if you find any difficulty, or if you perceiue that the childs head cannot eaÅ¿ily bee brought forward, or that the child, or his mother, or both together bee weake, foreÅ¿eeing that the trauaile will bee long, then without doubt the beÅ¿t and Å¿ureÅ¿t way is, to Å¿earch for the feete (as we haue Å¿aid) and to plucke him forth gently by them.

Another obÅ¿eruation.The other point to bee obÅ¿erued is, that if the Å¿aid after-birth be much come foorth, and that it cannot bee put backe againe: as well by reaÅ¿on of the bignes of it, as alÅ¿o of the fluxe of bloud, that commonly companies it: and likewiÅ¿e if the child follow it cloÅ¿e,When the afterbirth muÅ¿t be drawne forth. Å¿taying onely to come into the world: then muÅ¿t the after-burthen be puld away quite, and when it is come forth, it muÅ¿t be laide aÅ¿ide,
without cutting of the Å¿tring that cleaues vnto it. For by the guiding of the Å¿aid Å¿tring, you may eaÅ¿ily find the child, who whether hee bee aliue or dead, muÅ¿t be drawn out by the legs, with as much dexterity as may be. And this muÅ¿t be done onely in great neceÅ¿Å¿ity, that the child may bee quickly drawne forth: as it may be eaÅ¿ily iudged by the Å¿entence of Hippocrates, who Å¿aith, Lib. 1. de morbis Mulier. The after-birth muÅ¿t come laÅ¿t. that the after-burthen Å¿hould come forth after the child, for if it come firÅ¿t, the child cannot liue, becauÅ¿e he takes his life from it, as a plant doth from the earth.

Sometime it chaunceth, that a part of the after-birth, as alÅ¿o the membrane which containes the waters doe offer it Å¿elfe like a skin, and comes forth Å¿ometimes the length of halfe a foote, which happens to Å¿uch women as haue the skin wherein the waters are contained Å¿welling out to the bignes of ones fiÅ¿t and more, which breaking foorth of themÅ¿elues, leaue the skinnne hanging forth, and yet the child not following it, which happening,It muÅ¿t bee puld gently. it muÅ¿t not be violently puld away: becauÅ¿e the afterburthen oftentimes, is not wholly looÅ¿ened from the Å¿ides of the wombe. So that in drawing that, you Å¿hall likewiÅ¿e draw the Å¿aide after burthen, and Å¿o conÅ¿equently, the womb, or elÅ¿e part therof, which commonly brings the woman into extream paines, and fainting, yea, and oftentimes to death: Which hapned (to my great griefe) vnto a Gentlewoman,A Å¿tory. that died as Å¿oone as Å¿hee was deliuered, who putting her Å¿elfe into her nurÅ¿es hands, who tooke vpon her to be a Midwife: and was Å¿o ventrous, as to
plucke and draw forth the Å¿aid Membrane, and part of the after-burthen, which came to light by means of her Chamber-maid, who had kept it, and Å¿hewed it vs after her deceaÅ¿e: we being very inquiÅ¿itiue to know the cauÅ¿e of her death.

The remedy.But when this happens, it muÅ¿t not be puld away but rather gently be thruÅ¿t in againe, or elÅ¿e you may put in your hand, betweene that, and the neck of the wombe, to find the childs feete, and Å¿o draw him forth, as we haue Å¿hewed before.

I haue Å¿et downe this Å¿tory more at large, by reaÅ¿on of the great Å¿orrow I tooke; for this Gentlewomans death, whom I had deliuered twice before, with mine own hands, comming not Å¿oone enough to helpe her the third time.

div.head: The meanes to deliuer a woman when her child is dead, in her wombe. CHAP. XIII.
div.p: WHen it is certainly knowne, that the child is dead, the woman muÅ¿t bee placed in the Å¿ame manner, as it hath beene Å¿hew'n, where wee Å¿pake of the taking forth of the child, when there is a fluxe of bloud.

What muÅ¿t be done wheÌ the childe coms ill.If he put forth an arme, Å¿houlder, backe, belly, or other part of his body firÅ¿t, hee muÅ¿t be turned with all diligence, and drawne forth by the feete, as we will more particularly declare, in euery Å¿euerall deliuery, according to the Å¿undry faÅ¿hions, wherein he may come, either aliue or dead.

If he come dead, with his head forwards,The woman muÅ¿t be Å¿peedily helped. and that there is no hope at all of the womans deliuery without helpe, and that her Å¿trength begins manifeÅ¿tly to decay: the Å¿ureÅ¿t way is to apply the hand. And then the Chirurgion Å¿hall thruÅ¿t gently his left hand beeing wide opened, betweene the childs head, and the necke of the wombe: and with his right hand he muÅ¿t put between the Å¿aid head, and flat of the hand, an Iron Crochet, Å¿uch a one as you Å¿ee heere figured vnto you.

figure.p: The figure or portaict of the Crochet, wherewith the dead childe may bee drawn forth of his mothers belly, when hee comes with his head forward: the which is Å¿o lock'd within the os pubis, that it cannot be diÅ¿placed or puÅ¿ht vpward, to turne and draw foorth the child by the feete, without much hurting the Mother, and often endaungering her life. div.p:
Which muÅ¿t bee faÅ¿tned to the Å¿ide of the childs head, as about his eare, or bone of the Temples, or in Å¿ome other place if it may bee done
conueniently, as within the hollow of the eye, or the hinder bone of his head, the Chirurgion keeping his left hand in the Å¿ame place where he put it firÅ¿t, and therewith he Å¿hall wagge and Å¿tirre gently the childs head:Skill in drawing forth the child. and at that very inÅ¿tant, with his right hand wherin he holds the crochet, Å¿o faÅ¿tned, in any part of the head, muÅ¿t he draw and bring out the child: bidding the woman Å¿triue and force her Å¿elfe, as though Å¿he would be deliuered alone. And it is to be noted, that the Chirurgion muÅ¿t take his time, to draw him forth, when the woman falls into throws, for while the throws continue, the child Å¿lides forth the eaÅ¿ier.

Oftentimes it chaunceth, that the Crochet cannot be put high enough at the firÅ¿t, to draw foorth the head all at once,ObÅ¿eruation in vÅ¿ing the Crochet. Å¿o that after it is come forward and drawne out in part, they are faine to take away the Crochet, from the place where it was firÅ¿t faÅ¿tned, and put it in againe to take new hold higher in another place, which the Chirurgion may doe very fitly, as it hath beene Å¿hewed already. LikewiÅ¿e, if the Crochet be not well, and Å¿urely faÅ¿tned at firÅ¿t but that it Å¿lip, and loÅ¿e the firÅ¿t hold, then it will bee needfull, to faÅ¿ten, and put it in a Å¿urer place.

The child may be Å¿urely drawne out by the Å¿houlders.Hauing drawne forth the head, and the Crochet beeing taken out, the Chirurgion Å¿hall Å¿lide in his fingers, very cunningly vnder the childs armepits, that he may draw forth the Å¿houlders, and the reÅ¿t of his body, for by this meanes hee Å¿hall bee eaÅ¿ier drawne out then by the head: which muÅ¿t be done
very leaÅ¿urely, without any violence, giuing the woman leaue to gather her Å¿trength, and expecting till her throws come vpon her.

While the Chirurgion is about this worke, they muÅ¿t giue the poore Woman, a little wine, or elÅ¿e let her Å¿ucke a toÅ¿t Å¿op't in wine, or Hippocras: perÅ¿wading and incouraging her, that Å¿he Å¿hall quickly be deliuered.

This manner of drawing the dead child out of the mothers womb, is Å¿afer, and Å¿peedier,Safe way to draw the child by the feete. then that which is vÅ¿ed by turning and putting backe the childs head, to finde his feete, and Å¿o pull him out thereby. For whenÅ¿oeuer the childs heade is much entred within the os Pubis it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible to thruÅ¿t him vpward,Inconueniences to turne the child. and turne him without much indaungering the Mother: and cauÅ¿ing great contuÅ¿ion in the wombe, from whence proceeds diuers accidents, and Å¿ometime death, as I haue Å¿eene it often happen.

I know Å¿ome will alledge, that they haue taken foorth children aliue, which were thought to haue beene dead, in the Mothers wombe, with the Å¿aide Crochet: and that they haue preÅ¿ently died, onely with the hurt they receiued by the Crochet, and certainely this is a cruell kind of practize. Whereto I anÅ¿were, that we muÅ¿t diligently looke, and conÅ¿ider, whether the child be aliue or dead, before wee put in the Crochet,ConÅ¿iderations in vÅ¿ing the Crochet. and if there be any appearance of life, wee muÅ¿t deferre the taking of him foorth therewith, as long as we may: But being dead, I Å¿ee no reaÅ¿on but wee Å¿hould take the child forth; with
the Å¿aid Crochet for the cauÅ¿es heeretofore mentioned.QueÅ¿tioÌ whether the Crochet may bee vÅ¿ed. But if the child be aliue, it is a great queÅ¿tion whether he ought to be puld forth by the Crochet, preÅ¿uppoÅ¿ing that the Mother, hauing loÅ¿t her Å¿trength, is ready to dye, except this meanes bee vÅ¿ed: it beeing more expedient to looÅ¿e the Mother then the child, who would both dye, if that were deferred any longer: and whether to Å¿aue the Mother, (who is more deare, then the Å¿aide child) this practize may be ventured. But as I thinke, there are none, that goe about this buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e, but with Å¿ome touch of ConÅ¿cience, which being a point of Diuinity, I leaue to be decided by them, that are more conuerÅ¿ant therein, then my Å¿elfe.

div.head: The meanes to draw forth a child, that is Å¿wollen, and puft vp: in his mothers womb, together with the manner of drawing the head, when it Å¿tayes behind. CHAP. XIIII.
div.p: IF the dead child continue long in the mothers wombe,The dead child Å¿wels and is puft vp. he may eaÅ¿ily be putrified, and not onely his head, breaÅ¿t and nether belly, Å¿wolne and fild with wind, and water, but likewiÅ¿e his legges and feet will be puft vp.

This Å¿welling, and puffing vp, may alÅ¿o happen through all the childs body,The child that is aliue may likewiÅ¿e be Å¿wolne. though he be aliue, hauing eyther the Hydro cephale, or Å¿welling of the head, or the dropÅ¿ie, either of the lungs, or belly:
or elÅ¿e beeing Leucophilegmaticall. This accident happening when the child is aliue, hee muÅ¿t be helped as being aliue, not deliuering the Woman to the childs loÅ¿Å¿e. But if he be dead, and ye perceiue that his head, breÅ¿t, or nether belly is Å¿woln, or fil'd with wind, or wateriÅ¿h matter, then the Chirurgion muÅ¿t put vp his hand carrying in the hollowneÅ¿Å¿e of it a little crooked knife, very Å¿harp, made after this faÅ¿hion, & with the Å¿aide knife hee Å¿hall deuide, and cut the part wherein the wind and water Å¿hall bee incloÅ¿ed, (whether it bee the head, breaÅ¿t, or belly) which beeing let foorth, the childe will grow leÅ¿Å¿e, and afterwards, hee may the more eaÅ¿ily be taken out.

figure.p: The forme of the Knife to deuide the Å¿wolne part, which muÅ¿t be of this bigneÅ¿se heere deÅ¿cribed, that it may the better be carried, within ones hand to the place that muÅ¿t bee cut or open'd, whether it be the head, breaÅ¿t, or belly.

div.p:
It may Å¿o happen, that the childs arme comming formoÅ¿t through the long Å¿tay it makes without, as alÅ¿o becauÅ¿e it hath been pul'd by violence,
will be Å¿wolne, yea, and euen gangren'd, that it cannot poÅ¿Å¿ibly be thruÅ¿t backe againe, that the child may be drawen foorth by the feet: If it fall out to be Å¿o, then the arme muÅ¿t be pul'd out, as far as it can, and if it may be done conueniently, let it be cut off at the ioint of the Å¿houlder, or elÅ¿e as neere vnto it, as may be; the bone Å¿hall be cut off with Å¿harpe cutting pincers, or elÅ¿e Å¿awed off verie euen, the skin and muÅ¿cles being put aÅ¿ide, that Å¿o the bone may be couer'd, with the Å¿aid fleÅ¿h, muÅ¿cle, and skin, which will fall ouer it; and alÅ¿o, that the bone, through his roughneÅ¿Å¿e, and hardneÅ¿Å¿e, may not hurt the Å¿ides of the wombe, the Å¿tumpe that was cut, or Å¿awed being put backe againe.

Sometime the childs head will not follow the bodie, either becauÅ¿e of the bigneÅ¿Å¿e thereof, or elÅ¿e, becauÅ¿e the child is ill turn'd, that in drawing him foorth, he chances to haue his belly, Å¿tomacke, and face lying vpward: which cauÅ¿eth, that the bodie being wholy come foorth, while they would alÅ¿o draw foorth the head, the chin takes hold of the Os pubis, and being pul'd violently, the bodie onely is drawen, and the head not moued, Å¿ticketh faÅ¿t.

For the remedying whereof, that the head Å¿tay not behind: the bodie muÅ¿t be gently turn'd, placing the face downward: (as we Å¿aid before,) for by this Å¿ituation, the head being moued vp and downe, will be eaÅ¿ily drawen foorth with the reÅ¿t of the bodie; by holding the bodie with one hand,

And when the head Å¿tickes, the Chirurgion muÅ¿t thruÅ¿t his left hand into the wombe, and put his fore finger into the childs mouth, to Å¿tay the head, which by reaÅ¿on of the roundneÅ¿Å¿e of it, and moiÅ¿ture of the wombe, roules and Å¿lideth vp and downe, not being eaÅ¿ilie Å¿taied; then with his right hand, let him put in the Crochet, which muÅ¿t be hook't or faÅ¿tned, either in the temples, hole of the eare, hollow of the eye, or elÅ¿e in the mouth; and then let him draw the head gently, both with the Crochet, and alÅ¿o with the left hand, hauing his fore-finger in the childs mouth, and Å¿o bring him foorth as cunningly as he can: taking his time alwaies when the Mother is in Å¿ome paine, that Å¿o the child may be the eaÅ¿ier drawen foorth.

div.head: The meanes to help a Woman in her trauaile, when the child comes with his head formoÅ¿t, but hauing his necke awrie, and his head aÅ¿ide. CHAP. XV.

figure.figDesc: depiction of child in womb: asynclitic birth

div.p:
BEing now to Å¿peake of Births that are contrarie to nature, we will begin firÅ¿t with the Head, as being the worthieÅ¿t, and moÅ¿t notable part of all the bodie. Sometimes the child comes (as he doth naturally) with the head formoÅ¿t, but it is placed amiÅ¿Å¿e, which
may be after foure Å¿euerall faÅ¿hions;In how many faÅ¿hions the head may be placed. either the head lying vpon the backe: or vpon the Å¿tomacke: or elÅ¿e vpon the edge of the Å¿houlders, inclining towards one of the Mothers flanckes, which makes that the child cannot come foorth Å¿traight, and in a direct line: becauÅ¿e his necke is bow'd, and Å¿tands awrie. He being thus turn'd, it is verie hard, yea, euen impoÅ¿Å¿ible, that the Mother Å¿hould be deliuer'd, either through any indeauour of the childs thruÅ¿ting his feet againÅ¿t the bottome of the Matrice: nor by any labour of the woman, forcing likewiÅ¿e and Å¿training her Å¿elfe, as much as Å¿he can poÅ¿Å¿ibly, by holding in her breath. But contrariwiÅ¿e, the more the child Å¿triues to come foorth,When the Mother & the child Å¿triue in vaine. and inioy the outward ayre, the more he intangles and wreath's his necke, Å¿o that at laÅ¿t, both his Å¿trength, and the Mothers, are together much weakned, through the paine they both Å¿uffer; the child being in danger, by reaÅ¿on of the great compreÅ¿Å¿ion that muÅ¿t needs follow the wreathing of his necke, and alÅ¿o by the hindrance of reÅ¿piration,How the child breaths. though he breaths onely as yet by the Arteries of his Mother, vntill the after-burthen be looÅ¿ened, for then he takes breath at his owne mouth. The Marrow alÅ¿o of the backe, and the Å¿inewes (being the inÅ¿truments of motion) may thereby be Å¿o preÅ¿Å¿ed together, that the animal Å¿pirits may be intercepted, which depriueth the child of all motion, and conÅ¿equently of life: wherefore, it will be verie neceÅ¿Å¿arie to help him Å¿peedily, which ought to be done in this Å¿ort. FirÅ¿t, let the Mother be placed,
and held after the Å¿ame order we preÅ¿cribed for the helping of them, that are troubled with a great Flux of bloud. Then the Chirurgion, hauing his hands annointed (as we Å¿aid before) Å¿hall put vp his right hand, being open, as gently as he can poÅ¿Å¿ibly,How to find which way the childs head leaneth. to find on which Å¿ide the head doth leane, and is turn'd: if the childs head lean vpon his breaÅ¿t, his hand will meet firÅ¿t with the backe; if it be turned toward the backe, then he Å¿hall light vpon the breaÅ¿t: or if the head leane vpon one of the Å¿houlders, then he Å¿hall find the other firÅ¿t, which will alÅ¿o be inclining Å¿omewhat toward the womans flancks; which when he hath found, before he go about to remoue the head, and bring it into his naturall Å¿ituation, which is to place it directly ouer againÅ¿t the necke of the Matrice, he muÅ¿t firÅ¿t with the ends of his fingers, thruÅ¿t vpward the bodie of the child, either by the Å¿houlders, or backe, or by the breaÅ¿t: for by this meanes the head of the child, will not leane Å¿o hard againÅ¿t the Å¿ides of the wombe:Way to bring the head Å¿traight. Å¿o that his necke will euen come of it Å¿elfe to the right place. And for the better help, the Chirurgion at the Å¿ame inÅ¿tant Å¿hal Å¿lide in his other hand, (yet not taking out the former) wherewith finding the place where the head doth reÅ¿t, and leane: he may eaÅ¿ily draw his hand towards the Å¿ide of the childs head, and Å¿o Å¿hall he bring it gently to the naturall place: and by this meanes, the childs head will reÅ¿t betweene his hands, to be Å¿et right. The like alÅ¿o may he do, by putting his hand gently, toward the hinder part of
the head, and Å¿o Å¿et it right, hauing firÅ¿t thruÅ¿t the child vpward, either by the backe, or breaÅ¿t: the which is Å¿eldome done,Another way. becauÅ¿e it is a Å¿urer and readier way, to thruÅ¿t him vp by the Å¿houlders: and to Å¿ay the truth, the childs head is oftner turned, toward the Mothers flancks, then either toward her belly, or her backe.

div.head: The meanes to help a Woman in trauaile, when the child comes with the hand and arme together, with the head formoÅ¿t. CHAP. XVI.
div.p:
THe child Å¿hould come into the world, with his head forward, and if there be any thing that comes with it, it is contrarie to nature. If the hand, and arme, offer themÅ¿elues, and come foorth of the wombe, this trauaile is contrarie to nature, and therefore dangerous: becauÅ¿e the arme takes vp the roome,The hand comming foorth, hinders the deliuerie. the head Å¿hould haue, & hinders it from comming right; according as it is turned, either to the right Å¿ide, or to the left; or elÅ¿e vpward; the head leaning vpon the backe: or downward, being placed vpon the breaÅ¿t: (as we Å¿hew'd in the laÅ¿t Chapter, when the necke Å¿tands awrie,) which vnleÅ¿Å¿e it be help'd in time, it will be verie hard for him to come Å¿afe into the world. For the hand, and arme, comming foorth, by reaÅ¿on of their tenderneÅ¿Å¿e, and Å¿oftneÅ¿Å¿e, being neuer Å¿o little cruÅ¿h'd, or held in the ayre:
they are quickly alter'd, and Å¿poil'd, and will be Å¿wolne, and puft vp exceedingly: yea, and Å¿ometime fall into a Gangrene,The arme comming foorth, fals into a Gangrene. which I haue often Å¿een come to paÅ¿Å¿e: and therefore it will be verie neceÅ¿Å¿arie to redreÅ¿Å¿e it Å¿peedily.

But eÅ¿pecially, the Chirurgion muÅ¿t take heed of pulling the Å¿aid hand, or arme; becauÅ¿e it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible,Inconuenience of drawing the child by the arme. he Å¿hould draw him out thereby: For how much the more the arme is thruÅ¿t, whether it be by the Mothers, or the childs Å¿triuing, or elÅ¿e by the Chirurgion, who labours to pull it out: Å¿o much the more will it make the head and necke to bow, and bend; either toward the Å¿tomacke, backe, or Å¿ides: it being impoÅ¿Å¿ible that the head and arme Å¿hould come foorth both together, becauÅ¿e the Å¿aid head is Å¿o infolded, and ingaged, in one of the Å¿aid places: and therefore this order muÅ¿t be obÅ¿erued heerein.

The practize.FirÅ¿t, the Mother muÅ¿t be laid vpon her backe, her head and necke lying Å¿omewhat low, and her hips Å¿omewhat raiÅ¿ed: then the Chirurgion, hauing his hands oil'd (as before) Å¿hall annoint, all the womans parts with that hand, which is moÅ¿t fit, according to the diners Å¿ituation of the child. If the hand onely come foorth, he Å¿hall take it, at the top of the wriÅ¿t, and Å¿o thruÅ¿t it backe, as high as he can, guiding it all along the Å¿ides and flancks of the child: and hauing plac'd it there, he muÅ¿t pull backe his hand to giue place to the childs head, which at the Å¿ame inÅ¿tant, with his other hand, muÅ¿t be brought and put, right againÅ¿t the necke
of the wombe: And the better to Å¿et it aright, he muÅ¿t with both his hands being Å¿pred abroad, and placed on each Å¿ide the head, thruÅ¿t the Å¿houldert vpward, with the ends of his fingers, (as we Å¿hew'd in the former Chapter) that the childs head may be Å¿et in the mid'Å¿t: which will be eaÅ¿ie for him to do, in taking the childs temples of his head, betweene both his hands, and by that meanes Å¿et it Å¿traight. And when this is done,The woman muÅ¿t be hartned. let him Å¿uffer the woman to reÅ¿t her Å¿elfe a little, aÅ¿Å¿uring her, that her child is well plac'd, and that by and by, he will come naturally into the world: The reÅ¿t Å¿hall be performed, as we haue Å¿hew'd in the naturall Deliuerie; placing the woman after the Å¿ame order, as hath been Å¿aid. But if it chance, that the child be dead, and that the arme be gangren'd, and Å¿o Å¿wolne, that it cannot be put backe, then muÅ¿t it be help'd in the Å¿ame manner as we haue Å¿hewed before, which ought to be done with all Å¿peed: for feare of the putrifaction, that may happen vnto it.

div.head: The meanes to help the trauaile, wherein the Child comes with both his hands, armes, and head formoÅ¿t. CHAP. XVII.
div.p:
MAny men are of opinion,Comparing of the two Å¿orts of deliueries. that the trauaile wherein the child puts formoÅ¿t both his hands, and armes, is not Å¿o dangerous, and difficult, as the former, when there is but one: BecauÅ¿e
cauÅ¿e when both the armes come, thus Å¿tretched out, the head is found iuÅ¿t in the mid'Å¿t of the paÅ¿Å¿age. depiction of child in womb But Å¿ince that both armes muÅ¿t be put backe againe, as in the former, before the child can come into the world, (it being verie hard, and dangerous to draw him foorth by the armes) it hath made me alwaies thinke, that this kind of deliuerie is more troubleÅ¿ome and dangerous, then the former.

The deliuery where both armes come formoÅ¿t is not Å¿o dangerous.NotwithÅ¿tanding this may bee Å¿aid to bee leÅ¿Å¿e dangerous for the child, becauÅ¿e howÅ¿oeuer hee Å¿triue to come forth, and for all the throws that the Woman can haue, yet the child cannot wreath or turne his necke aÅ¿ide. But yet to Å¿ay the truth, it is
more troubleÅ¿ome, both for the Mother, and the Chirurgion, yea; and Å¿ometimes for the childe alÅ¿o.

But the beÅ¿t way to proceed heerein is,The practiÅ¿e. that the Chirurgion, after he hath placed the woman (as is aforeÅ¿aid) hauing his hands annointed, as alÅ¿o the parts of the Woman, he Å¿hall gently put in his right hand, and bring one of the childs armes to his due place, by Å¿tretching it out at length, along by the flankes and thighs; and preÅ¿ently with drawing that hand, he Å¿hall thruÅ¿t in his left, to bring the other arme into his place, as he did the former. This being done, he Å¿hall marke, whether the head of the child be placed right, in the meane time Å¿uffering the woman to take Å¿ome eaÅ¿e, not holding her Å¿o much backe, as when hee placed the armes of the child. Then Å¿hall he place her, as in a naturall birth, but if hee find that the head of the child be turned aÅ¿ide, and be not Å¿et direct againÅ¿t the paÅ¿Å¿age, as it vÅ¿eth to be in a naturall birth, then Å¿hall he gently put in both his hands ioyned together, and preÅ¿ently opening them, he Å¿hall touch onely with the ends of his fingers, both the Å¿houlders of the child, and put him backe eaÅ¿ily toward the bottom of the Matrice: and beeing Å¿o put backe, the head of the child will come betweene his hands, which he Å¿hal eaÅ¿ily place aright againÅ¿t the paÅ¿Å¿age (as is aforeÅ¿aid) by taking both Å¿ides of his head, or temples betweene his hands, and Å¿o the deliuery Å¿hall be performed naturally.

div.head: The meanes to helpe the mother when the child comes with one, or both feete formost. CHAP. XVIII.
div.p:
WHenÅ¿oeuer the child, comming into the World, doth put one or both his feete formoÅ¿t, the Chirurgion Å¿hall place the Woman (as it hath beene oftentimes told,) & hauing his hands annointed, let him chuÅ¿e whether he will draw the child forth by the feete: or elÅ¿e if he thinke it better, to put backe either one or both the feete, and Å¿o turne him, and bring his head Å¿traight to his paÅ¿Å¿age. For my part, I thinke it the better & Å¿afer way to draw him foorth by the feete, then to turne him vpÅ¿ide downe, and lift his feete vpward, thereby to bring his head downward to the paÅ¿Å¿age. And therfore,What muÅ¿t be obÅ¿erued concerning the child. whether he come with one, or both his feete forward, the greateÅ¿t care muÅ¿t be to know how his whole body is placed, & lyes in his Mothers womb: as whether his face and belly be turned toward the mothers backe, and his Å¿houlders, backe, and buttocks towards her Nauell: likewiÅ¿e whether his armes bee Å¿eparated from his thighs, flankes, and Å¿ides, which ought alÅ¿o to be diligently obÅ¿erued in all births that are contrary to Nature, eÅ¿pecially, in thoÅ¿e, when the child is drawne forth by the feete: For when you draw him out of the wombe,
with his buttockes, backe, and hinder parts of the head, turned toward the backe of the Mother, and his face toward her Nauell, and belly, then without doubt the feet, buttocks, body and Å¿houlders, of the child being drawn forth, when the head commeth to the os pubis, it will hang therein: which beeing Å¿o catched it will be very hard, nay impoÅ¿Å¿ible, to draw forth the child: and if you draw him too violently, it is to be feared leaÅ¿t you breake his necke, eÅ¿pecially if the child be too big, or his head great. Therefore when you haue drawne him by the feete till he is come forth, as farre as the buttocks, and waÅ¿t, before you draw him any further, you muÅ¿t marke diligently the poÅ¿ition of the body, whether the belly breÅ¿t, and face, be vpward, or no. For if he be Å¿o placed, before you draw him any further, you muÅ¿t turne him vpÅ¿ide downe, which you Å¿hall performe, if you hold him faÅ¿t by the buttockes, and hips, with both your hands, and turn the whole body (withall drawing it gently) and Å¿o bring the belly, breaÅ¿t, and face downeward, which being done, you Å¿hall draw him forth with eaÅ¿e, without daunger of Å¿taying, or carrying the head vpon os pubis: which muÅ¿t needs happen, if the child were drawne with the face vpwards. And this haue I well obÅ¿erued, being called to the deliuery of Å¿ome women, where this chance, (for want of good heed taking) hath happened, the head Å¿ticking within, and putting vs to great trouble, to draw it foorth. BeÅ¿ide,An obÅ¿eruation when the two arms are Å¿tretched out. when the body is thus Å¿ituated, if both the armes be Å¿tretched out aboue the head, you Å¿hall bring
downe one of them cloÅ¿e to the Å¿ide, and let the other Å¿tay Å¿tretched out, that when the Å¿houlders, are come foorth, the Å¿aid arme may be as it were a Å¿tay, or Å¿plint to the necke, for the paÅ¿Å¿age of the head, to hinder the paÅ¿Å¿age from Å¿hutting or cloÅ¿ing vp, and faÅ¿tning about the necke of the child, and Å¿o hinder che child from comming foorth, notwithÅ¿tanding oftentimes, the child is Å¿o Å¿lender and little, that Å¿o Å¿oone as the Å¿houlders are come out preÅ¿ently the head follows after, and needeth not, the helpe of an arme, to bee a reÅ¿t for the necke.

Now the Chirurgion when hee hath thus obÅ¿erued, and marked the Å¿ituation of the child, or elÅ¿e hauing after that manner put him backe if he find the child may be eaÅ¿ily turned by lifting his feet vpwards, and bringing his head downeward, he may gently make triall of it.The Å¿afeÅ¿t way is to draw the child forth by the feet. But if he find that there is any difficulty therein, then the beÅ¿t and Å¿ureÅ¿t way is to draw him forth by the feete. Therfore, if but one of his feet come forth, he Å¿hall tye a ribband about it, that if it be needfull, to put it backe againe, to Å¿earch for the other, he may the Å¿ooner find it, and draw it forth. For it were enough to teare the child aÅ¿under, and Å¿o kill both him and his mother, to draw him forth by one foote. Therefore, whether the firÅ¿t foote hang out, or whether it be Å¿omwhat put backe againe, let it Å¿erue for a guide to find the other, the Chirurgion putting his hand all along

the Å¿aid leg and thigh euen to the Perinaeum, How to find the childs feet neere the which hee Å¿hall be Å¿ure to find the other thigh, and afterward the leg and foote, (vnleÅ¿Å¿e you meet with them firÅ¿t, as commonly it fals out). But the Å¿ureÅ¿t way is to do it the firÅ¿t way (that is to find the thigh firÅ¿t) becauÅ¿e oftentimes there are two children, which if it Å¿hould Å¿o happen then might you
depiction of child in womb: breech birth
take one foote of the one, and another foote of the other: and thinking, that they were the feete of one child onely, without doubt in drawing them foorth after that manner, you would kill them both, and put the mother likewiÅ¿e in great danger of death, becauÅ¿e it would be impoÅ¿Å¿ible to draw them forth both together. And you muÅ¿t obÅ¿erue, that to draw a child well out of his Mothers wombe, you muÅ¿t haue a Napkin, or Å¿ome other linnen cloth, that you may not hold the child naked,You muÅ¿t not hold the child naked. either by the feete, thighs, or other part of the body: but let it be with a warme cloth, for your hands beeing annointed, and greaÅ¿ie, and the child being alÅ¿o moiÅ¿t, hee will eaÅ¿ily Å¿lip from betweene your hands, and you Å¿hall
not take Å¿o Å¿trong hold as is fit, for to bring him foorth. And yet it may happen,An ObÅ¿eruation. that the inner neck of the Matrice, may not be Å¿o wide, as to giue way to the Chirurgions, or Midwiues hand, without great difficulty and paine: the paÅ¿Å¿age beeing not bigger then to admit two or three fingers, by which neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e, it is found in what manner the child commeth. If you obÅ¿erue that one foote or both come formoÅ¿t, you muÅ¿t proceed according to this example.

Being at Moret with Count Charles, I was called,A Å¿tory. together with the late Mons: de la Corde, one of the Kings PhiÅ¿itions, to deliuer a poore woman, which had beene in trauaile two daies and two nights: the waters beeing broken, and the child left dry, the necke of her Matrice was cloÅ¿ed, Å¿he being no more vrged with paines or throwes, which I obÅ¿erued by Å¿lipping vp my hand, vnto the Å¿aid necke, and getting two of my fingers therein, where feeling one of the childs feete, I perÅ¿waded my Å¿elfe that I Å¿hould deliuer her well, which I did in this Å¿ort.

FirÅ¿t, when I had placed her well, I annointed my hands with butter and hogs greaÅ¿e melted together, and with Å¿tore thereof, I annointed the inward necke of the Matrice, as well as poÅ¿Å¿ibly I could: and when I had Å¿omewhat dilated the Å¿aide necke, with three of my fingers I caÅ¿t a ryband with a Å¿liding knot, vppon the childs foote, faÅ¿tning it gently: and then dilating againe the Å¿aid necke, I found out the other foote, vpon which I Å¿lipped another riband, as I had done vpon the former: Then
did I draw both the ribands, and brought the two feete together, which when I had drawne out, vnto the buttocks, I began againe to annoint, as before, then taking a napkin, leÅ¿t it Å¿hould Å¿lip, I bad the woman force her Å¿elfe, as much as Å¿hee could poÅ¿Å¿ibly, eÅ¿pecially when Å¿hee felt her paines and throws comming: and then drawing Å¿ometimes directly, and Å¿ometimes to the one Å¿ide, Å¿o to enlarge the paÅ¿Å¿age, I drew on the child gently turning the belly thereof downward; that the chin might not catch in the ospubis, as I haue noted before.

Sometimes the child comes not with his feet but
depiction of child in womb: breech birth
with his knees forward, and in this caÅ¿e, the Chirurgion Å¿hall vÅ¿e the Å¿ame art, as before, conÅ¿idering
firÅ¿t, whether it be fitter to bring the childs head formoÅ¿t, or to draw him out by the feet. If he will draw him out by the feet, he Å¿hall bring him into the foreÅ¿aid Å¿ituation, that is, to let the face of the child be turn'd toward the Mothers backe, and his backe, toward her Nauell: then Å¿hall he vnfold, or vnlooÅ¿e the legs, that were bow'd and bent; and Å¿hall draw them foorth firÅ¿t, and then the reÅ¿t of the bodie, in this Å¿ort.How to draw him foorth. He Å¿hall Å¿lide his hand from the knee of the child, along the Å¿hine, till he come to the foote, which he Å¿hall draw foorth, and tye a Å¿mall ryband about it, and put that foot in againe, letting the ryband hang out: The like Å¿hall he doe to the other foot, and Å¿o Å¿hall he eaÅ¿ily draw out the two feet. Then let him draw foorth the thighs, and buttockes, and if the child lie with his belly, breaÅ¿t, and face downward, and his buttockes, backe, and Å¿houlders vpward; let him inÅ¿tantly, draw gently out the reÅ¿t of the child, (as we haue Å¿aid before.) But if he be placed contrariwiÅ¿e,The child muÅ¿t be turned. he muÅ¿t turne him gently, the face downward, leaÅ¿t otherwiÅ¿e the head take hold vpon the Ospubis, by the chin, as we haue Å¿aid before.

I haue often repeated, this faÅ¿hion of drawing out the child, for feare leaÅ¿t the young Chirurgion erre, in performing it otherwiÅ¿e; which if he Å¿hould doe, he will be much troubled in drawing out the head, which may Å¿ticke by the way, as I haue Å¿een it happen.

div.head: The meanes how to help a Woman, when her child commeth, with both the feet, and both the hands together. CHAP. XIX.

figure.figDesc: depiction of child in womb: transverse presentation

div.p:
THe child comming into the world, may offer himÅ¿elfe to the necke of the Matrice, in diuers
faÅ¿hions: as (beÅ¿ide thoÅ¿e that haue been Å¿poken of,) with both the feet and hands formoÅ¿t; the buttocks, backe, and head of the child, being Å¿o bent, and bow'd againÅ¿t the bottome of the Matrice, which doth preÅ¿Å¿e, and thruÅ¿t him downward, that the Å¿aid hands and feet,A terrible kind of deliuerie. come foorth with Å¿uch violence, that it is a fearefull thing to Å¿ee, and full of danger, becauÅ¿e of the difficultie to remedie it; the Matrice bearing downe it Å¿elfe in Å¿uch Å¿ort, and to no vÅ¿e; it being impoÅ¿Å¿ible, that the child Å¿hould be borne, whil'Å¿t he is thus Å¿ituated. And therefore it will be neceÅ¿Å¿arie in this caÅ¿e, to giue help with as much Å¿peed, as may be: The practize whereof is in this manner.

FirÅ¿t, you Å¿hall place the woman as we haue Å¿aid before,Meanes to helpe the trauaile. then the Chirurgion hauing his hands annointed, as is required: if the child be aliue, he Å¿hall trie firÅ¿t with his right hand to put the feet into the Matrice, making them Å¿lip vp, as eaÅ¿ily as he can to the bottome of the Å¿aid Matrice, and with his left hand, Å¿hall he Å¿tay the hands that they come not foorth further: the feet being thus thruÅ¿t backe, preÅ¿ently, he Å¿hall either put one of his fingers, into the childs mouth, or elÅ¿e take him by the hinder part of the head, to bring it direct againÅ¿t the paÅ¿Å¿age: in the meane time putting backe with his left hand, the childs hands and armes, that they may fall cloÅ¿e to his Å¿ides: then taking the head between the palmes of his hands, he Å¿hall place it iuÅ¿t againÅ¿t the paÅ¿Å¿age. Which being done, the birth will Å¿ucceed naturally, both by the help and Å¿triuing of
the child, and alÅ¿o by the indeuour of the Mother, when Å¿he feeles her throwes come vpon her.

A Å¿urer way to draw forth the child.But when the Chirurgion Å¿hall find, that the feet, legs, and hands, cannot be put backe, and that the Matrice doth beare downeward, and Å¿hut it Å¿elfe not Å¿uffering the feet to Å¿lip vp, then muÅ¿t he, with all the Art he can, put back with his left hand, the childs hands, and with his right hand draw the feete gently, taking heede that the childs face and belly may bee downeward, and Å¿o draw out the child, as hath beene Å¿hewed before.

LikewiÅ¿e if the Chirurgion find that the child be dead, he muÅ¿t draw him forth by the feete, without troubling himÅ¿elfe to bring the head of the child, to the paÅ¿Å¿age. For euery dead child, becauÅ¿e he is not able to giue any helpe to the birth, but that all the labour is to come from the Mother, is oftentimes the cauÅ¿e of her death. And therfore the Å¿ureÅ¿t way is to turne him Å¿o, that he may be drawn but by the feete, or elÅ¿e with the Crochet.

The Authors opinion.As for my Å¿elfe, I am of this opinion, that it is better, whether the child be dead or aliue, (if he come with his feete, and hands formoÅ¿t) that the Chirurgion bring him foorth by the feete, then to turne him, and bring his head formoÅ¿t, and Å¿o expect a naturall birth: for in this Å¿triuing, the Mother hauing been much wearied, and the chid much weakned, the deliuerie (though it be naturall) will proue verie long, and difficult, in regard that neither the Mother, nor the child, can haue much Å¿trength left them: Whereas if you draw him foorth by the
feet, neither the Mother, nor the child being much weakned, the birth will be more eaÅ¿ie, and fortunate; As I haue alwaies had experience.

div.head: The meanes how to helpe a Woman, when her child comes double, putting formoÅ¿t, either the Sides, or the Backe, and Shoulders, or elÅ¿e the Buttockes. CHAP. XX.

figure.figDesc: depiction of child in womb: transverse presentation

div.p:
BEÅ¿ide the former deliuerie, which is, when the child comes double, putting his hands and feet formoÅ¿t: there likewiÅ¿e happen diuers other births that are no leÅ¿Å¿e difficult, and
dangerous: For when he comes Å¿ide-long, with his Sides, Backe, or Shoulders next the paÅ¿Å¿age, his feet muÅ¿t needs be on the one Å¿ide of the Matrice, and his head on the other, lying quite croÅ¿Å¿e; Å¿o that the child, beating on both Å¿ides, with his head and feet againÅ¿t the wombe, doth extend, and Å¿tretch it to no purpoÅ¿e, wherby the Mother growes weake and faint: which neither Å¿he, nor the child can long indure without danger of death; becauÅ¿e his Å¿triuing helps not at all for his comming foorth.

figure.figDesc: depiction of child in womb: transverse presentation

div.p:
A dangerous Å¿ituation.The like may happen, when the child puts out his thighs, and buttocks formoÅ¿t: which kind of birth is verie painefull and difficult, becauÅ¿e the child
fils all the Matrice: Which the Chirurgion perceiuing, he Å¿hall conÅ¿ider, whether it be better, to turne the child, and bring formoÅ¿t his head, or elÅ¿e his feet: if he can eaÅ¿ily bring the childs head vnto the paÅ¿Å¿age, he Å¿hall proceed in this Å¿ort.

FirÅ¿t, he Å¿hall put in his right hand (being annointed as before) to turne the child, and hauing found the Å¿houlder, with the palme of his Å¿aid hand, he Å¿hall lift the child vpward, that his feet or knees may be toward the bottome of the Matrice, whil'Å¿t the head fals and Å¿lides downward: and Å¿hall hold it faÅ¿t at the orifice of the wombe, with his left hand, being put in at the Å¿ame inÅ¿tant; and by this meanes Å¿hall bring the Armes cloÅ¿e to the thighs, and Å¿ides of the child that the Woman may be naturally deliuered. But if the Chirurgion finde any difficulty, to lift the body vpward, for the bringing of the head downward: then Å¿hall he Å¿lide his right hand vnder the childs armepit, and Å¿o draw him gently, yet not making the arme come foorth, to place the head right againÅ¿t the paÅ¿Å¿age.

But if the Chirurgion find any hindrance in bringing the head downeward, and that hee thinkes he can more eaÅ¿ily guide and bring the feete to the orifice of the wombe, then the beÅ¿t and Å¿ureÅ¿t way is to draw him foorth in that Å¿ort, by the feete: and certainly when the child comes with his buttocks formoÅ¿t, his head being vpward, then may you Å¿ooner meete with his feete, and bring them eaÅ¿ier to the orifice of the Matrice, to bee drawne foorth as wee haue Å¿hewed before. But when hee puts his
Å¿houlder or backe formoÅ¿t, then may you the more eaÅ¿ily lift him vp to make his head Å¿lip downeward, or elÅ¿e take him by the Armepit, and Å¿o bring gently his head to the necke of the wombe, to deliuer him naturally.

div.head: The manner of helping the deliuery, wherein the child comes with his belly and breaÅ¿t formoÅ¿t. CHAP. XXI.
div.p:
THe moÅ¿t troubleÅ¿ome, and painfull Å¿ituation of a childe in his mothers wombe, is when he comes with his belly formoÅ¿t, putting out his nauell, his legges and armes being turned backwards. For when hee is placed in this manner, and Å¿triues to come foorth, hee thruÅ¿ts againÅ¿t the Å¿ides of the Wombe with his hands and feet, and Å¿o boweth backward, and bends the backe bone that hee brings himÅ¿elfe as it were into a circle, whereby hee endur's and Å¿uffers much paine, and likewiÅ¿e is weakned exceeding much, vnleÅ¿Å¿e hee be Å¿peedily helpt: and beÅ¿ides, by his compreÅ¿Å¿ion and Å¿triuing, hee cauÅ¿eth the Mother to endure much paine, and anguiÅ¿h without any profite at all both which doth require to be Å¿peedily redreÅ¿Å¿ed, which maybe performed in this Å¿ort. FirÅ¿t the ChirurgioÌ
depiction of child in womb: transverse presentation
Å¿hal place the woman in good order (as hath beene Å¿aid)Meanes to help the child. and then Å¿hall he Å¿lide vp his right hand (beeing firÅ¿t annointed) to obÅ¿erue and feele what part of the childs body is neereÅ¿t, which hee Å¿hall perceiue both by his feeling, and by wagging and Å¿tirring the child vp and downe: If the breaÅ¿t be
next, he Å¿hall take with the Å¿aid hand) the child by he Å¿houlders and top of the Arme, bringing him thereby gently downeward, afterward lifting vp his hand, that the childs head may fall right towards the paÅ¿Å¿age, putting in preÅ¿ently his left hand to receiue and Å¿et Å¿traight the childs head, which may be turned on the one Å¿ide, and that being done, the deliuery Å¿hall bee afterwards performed Naturally.

Another conÅ¿ideration.But if the head cannot be eaÅ¿ily brought downward, or that the belly and top of the thigh be neerer vnto the paÅ¿Å¿age, then the Chirurgion Å¿hall put his right hand along the childs thigh to find one of his feete, which being found, hee Å¿hall caÅ¿t about it a riband, with a Å¿liding knot, and then Å¿hall he Å¿eeke for the other, and bring them both gently to the paÅ¿Å¿age, and Å¿o draw him forth by the feete, taking hold of him with a warm napkin, between both his hands: obÅ¿eruing alwaies that his face and belly be downewards; for feare leaÅ¿t when the Å¿houlders are come forth, the chinne catch vpon the os pubis, as we haue Å¿hewne more at large, in the chapter of deliuering the childe with the feete formoÅ¿t, to which place I referre you, Å¿hunning often repetition.

div.head: The meanes to help the birth, when there be twins the one comming with his feete, the other with his head formoÅ¿t. CHAP. XXII.
div.p:
IT cannot well bee perceiued alwaies, whether a woman beares two children, though Å¿he be in
trauaile: for I my Å¿elfe was preÅ¿ent not long Å¿ince, at the deliuery of an honeÅ¿t woman,One may bee Å¿afely deliuered of two children. who brought two children: and when Å¿he was deliuered of the firÅ¿t, the Midwife (not expecting that there was a Å¿econd) was ready to draw out the after burthen, but that I perceiued another offer it Å¿elfe at the paÅ¿Å¿age, which as it came naturally, Å¿o was Å¿hee deliuered thereof very fortunately. But if it Å¿o fall out that the twins do come, the one with his head, the other with his heeles formoÅ¿t, then the Chirurgion Å¿hall behaue himÅ¿elfe in this Å¿ort.

How he muÅ¿t deliuer the woman when the twins come ill.FirÅ¿t he Å¿hall conÅ¿ider, which of the two children the woman may be eaÅ¿ieÅ¿t deliuered of. If the head of the one come not Å¿o forward, as the feete of the other: it will be eaÅ¿ie to draw foorth that child by the feete, putting the others head a little aÅ¿ide, and when he hath brought that foorth, he muÅ¿t preÅ¿ently Å¿et the head of the other right againÅ¿t the paÅ¿Å¿age, and incourage the woman to bee deliuered, which will the eaÅ¿ier bee done, becauÅ¿e the other hath prepared the way.

And if it happen, that in deliuering the firÅ¿t by the feete, the Å¿econd Å¿hould change his Å¿ituation; then the Chirurgion Å¿hall looke after the feet, and draw him foorth, as he did, the former. And when the head of the firÅ¿t, is very forward: then Å¿hall hee thruÅ¿t backe the feete of the Å¿econd, to giue way to the others head, that he may come naturally.

div.head: The meanes to help a Woman in trauaile of Twins, their feete comming formoÅ¿t. CHAP. XXIII.
div.p: AS two twins may chance to offer themÅ¿elues with their heads, Å¿o likewiÅ¿e Å¿ometimes they may happpen to come with their feete formoÅ¿t.

When this chaunceth, the Chirurgion ought to obÅ¿erue, whether the twins be Å¿eparated, (as wee Å¿aid before) or whether they be vnnaturall, as hauing
foure legs, one or two bodies, and likewiÅ¿e one or two heads. Now the beÅ¿t way to find it is, that the Chirurgion hauing his hand annointed (as before) Å¿lip it vp gently wide open,Meanes to know whether the child be a monÅ¿ter or no. as high as he can, and finding that the twins are not ioyned together, but diuided and diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed, he Å¿hall bring down his hand betweene one of their thighs, and pulling it a little lower, Å¿hall take hold of one of the twins feet, (that which he thinks may bee eaÅ¿ieÅ¿t drawne foorth) and tye about it a riband, with a Å¿liding knot, towards the Ankle: then Å¿hall he put his hand along the Å¿aid legge, and Å¿o euen to the buttockes that thereby hee may find the other legge of the Å¿ame child, and ioyne them together, and not bee miÅ¿taken (taking one legge of the one twinne, and another of the other: For if he Å¿hould doe Å¿o, then without doubt in drawing of them forth, he would teare them both aÅ¿under:) but beeing certaine by this meanes, that both the legges and feete, bee of the Å¿ame child, you may draw them foorth gently, (as wee haue Å¿hewed before) taking care that the childe come with his face downeward.WheÌ the firÅ¿t is come hee muÅ¿t be taken away. When you haue thus drawne foorth the firÅ¿t, you Å¿hall in the Å¿ame manner, proceed to the Å¿econd: hauing firÅ¿t taken away (as is Å¿aide before) the other, from betweene the mothers legges. And if it happen that one of the twins come naturally, with his head formoÅ¿t, and the other with his feete: and that his feet are more forward then the others head: then the Å¿afeÅ¿t way will be to draw him foorth firÅ¿t, that hath his feete formoÅ¿t: hauing firÅ¿t of all put the other aÅ¿ide
that offered himÅ¿elfe at the paÅ¿Å¿age. But if the head of the one be right againÅ¿t the paÅ¿Å¿age and the feet of the other on the one Å¿ide, then Å¿hall hee put backe the feete gently, and deliuer the woman firÅ¿t of him that had his head formoÅ¿t, and afterwards draw the other foorth by the feete.

It may alÅ¿o happen in each of the former births,It muÅ¿t be knowen which is aliue. that one of the twins may be dead, and the other liuing. HowÅ¿oeuer they are placed, the Chirurgion muÅ¿t be very certaine which of them is dead, or aliue.The meanes to know it. Which hee Å¿hall know by feeling them about the Nauell, Temples, or region of the Heart, HandwriÅ¿ts, or Ankles, where if he find no pulÅ¿e, or beating of the Arteries, then he may be Å¿ure that the child is dead, as alÅ¿o if he be leÅ¿Å¿e hot then the other: and when you put your finger into his mouth, he neither Å¿ucke it, nor wag his tongue. But if you find all theÅ¿e Å¿ignes concurre,How you muÅ¿t draw him out. then there is Å¿ome likelyhood that he is aliue: and therefore it will be beÅ¿t to bring his head right againÅ¿t the paÅ¿Å¿age, that Å¿o the woman may be the Å¿ooner deliuer'd, which will be done the more eaÅ¿ily, becauÅ¿e the liue child can better help himÅ¿elfe, then he that is dead. But if the Chirurgion thinke, that he Å¿hall hardly bring the head to the Å¿aid paÅ¿Å¿age, and that he find the feet are neerer, and readier; then I would aduiÅ¿e him to bring the child foorth by the feet, and when the woman Å¿hall be deliuer'd of th'one, let him draw foorth th'other in the Å¿ame faÅ¿hion.

div.head: Of the Å¿taying of the after-burthen, after the deliuerie. CHAP. XXIIII.
div.p: OFtentimes it happens, after the woman hath been deliuer'd, whether it be naturally, or by the Chirurgions helpe: that the bed whereupon the child lay, (commonly called the After-burthen) as being a Å¿econd burthen,The After-burthen may be Å¿top't. or deliuerie of the woman; becauÅ¿e, when that is come away, the Mother is wholy deliuer'd, doth remaine faÅ¿tned to the Å¿ides of the wombe, and cannot verie eaÅ¿ily be Å¿eperated from it, and though it be looÅ¿ened, yet oftentimes it cannot be put foorth: The which may proceed, either from the dryneÅ¿Å¿e of the Matrice, and after-burthen,CauÅ¿es of the retention of the after-burthen. being deÅ¿titute of their moiÅ¿ture, or becauÅ¿e, that it is Å¿wolne, and Å¿tretch'd, or elÅ¿e becauÅ¿e the expulÅ¿iue facultie of the wombe, hath been much weakned by a long and painfull trauaile: Whereunto may be added, that oftentimes the Mother hath been Å¿o wearied, and brought Å¿o low, and become Å¿o faint, weake, and feeble, that Å¿he is not able to Å¿traine, or force her Å¿elfe at all.

Now it is moÅ¿t certaine, that after the child hath left his Mothers wombe, the Å¿aid after-birth is a thing contrarie to nature, which muÅ¿t needs be taken away and Å¿ent foorth: And therefore one of theÅ¿e two accidents muÅ¿t needs follow, either that
the quicke (which is the wombe) thruÅ¿t foorth the dead, (which is the after-birth:) or that the dead kill the quicke: And Å¿urely, that being retayned, it doth breed in the Mother, moÅ¿t pernicious, and dangerous Symptomes, as Å¿wounnings, oppreÅ¿Å¿ion, and Å¿uffocation: yea, and Å¿ometimes being corrupted and putrified, it is an occaÅ¿ion of death.

For the preuenting whereof, there muÅ¿t be great care and diligence vÅ¿ed in the bringing and drawing of it foorth: which muÅ¿t not be done raÅ¿hly, but leaÅ¿urely, by often Å¿haking and mouing it. In the meane time, taking heed that neither the Mother, nor the wombe, take any cold, for feare leÅ¿t it be Å¿odainly clos'd and Å¿hut vp: and therefore, firÅ¿t of all, if the woman be weake, you Å¿hall giue her, either Å¿ome Broth, Gelly, yelke of an egge, or elÅ¿e a toÅ¿t and Å¿uger. And you muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e put in practize, that which we haue formerly Å¿poken of: as to make her Cough, Å¿neeze, and blow, in her hands holding Å¿alt therein: and beÅ¿ide you muÅ¿t giue her medicines, that are proper to expell and driue forth the Å¿aid after-bith; which are, Å¿uch as we formerly preÅ¿cribed, in Difficult trauaile: as

GeÅ¿ner in an EpiÅ¿tle he writes to GaÅ¿Å¿erus Å¿aith, That the Å¿tone of a horÅ¿e, dried in an Ouen, being made into powder, and taken the quantitie of a dragme, or foure Å¿cruples, is an excellent medicine.

div.head: THE PREFACE TO Ladies, wherein they are exhorted to nurÅ¿e their Children themÅ¿elues.
div.p: AVLVS Gellius (in my opinion) did not amiÅ¿Å¿e in putting no difference betweene a woman that refuÅ¿es to nurÅ¿e her owne childe; and one that kills her child, as Å¿oone as Å¿hee hath conceiued; that Å¿hee may not bee troubled with bearing it nine moneths in her wombe. For why may not a woman with as good reaÅ¿on, deny to nouriÅ¿h her child with her bloud, in her wombe, as to deny it her milke being borne? Å¿ince the milk is nothing elÅ¿e but bloud whitened, beeing now brought to perfection and maturity.

But Å¿ome will Å¿ay that the child may bee deliuered to Å¿ome other Woman, to nurÅ¿e it, and that the Mother may haue an eye and care ouer it: But (Gentle Ladies) here I deÅ¿ire you to conÅ¿ider with me the great inconueniences that may hence ariÅ¿e, which though they bee infinite, yet I will reduce them to foure heads.

list.item: 1. First there is danger leaÅ¿t the child be changed and an other put in his place.

2. Then that naturall affection which Å¿hould be betwixt
the mother and the child by this meanes is diminiÅ¿hed.
3. Thirdly, it may be feared, that Å¿ome bad conditions or inclinations may be deriued from the NurÅ¿e into the child.
4. And lastly, the NurÅ¿e may communicate Å¿ome imperfection of her body into the child.

div.p: 1. As for the firÅ¿t point, which is the changing of the child, that may eaÅ¿ily come to paÅ¿Å¿e; becauÅ¿e as Å¿oone as the child is borne, and ChriÅ¿tned, the Mother preÅ¿ently deliuers it to the NurÅ¿e, to bee carried into the Country: Where the child, being wholly left to the diÅ¿cretion of the NurÅ¿e, may by Å¿ome ill chance be Å¿tifled, ouer-laid, be let fall, and Å¿o come to an vntimely death: or elÅ¿e may be deuoured, Å¿poiled, or diÅ¿figured by Å¿ome wild beaÅ¿t, Wolfe, or Dogge, and then the NurÅ¿e fearing to be puniÅ¿hed for her negligence, may take another child into the place of it, which can hardly euer be marked and diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hed: And indeede when children grow Å¿omwhat big, and are brought home from NurÅ¿e, if they proue not like their parents in body, in conditions and wit, the Prouerbe goes, That they are chaunged at NurÅ¿e; Which Å¿ometimes may bee truer, then they are aware of.

The HiÅ¿toriographers report that Arthebar King of the Epirotes being old, had one only Å¿onne, whoÅ¿e nurÅ¿e was corrupted with great gifts to change him, and to take a Gentlemans Å¿onne into his place. But when the King was dead, the NurÅ¿e repenting her Å¿elfe of this wickedneÅ¿Å¿e, reuealed the error: wherupon enÅ¿ued Å¿uch terrible wars, betweene the lawfull and the Å¿uppoÅ¿ed Å¿on, that both of them loÅ¿t their liues, in a battaile. Vpon
this occaÅ¿ion, ThomiÅ¿tus the Å¿euenth King of the Lacedemonians leauing two Å¿onnes behind him, when he dyed; the Lacedemonians choÅ¿e the younger of them for their King, becauÅ¿e he had beene nurÅ¿ed by the Queene his Mother; and reiected the eldeÅ¿t, who had beene brought vp by a Å¿trange woman; fearing leaÅ¿t he had bene changed by his NurÅ¿e.

2. For the Å¿econd point which is naturall affection, without doubt that cannot bee Å¿o earneÅ¿t, either from the Mother toward the child, or from the chlld toward the Mother; if Å¿hee haue not nurÅ¿ed him and giuen him Å¿ucke. For if Å¿he nurÅ¿e him, he Å¿ucks and draws her owne bloud. Whereupon grows a familiar inwardnes, and the child (when he comes to yeares of diÅ¿cretion) finds himÅ¿elfe bound to his Mother, for many benefits: both in that Å¿he hath borne him nine Moneths in her womb, and alÅ¿o becauÅ¿e Å¿hee hath nurÅ¿ed him, watched him, and often made him cleane. In recompence whereof, he endeuours to Å¿hew her a thouÅ¿and delights, to make her forget or take in good part, Å¿o much care and paines, as Å¿hee hath taken with him. Hee playes a number of apiÅ¿h trickes about her, he kiÅ¿Å¿eth her, Å¿trokes her haire, noÅ¿e, and eares: he flatters her, he counterfeits anger, and other paÅ¿sions, and as he groweth bigger, hee finds other Å¿ports with her, which cauÅ¿eth that they beare one another Å¿uch an affection, as cannot be expreÅ¿Å¿ed; & makes that they can neuer be parted: When hee is bigge, and comes to be weaned, if one chide his nurÅ¿e he cries, and Å¿tamps: and if one offers to take him out of his nurÅ¿es armes, he will flye in their faces, and if it were poÅ¿sible, he would euen pull out their heart: and all this proceeds from that inward affection of the child, to which no
loue can bee compared. And heereupon Plato iuÅ¿tly Å¿aid, That children would neuer loue their parents Å¿o well; but that their fathers doe often beare them in their armes, and the mothers giue them Å¿ucke at their owne breaÅ¿ts.

And heereof wee haue a memorable example in Cornelius Scipio, who when he had condemned ten of his moÅ¿t valiant Captaines to death, he would not heare his owne Brother Scipio Africanus intreating for them, and yet granted their pardon, to one that had bin his FoÅ¿ter-brother, and Å¿ucked the Å¿ame NurÅ¿e: which being obiected to him, by his owne Brother, Å¿aying; That they had been borne both of one Mother; He anÅ¿wer'd him, That his NurÅ¿e-Mother had deÅ¿erued better of him, than his owne Mother had done. One of the familie of the Gracchi, returning from the warre, met his owne Mother, and his NurÅ¿e together: but he addreÅ¿sing himÅ¿elfe, firÅ¿t to his NurÅ¿e, preÅ¿ented to her a Girdle of gold, and then to his Mother, a Iewell of of Å¿iluer: which Å¿he taking indig â¢ ely, and rebuking him with reproaches, he replyed: I know (Mother) that you bore me nine Moneths in your wombe, yet that was out of neceÅ¿sitie, becauÅ¿e you could do no otherwiÅ¿e; but when I was borne, then you forÅ¿oke me, and my NurÅ¿e-mother willingly intertain'd me, carried me three yeares in her armes, and nouriÅ¿h'd me with her owne bloud.

3. As for the maners and conditions of the child, there is no doubt to be made, but that they are better bred and faÅ¿hioned by the Mother, than by the NurÅ¿e. For first, it is deliuered by learned writers, that the Manners and conditions of the mind, do follow the
temperament of the bodie, and the temperament ariÅ¿eth out of the nouriÅ¿hment: Å¿o that commonly, Å¿uch as the humours are, Å¿uch proue the manners. Hence muÅ¿t we conclude, that the child that Å¿uckes a NurÅ¿e, that is vitious, and wicked; Å¿ucketh alÅ¿o from her, her faults and vices: And beÅ¿ide, when the child comes to vnderÅ¿tanding, and obÅ¿erues what the NurÅ¿e Å¿peakes and doth, he retaines that, Å¿aies it after her, and imitates her: and that which is imprinted from the infancie, will hardly, or neuer be rooted out. For this cauÅ¿e Plato warnes vs, not to Å¿peake, or Å¿hew any thing before a child, which is not decent, and honeÅ¿t: and AriÅ¿totle forbids, to let a child Å¿ee any wanton or laÅ¿ciuious picture. Then (to returne to our NurÅ¿e) we may be aÅ¿sured, that the Milke (wherewith the child is nouriÅ¿h'd two yeares together) hath as much power to make the children like the NurÅ¿es, both in bodie, and mind; as the Å¿eed of the Parents hath to make the children like them. For although the child be borne of honeÅ¿t Parents, neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e, the bad nurture of a wicked NurÅ¿e, will make the child vicious and wicked: For, (as the prouerbe is) Nurture preuailes more than Nature. This may be plainly obÅ¿erued in all things, that haue life: for a faire and flouriÅ¿hing tree, which hath been bred in a good and fat ground, if it be tranÅ¿planted into a barren ground, becomes a Å¿hrub, and beares no fruit, that is good, and taÅ¿tfull. LikewiÅ¿e, the graine that is Å¿owed in good ground, will beare a faire and odoriferous flower; but if it be caÅ¿t into bad ground, it will bring foorth a baÅ¿tard flower, without any good or pleaÅ¿ing Å¿mell. It is reported, that a certaine child, was nouriÅ¿h'd with the milke of
a Bitch: But he would riÅ¿e in the night and houle with other dogges. Plato going about to giue a reaÅ¿on, why Alcibiades was Å¿o hardy, although he were an Athenian (who naturally were milde and timerous) reÅ¿olues it thus: becauÅ¿e the Å¿aid Alcibiades had been nurÅ¿ed by a Lacedaemonian woman, which is a verie Å¿tout, and valiant Nation.

4. As for the imperfections of the bodie, which children may borrow from their NurÅ¿es, although they bee very many, yet conÅ¿ider only thoÅ¿e, which the corpulencie, and diÅ¿eaÅ¿es of the NurÅ¿e may bring them. Tacitus writeth, that the Germanes of all other people, are the biggeÅ¿t, and Å¿trongeÅ¿t of bodie; and the reaÅ¿on is, becauÅ¿e they are nurs'd by their Mothers, which are big of Å¿tature. And it is obÅ¿eru'd, that they which put foorth their children, to women of Å¿mall Å¿tature, haue them, neither Å¿o big, nor Å¿trong and able of bodie, as if they had brought them vp themÅ¿elues. If a young Lambe Å¿ucke a Goate, it is found by experience, that the wooll of it will be harder, then of other Å¿heepe, and he will prooue more fierce, and wild, then is naturall for his kind.

And to this purpoÅ¿e, Procopius relates a Å¿torie of Polopeia, the daughter of TheÅ¿eus, who being deliuer'd in Å¿ecret of a Å¿onne, and deÅ¿irous to conceal her immodeÅ¿tie, caus'd him to be caÅ¿t into a forrest, where he being found by a Sheep-heard, was brought vp and nouriÅ¿h'd with Goates milke, (from whence he tooke the name of AegiÅ¿tus) which made him Å¿o Å¿wift of foot, that eueryone did admire him for his nimbleneÅ¿Å¿e and quickneÅ¿Å¿e in running.

Now, concerning the diÅ¿eaÅ¿es of NurÅ¿es, you Å¿hall
find more of them, polluted and infected with the french Poxes, and other diÅ¿eaÅ¿es; than Å¿ound and healthfull. And I haue knowen NurÅ¿es giue little children the French Pockes, who afterwards lying with their owne parents, haue likewiÅ¿e infected them.
Now what a diÅ¿grace, and what a Å¿orrow & griefe of hart, this would be to a Mother, if Å¿uch a chance Å¿hould happen, I leaue vnto you (faire Ladies) to iudge.

And therefore euery Mother Å¿hould endeauour, by all meanes poÅ¿sible (if Å¿he be not Å¿ickly, or too tender) to nurÅ¿e her child her Å¿elfe; Å¿ince that nature hath beÅ¿tow'd two Paps vpon her, onely for that purpoÅ¿e.

There are no other Creatures, but giue Å¿ucke to their young ones, and if you do but onely make a Å¿hew, that you would take them from their dams, what a coyle and Å¿tir doe they make? If you carrie them away, they will run after you, and neuer leaue, till you haue let go your hold: deÅ¿iring rather to looÅ¿e their owne liues, than Å¿uffer their little ones to be carried away.

And therefore let Mothers neuer put foorth their children to nurÅ¿e (if they themÅ¿elues be Å¿ound and healthfull) for feare of being chang'd. So Å¿hall you be Å¿ure, to haue Children, which will honour and loue you, without Å¿etling their affections vpon a Å¿tranger: Then Å¿hall you not need to make any doubt, but that your Children will be vertuous, and honeÅ¿t; not being addicted to any vices, which they may take from their NurÅ¿es: and they Å¿hall not learne any diÅ¿honest, or vndecent Å¿peeches; nor heare any thing that Å¿hall be either laÅ¿ciuious, or vnbefitting: then Å¿hall you be Å¿ure, that your children will be healthfull, Å¿ince they haue been
nouriÅ¿h'd with good milke, and not fed with Apples, Peares, Sops, and Å¿uch like traÅ¿h, which is often giuen them, for want of milke. And by this meanes, you Å¿hall haue faire and goodly children, well brought vp, docile, vertuous, louing, Å¿trong, and luÅ¿ty, without any diÅ¿eaÅ¿es: Then Å¿hall you be accounted for Mothers indeed, and not Step-Mothers: and therefore neuer make your excuÅ¿es, that you cannot, nor are not able to endure the trouble, and paines; or that your Husbands will not Å¿uffer you to do Å¿o.

And to conclude, I would haue you imitate Blanche of CaÅ¿tile, Å¿ometimes Queene of France, who nurs'd the King St Lewes her Å¿onne her owne Å¿elfe; and on a time, as Å¿he was out of the way, her child being froward, a great Ladie of the Court gaue him Å¿ucke, to Å¿till him, and make him quiet: which comming to the Queenes eare, Å¿he preÅ¿ently tooke the child, and thruÅ¿t her finger Å¿o far downe into his throat, that Å¿he made him vomit vp all the milke, he had Å¿uckt of the Å¿aid Ladie, being very angry that any woman Å¿hould giue her child Å¿ucke, but her Å¿elfe.
