div.head: The Preface.
div.p: IT is recorded by auncient HiÅ¿tories,Metrop. Salisb. EpiÅ¿e. 36. Scolion ad Tertul. lib. 9. de Anim. that there haue beene Å¿ome Children, which haue made a noiÅ¿e, and caÅ¿t foorth cries being yet in their mothers belly: and for proofe heereof, they relate, that in the City of RaÅ¿cat, there was a child borne with two hornes, whoÅ¿e moanes, and lamentations were herad fourteene daies before his birth: But this is rather Prodigious then Naturall: as S. AuguÅ¿tine Å¿aith,Aug. lib. 3. de ciuit. Dei. cap. 31 For a childe naturally, neither laments nor cries, Å¿o long as he doth abide in his mothers wombe.

And I haue often obÅ¿erued, that a child neither cries, nor makes any noiÅ¿e, neither Å¿ighes, though he be halfe come foorth, what paine or anguiÅ¿h Å¿oeuer he Å¿uffers in the paÅ¿sing. But as Å¿oone as he is born, and Å¿ees the light (beÅ¿ide the alteration of the ayre, which he finds) euen very neceÅ¿sity, and his owne feeling, doe force and as it were wring from him cries and moanes, thereby to Å¿hew, in what need he Å¿tands of helpe. He craues and demands the Å¿uccour of his owne Mother to be nouriÅ¿ht and fed, otherwiÅ¿e hee would dye in a Å¿hort Å¿pace;Metaph. 10. Martij. Lipom. com. 7. except hee were a Å¿econd Codratus the Martyr, who was euen from his tender age depriued of all humane aide, and forÅ¿aken both of Father and mother, and all the world beÅ¿ide. But our Lord God did Å¿upply this want and cauÅ¿ed in recompence thereof that a round cloud, comming downe from heauen, did encompaÅ¿Å¿e him about, and nouriÅ¿h him.

div.head: OF A NVRSE, AND what election, and choice ought to be made of her.
CHAP. I.
div.p: THough it were fit, that euery mother Å¿hould nurÅ¿e her owne child: becauÅ¿e her milke which is nothing elÅ¿e, but the bloud whitened (of which he was made, and wherwith hee had beene nouriÅ¿hed the time hee Å¿taide in his Mothers wombe) will bee alwaies more naturall, and familiar vnto him, than that of a Å¿tranger: and alÅ¿o by nurÅ¿ing him her Å¿elfe, Å¿he Å¿hall be wholly accounted his mother: yet Å¿ince they may be hindred by Å¿icknes, or for that they are too weake and tender, or elÅ¿e becauÅ¿e their Husbands will not Å¿uffer them, therefore I Å¿ay, it will be very neceÅ¿Å¿ary to Å¿eeke out another NurÅ¿e:The difficulty of finding a good nurÅ¿e. and euery one knowes how hard a thing it is, to finde a good one, becauÅ¿e they haue beene Å¿o often beguiled, and deceiued therein: which hath giuen mee occaÅ¿ion, firÅ¿t of all to Å¿hew Å¿ome marks, whereby you may make Å¿ome choiÅ¿e of one that is fit.

Now, in chuÅ¿ing of a NurÅ¿e, there are Å¿ixe things
to be conÅ¿idered: Her birth and Parentage: her perÅ¿on: her behauiour: her mind: her milke: and her child.

1. Her Lignage.FirÅ¿t, Concerning her Lignage, Å¿he muÅ¿t come of a good Å¿tocke, or kinred: there being none of her race, whether it be grandfather, or grandmother, nay, not Å¿o much as one of her great grandfathers, or ancient progenitors, that hath euer been Å¿tayned, or Å¿potted, either in bodie or mind: For, oftentimes we Å¿ee, though the Parents be healthfull, and Å¿ound, yet their children be Å¿ometimes, either Å¿ickly, or fooles, or elÅ¿e viciouÅ¿ly giuen: who retaine Å¿uch vices from their grandfather, grandmother, yea, and Å¿omtimes from their great grandfathers; which troubleth many men, to thinke from whence theÅ¿e accidents may proceed: For it is verie certaine, that there are many Children, which are diÅ¿eaÅ¿ed or deformed, either in bodie, or mind, whoÅ¿e parents are verie healthfull, and well featur'd: But yet, if you Å¿earch farther, you Å¿hall find that Å¿ome of their progenitors haue been affected in the like manner.

2. Her PerÅ¿on.2. Touching the NurÅ¿es perÅ¿on; for her age, Å¿he Å¿hall be choÅ¿en, when Å¿he is at her full growth, which is about fiue and twentie yeares of age, from which time, to the fiue and thirtieth yeare, is the age, wherein women are moÅ¿t temperate, healthfull, Å¿trong, and luÅ¿ty: therefore one Å¿hall be choÅ¿en, that is betweene fiue and twentie, and fiue and thirtie yeares.Her Stature. Now, for her bodie, Å¿he ought to be of a middle Å¿tature, neither too big, nor too little,
nor too fat, nor too leane, nor yet too groÅ¿Å¿e, hauing good fleÅ¿hy armes, and legges; and her fleÅ¿h being hard and firme: Å¿he muÅ¿t not be deformed, neither Å¿quint-ey'd, lame, nor crump Å¿houldred: Å¿he muÅ¿t be one that is healthfull, and not Å¿ubiect to any diÅ¿eaÅ¿e: the complexion and colour of her bodie, muÅ¿t be liuely, and roÅ¿ie: Å¿he muÅ¿t not be Å¿potted with redneÅ¿Å¿e,A red hair'd NurÅ¿e diÅ¿commended. and eÅ¿pecially Å¿he Å¿hould not haue red haire: and therefore, Å¿uch as are of a browne complexion, are held to be beÅ¿t, whoÅ¿e haire is of a cheÅ¿t-nut colour, betweene yellow and blacke.

She muÅ¿t haue a pleaÅ¿ing countenance,Her Countenance. a bright and cleare eie, a well formed noÅ¿e, neither crooked, nor of a bad Å¿mell, a ruddie mouth, and verie white teeth: She muÅ¿t deliuer her words well, and diÅ¿tinctly, without Å¿tammering: and Å¿he muÅ¿t haue a Å¿trong and big necke:A NurÅ¿es perfections. for thereby (as Hippocrates Å¿aith) may one iudge, of the Å¿trength of the bodie. She muÅ¿t haue a broad and large breaÅ¿t, garniÅ¿hed with two Paps of a reaÅ¿onable bigneÅ¿Å¿e, neither limber, nor hanging downe, but betweene hard and Å¿oft; full of Azure veines and Arteries, not being either knottie, or Å¿wolne bigger then they Å¿hould be: the nipple which is in the midÅ¿t of the breaÅ¿ts, ought to be Å¿omewhat eminent, and withall a ruddie colour like a Strawberie, it muÅ¿t be of a reaÅ¿onable bigneÅ¿Å¿e and thickneÅ¿Å¿e, and of an eaÅ¿ie draught, that the child may take it the better, and Å¿ucke the eaÅ¿ier.

She muÅ¿t not be with child, neither Å¿hould Å¿he
haue her naturall purgings;Hipp. lib. 2. Epidemiar. though Hippocrates Å¿eemes to allow the contrarie: relating the Å¿torie of a NurÅ¿e, whoÅ¿e bodie was full of PuÅ¿tules, of which Å¿he was freed, as Å¿oone as Å¿he had her ordinary Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e: deÅ¿iring (as Å¿ome Interpreters would haue it) to Å¿hew, that it is not without reaÅ¿on, for the NurÅ¿es health, that Å¿he Å¿hould haue her courÅ¿es: thereby to coole and cleanÅ¿e the bloud, whereof the milke is made.

3. Her Manners.3. She ought to be of a good behauiour, Å¿ober, and not giuen either to drinking, or gluttonie, milde, without being angry, or fretfull: for there is nothing that Å¿ooner corrupts the bloud, of which the milke is made, than choller, or Å¿adneÅ¿Å¿e: and therefore Å¿he muÅ¿t be merry, playing and Å¿inging to the child, dandling and vÅ¿ing him gently; and one that will not refuÅ¿e to giue him the breaÅ¿t at any time, for feare leaÅ¿t he crie. She muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e be chaÅ¿t, not deÅ¿iring after her husbands companie, and much leÅ¿Å¿e a Å¿trangers; becauÅ¿e carnal copulation (as Galen Å¿aith) troubleth the bloud, and Å¿o by conÅ¿equence the milke; alÅ¿o it diminiÅ¿heth the quantitie thereof, by prouoking the naturall purgations; and alÅ¿o makes her haue an ill Å¿mell, (as AriÅ¿totle Å¿aith) becauÅ¿e they heat themÅ¿elues verie much in this act: and which is worÅ¿t, the NurÅ¿e thinking onely to take her Å¿port a little, may therby prooue with child.

4. Her Mind.4. Concerning her mind: Let her be Å¿age, wiÅ¿e, diÅ¿creet, that Å¿he may take care of her little one, and not lay him in any place, where he may indanger
himÅ¿elfe, to be either Å¿icke, or Å¿tifled: For, there are more NurÅ¿es then Å¿hould be, which are Å¿uch beaÅ¿ts, and Å¿o careleÅ¿Å¿e; who hauing their child Å¿ucke in the night, as they lie with them in the bed, do oftentimes fall a Å¿leep vpon them, and Å¿o Å¿tifle them. And Å¿he muÅ¿t alÅ¿o haue diÅ¿cretion, to iudge Å¿omewhat neare, what her little one crieth after, it being not able otherwiÅ¿e to expreÅ¿Å¿e what it would haue:Gal. de Sanitat. tuenda. ObÅ¿eruing (as Galen Å¿aith) the childs diÅ¿poÅ¿ition, that Å¿o Å¿he may giue him that, which he craues or deÅ¿ires, or elÅ¿e take away Å¿uch things as Å¿hall offend him: playing with him, kiÅ¿Å¿ing him, dancing him gently in her armes, and Å¿inging withall: and Å¿he muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e open him often, to lay and keep him drie and cleane.

div.head: Of the conditions which are required in good Milke.
div.p:
THe choiÅ¿e of good Milke is,The qualitie of good Milke. that it be of a middle Å¿ubÅ¿tance, that is to Å¿ay, Å¿uch as Å¿hal be neither too watriÅ¿h, nor too thicke: For that which is too watriÅ¿h and thin, may cauÅ¿e the child to haue a Å¿cowring, and beÅ¿ides, it yeeldeth no good nutriment: And the Milke which is too thicke, is eaÅ¿ily crudled, and not Å¿o Å¿oone digeÅ¿ted, and Å¿o cauÅ¿eth obÅ¿tructions, from whence the matter of the Å¿tone is bred. As for the quantitie of Milke:Quantitie of Milke. a NurÅ¿e Å¿hould rather haue too much, then too little: becauÅ¿e when there is but little, it will be hard for the child to draw it; when as if there be plentie, it will
come the eaÅ¿ier, and euen thruÅ¿t out it Å¿elfe. Moreouer, if the child Å¿hould Å¿ucke the breaÅ¿t drie; then that which Å¿hall come in the roome of it, cannot be well concocted Å¿o Å¿oone: BeÅ¿ides, if the child Å¿hould chance to haue an Ague, then would he Å¿ucke, and conÅ¿ume a great deale. Againe, the NurÅ¿e beÅ¿ides a Å¿ufficient quantitie for the nouriÅ¿ â¢
ing of the child, muÅ¿t haue Å¿ome to mil â¢ to ãâã eyes, if he Å¿hould chance to haue any i â¢
â¢ fe â¢ to â¢ there: as either heat, pimples, or itch â¢ that Å¿o it may be cooled.

The colour of good Milke.As for the colour, it muÅ¿t be white, according to the common Å¿aying: (As white as Milke) for the Milke which is blewiÅ¿h, makes Å¿hew of Melancholy, as the yellow doth of Choller, and the reddiÅ¿h, that it is not well concocted, and Å¿ignifies either that there is a weakneÅ¿Å¿e in the breaÅ¿ts, or elÅ¿e an ill qualitie of the bloud whereof it is made, which hath not been concocted and corrected by the naturall heat of the paps.

The Å¿mell.BeÅ¿ides, good Milke ought not to haue any Å¿trong Å¿mell, but rather a Å¿weet Å¿ent, which Å¿melleth neither hote, nor Å¿ower, nor yet aduÅ¿t, for Å¿uch Å¿mels Å¿hew, that the bloud, of which it is made, is ouerheated or putride.

The taÅ¿t.And concerning the TaÅ¿t; that Milke which hath a Å¿weet Å¿auour is much commended: as contrarywiÅ¿e, that which is either Å¿harp, Å¿ower, or bitter, is to be refuÅ¿ed, and therefore not choÅ¿en for good.

A proofe of the goodneÅ¿Å¿e of Milke in quantitie.Now the triall there of may be made in this Å¿ort; as to know whether it be of a good Å¿ubÅ¿tance: let
the nurÅ¿e milke Å¿ome few drops of it, vpon a looking glaÅ¿Å¿e, or other Å¿leeke thing: and if in holding it gently aÅ¿ide, it flows and runs preÅ¿ently, and keepe not together a little, then it is a Å¿igne that the milke is watriÅ¿h, and too thinne, If it Å¿tand Å¿till, and will not runne at all, then it Å¿hews that the milke is too thicke and fat: But if it runne leaÅ¿urely, not Å¿taying eyther too long, or flowing too Å¿oone, vpon the Å¿aid Å¿mooth body: it Å¿heweth that the milke is of a middle Å¿ubÅ¿tance, and ought to bee reckoned and choÅ¿en for the beÅ¿t.

The quantity of the milke may be knowne thus:A trial of the quantity. if there remaine Å¿ome in the breaÅ¿t after the childe hath done Å¿ucking: and againe, if in opening the child you find him bepiÅ¿Å¿ed: But you muÅ¿t haue an eye that your nurÅ¿e be none of theÅ¿e CooÅ¿eners (for there be Å¿ome) that giue the child water to drinke in Å¿ecret, and others, which wet the childs bed: But Å¿uch NurÅ¿es deÅ¿erue to be whipt, and their knauery may be eaÅ¿ily deÅ¿cried, both by the eye and the Å¿ent and likewiÅ¿e diÅ¿cerned by the taÅ¿t.

Now the obÅ¿eruation,The choice of a NurÅ¿e by her child. which is taken from the NurÅ¿es child, for the choice of a fit NurÅ¿e, is concerning his age: For if her child be aboue Å¿euen or eight months old, then her milke will bee too Å¿tale afterwards: and beÅ¿ides it would be a doubt, whether Å¿hee would haue milke enough to nurÅ¿e him, that Å¿hould be put vnto her.

Againe, if the childe be but fifteene daies or a moneth olde, that Å¿hews, that her milke is too new, and that it is not as yet well purified: becauÅ¿e

the mother is not wholly purged and clenÅ¿ed.
Auicen. So Auicen commands, that a child Å¿hould not be put to Å¿ucke a Woman, till at leaÅ¿t two moneths after her deliuery; and at the fartheÅ¿t not after eight.

And becauÅ¿e the Å¿exe of the NurÅ¿es child muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e bee obÅ¿erued, Aegineta wiÅ¿heth, that it Å¿hould be rather a man child then a maid child: becauÅ¿e the milke is hotter, better concocted; and not Å¿o excrementitious; And he addeth farther, that it is fit (whether it be a boy or a wench) that the mother haue born her burthen, the full time. For thoÅ¿e that are commonly deliuered, before their time, for the moÅ¿t part are not Å¿ound, but Å¿ickly: though there be many healthfull women, which goe with their children but Å¿euen Moneths.

div.head: How a NurÅ¿e ought to order her Å¿elfe, concerning her Dyet, and manner of life. CHAP. II.
div.p: IT is not enough that a NurÅ¿e be indowed with the conditions and qualities aforeÅ¿aid: but it is very fit alÅ¿o that Å¿hee maintaine and preÅ¿erue them: wherefore wee will Å¿et downe briefely, how, and in what manner, Å¿he ought to gouerne her Å¿elfe.

FirÅ¿t of all therefore let her Å¿hun, and auoide all bad ayre, and all kind of ill and Å¿tinking Å¿mels: for
Å¿uch Å¿ents as are too Å¿trong, are naught and hurtfull for her, becauÅ¿e they infect and ouer-heat the Å¿pirits, and bloud, whereof the milke is made:What meat a nurÅ¿e muÅ¿t refrain from. Shee muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e auoide all meats, that are eyther too much Å¿alted, or Å¿piced, or of a Å¿trong taÅ¿t, as Onions, Leekes, Garlicke, MuÅ¿tard, and all kind of Baked Meates, and old cheeÅ¿e: Let her eate Veale, Mutton, Chicken, Kid, Partridge, and Å¿uch like meates which are of good iuice, and of eaÅ¿y digeÅ¿tion:What meates Å¿he Å¿hall vÅ¿e. and Å¿he muÅ¿t vÅ¿e them in moderate Å¿ort, without glutting her Å¿elfe.
All Å¿orts of fiÅ¿h are hurtfull for her, except it bee in Å¿mall quantity: Å¿hee may eate Iacke, Sole, and Quauluer; and if Å¿he eat no fiÅ¿h let her vÅ¿e new laid egges.

Her meate muÅ¿t be rather boyled, then roÅ¿ted, but yet there muÅ¿t be had a reÅ¿pect to the habitude and complexion of the child: For if hee bee very moiÅ¿t and flegmaticke, then the NurÅ¿e Å¿hall rather vÅ¿e roÅ¿tmeat: and Å¿o of other complexions.
Her bread Å¿hall be of good wheate, well made,Her Bread. light, and baked as it ought to be.
Let her put into her pottages, Lettuce, Sorrell,Her broth. Purcelaine, Borage, BugloÅ¿Å¿e, and Succory.
Shee Å¿hall refraine from all kind of raw fruits.

For her drinke, let her take Ale, or Beere;Her drinke. A kinde of drinke which they vÅ¿e in France which they call Bouchet. AriÅ¿totle. and where that cannot be had, Barley water; or water Å¿odden; or elÅ¿e a Å¿mall kind of Hydromel or meade which hath but a little Cinamon in it.

But I would rather counÅ¿aile them, to drinke Wine and Water together. AriÅ¿totle forbids wine,
both to the nurÅ¿e and the child, except it be (as they Å¿ay) well chriÅ¿tned.

Her exerciÅ¿e.She muÅ¿t vÅ¿e moderate exerciÅ¿e, and chiefly before meales: For moderate exerciÅ¿e, doth Å¿trengthen the naturall heate, and conÅ¿umeth all Å¿uperfluities. The parts which ought to be moÅ¿t exerciÅ¿ed, Å¿hould be rather the vppermoÅ¿t, as the Å¿houlders, and armes: becauÅ¿e that the exerciÅ¿ing of them, makes the bloud & Å¿pirits the Å¿ooner aÅ¿cend into the breaÅ¿ts.

Her Å¿leepe.For her Å¿leepe that cannot bee either limited or preÅ¿cribed: becauÅ¿e the NurÅ¿e is oftentimes conÅ¿trained to watch, when the child is eyther froward or Å¿icke. And therefore Å¿he muÅ¿t take her reÅ¿t when Å¿he may, whether it be in the day, or in the night, as the child will giue her leaue.
Her belly muÅ¿t be alwaies looÅ¿e, and if it chance to be bound, Å¿hee may take a CliÅ¿ter. Let her vÅ¿e Broths, Prunes, and Apples well Å¿odden, that Å¿o Å¿he may keepe her Å¿elfe Å¿oluble.
She muÅ¿t Å¿hun all diÅ¿quietnes of mind, and Å¿hee muÅ¿t bee merry and pleaÅ¿ant, neyther vexing, nor grieuing, nor too chollericke.

div.head: The care which a Nature muÅ¿t haue of all the parts of the childs body. CHAP. III.
div.p:
THe NurÅ¿e Å¿hould be choÅ¿en a month or two before the woman be deliuered, that Å¿he may alwaies haue an eye ouer her, and her child, and
then as Å¿oone as the Woman Å¿hall bee brought a-bed, and that the childe hath paÅ¿Å¿ed through the hands of the Midwife, or keeper, and is Å¿wathed by them he Å¿hall be deliuered to the nurÅ¿e to giue him Å¿ucke, and haue a care of him.

FirÅ¿t of all, let the NurÅ¿e conÅ¿ider and view al the parts of the childs body, beginning at the head, obÅ¿eruing whether it be well faÅ¿hioned or no: that if it chance to haue any ill forme, or figure; that then it may be mended as well as it may, which Å¿hall be done by bringing the Å¿aid head vnto the forme of a boule, a little preÅ¿Å¿ed and made flat on both Å¿ides:How to faÅ¿hion the childs head. in Å¿uch Å¿ort that neyther the forepart, nor hinderpart of the head, Å¿tand too farre out, nor yet be too flat: which Å¿hall be done with Å¿uch head-cloths, as they vÅ¿e commonly to weare, Å¿troking it by little and little, without much preÅ¿Å¿ing or cruÅ¿hing it, as Å¿ome NurÅ¿es do: but onely handling it in a milde and gentle faÅ¿hion.
Vpon the Mould of the head you Å¿hal lay a peece of kotton orkerÅ¿ey: Å¿ome vÅ¿e to lay a peece of Å¿carlet.

The eares muÅ¿t bee cleanÅ¿ed:The childs eares muÅ¿t be cleanÅ¿ed. with little rags made like tents: and the NurÅ¿e muÅ¿t looke whether the holes be well made, that there may not remain any filth eyther within, or in the wrinkles and folds behind them. And as RhaÅ¿is Å¿aith, the eares muÅ¿t be a little preÅ¿Å¿ed to the head, that they may not hang downe.

Let the eares alÅ¿o bee wrapped about with fine linnen clouts, that they may not bee ouer heated,
and Å¿o Å¿ticke to the head, by the meanes of Å¿ome groÅ¿Å¿e matter, or Å¿weat which commonly is bredde there.

The eyes clenÅ¿ed.But aboue all, the eyes muÅ¿t be looked vnto and wiped with a fine linnen cloth, eÅ¿pecially about both the corners, that if there Å¿hould chance to be any filth gathered in thoÅ¿e places, it may be taken away. Auicen puts there a little virgin oyle, becauÅ¿e it mitigateth and taketh away the roughneÅ¿Å¿e and nitroÅ¿ity which might remaine about the childs eyes, through his long Å¿wimming and lying in his owne Å¿weat and Vrine, while he was in his mothers wombe. I haue Å¿eene in Å¿ome children, that (after they haue bene borne) there hath runne out of the corner of the eye, many daies together thick drops of bloud, which congealed preÅ¿ently. There are many children likewiÅ¿e borne bleare ey'd, for the helping whereof, the NurÅ¿e Å¿hall vÅ¿e to annoint the corners of the eyes with a little Vnguentum Tutiae, and likewiÅ¿e Å¿pirt a little of her milke into them.

The noÅ¿e muÅ¿t be clenÅ¿ed.Now concerning the childs noÅ¿e, it is fit, that it Å¿hould be opened, and dilated gently, waÅ¿hing and cleanÅ¿ing it with a little warme water. The Å¿ame Auicen bids, that it Å¿hould bee annointed with a little Virgin Oyle, which muÅ¿t bee done with the top of ones finger, the nayles being pared very neer and euen. And if you chaunce to find Å¿ome little membrane, or skinne, that Å¿tops vp the holes, and paÅ¿Å¿age thereof, it Å¿hall be cut aÅ¿under, that there may bee a paÅ¿Å¿age for the excrements of the braine.

And for as much as the head of a childe aboundeth with Å¿tore of moiÅ¿ture, (as Galen writeth) which is purged and voided by the mouth, noÅ¿e, and other paÅ¿Å¿ages: therefore it will be very fit that the NurÅ¿e haue a care to the taking of them away for feare leÅ¿t by their Å¿tay, they eyther fall down vpon the lungs, or into the Å¿tomacke,For the clenÅ¿ing of the mouth. or elÅ¿e grow to be dryed, which happening the NurÅ¿e muÅ¿t put her finger being annointed with honey, to the bottom of the childs mouth, and rub it aboue and vnder the tongue, which Å¿hee may doe alÅ¿o with Sirup of Violets.

BeÅ¿ides Å¿hee Å¿hall looke whether the fundament bee well opened, and whether there bee any filth bred there or no: as alÅ¿o, whether the paÅ¿Å¿age of the yard be free: and if it be a wench,Care to bee had of the fundament. whether there be any membrane, that doth Å¿top vp the entrance: Not long Å¿ince, I made a new paÅ¿Å¿age in a little childe, who had the hole of his yard growne, and as it were glued together: and an other boy, which had the Å¿tring of his yard Å¿o Å¿hort and Å¿traight, that it made the head of it (called Balanus) bow downward, and Å¿eemed as though it had no paÅ¿Å¿age, but as Å¿oone as I had cut the Å¿tring, the yard came to the right faÅ¿hion.
And concerning the membrane which Å¿omtimes Å¿tops the paÅ¿Å¿age: I haue made inciÅ¿ion of the like membrans, in three girles, and lately in the daughter of M. Iames Boyzard.

As for the armes and legges,For the arme â¢ and legs. if they bee either crooked or Å¿tand awry, they muÅ¿t bee Å¿et Å¿traight
with little Å¿waths, & fit boulÅ¿ters, made for the purpoÅ¿e: as likewiÅ¿e if eyther the back bone, or the belly, do Å¿tand out. But for theÅ¿e they muÅ¿t repaire vnto a Chirurgion: who muÅ¿t Å¿hew and inÅ¿truct the NurÅ¿e how Å¿he ought to proceed herein, when Å¿he Å¿hifts the child.

Galen would haue vs, to looke to theÅ¿e deformities betimes,A Precept of Galen, de Å¿anitat. tuend. becauÅ¿e the bones (through their Å¿oftnes & tendernes) are more eaÅ¿ily made Å¿traight and are apter to be Å¿et in their right place & forme, then when they are growne dryer: it being then very hard to amend Å¿uch errors, as the Å¿ame Galen Å¿aith. Gal. de arte medica.

div.head: How the NurÅ¿e muÅ¿t Å¿hift the child. CHAP. IIII.
div.p:
WE muÅ¿t not onely haue a regard, to Å¿uch defects of Nature, as the child may bring with him from his mothers wombe, and cure them: but we muÅ¿t alÅ¿o looke, and haue an eye, that the NurÅ¿e, or Å¿hee that Å¿wathes, and dreÅ¿Å¿eth him, doe not make him worÅ¿e: and of a well faÅ¿hioned child, in all the parts of his body, do not make him deformed or miÅ¿hapen, and Å¿o Å¿poile him. For in Å¿wathing the child, moÅ¿t commonly they bind and cruÅ¿h him Å¿o hard, that they make him grow crooked. Some Å¿wath all the childs body hard to make him haue a goodly necke, and to make him
Å¿eeme the fatter: but this cruÅ¿hing makes his breÅ¿t and the ribs which are faÅ¿tned to the back-bone, to Å¿tand out; Å¿o that they are bended, and draw the Vertebrae to them, which makes the backe bone, to bend and giue out eyther inwardly, or outwardly, or elÅ¿e on the one Å¿ide: and that cauÅ¿eth the childe to be eyther crump-Å¿houldred, or crooked breÅ¿ted, or elÅ¿e to haue one of his Å¿houlders Å¿tand farther out then the other, Å¿ome alÅ¿o bind the hips Å¿o hard that they become very Å¿mal, and that hinders them from growing and waxing big. Which doth much harme, eÅ¿pecially to maids,Inconuenience of hard Å¿wathing the hips. who Å¿hould haue large hips, that when they come to age, they may bring foorth goodly children.

Galen hath obÅ¿erued, Gal. decaus. morber. that the too Å¿traight and hard binding or cruÅ¿hing of the hams, and legges of little children, when they are Å¿wathed, doth make them grow crooked legged and they will remaine, as the Latines call it Vari or Valgi; going either inward or outward with their knees. This imperfection may alÅ¿o happen through the NurÅ¿es fault, by carrying the childe alwaies vpon one arme, and the Å¿ame Å¿ide: and by holding the childs knees hard towards her, making them Å¿tand like a bow: For the preuenting of which miÅ¿chances, the NurÅ¿es Å¿hall carry their children, Å¿ometimes on the right Å¿ide, and Å¿ometimes on the left. And they muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e Å¿wath them, but looÅ¿ely, Å¿tretching downe their armes, all along their Å¿ides, without binding or cruÅ¿hing them hard together.

div.head: Of the childs cradle, and how it is to be placed; and alÅ¿o how the child ought to be laide when he goes to Å¿leepe. CHAP. V.
div.p:
WHen the child Å¿hall bee thus dreÅ¿Å¿ed, and Å¿wathed, it will then be fit to let him Å¿leepe and take Å¿ome reÅ¿t, for which purpoÅ¿e he muÅ¿t be laid in his cradle: fitted with a little mattreÅ¿Å¿e, which Å¿hall be laid deepe to the bottome, that the Å¿ides of the cradle may be a great deale aboue the mattreÅ¿Å¿e; that Å¿o the childe may as it were Å¿inke downe in his cradle for feare leaÅ¿t he fall out of it. Then vpon the MattreÅ¿Å¿e Å¿hal be laid a pillow,How to order the Cradle. that is Å¿omwhat Å¿oft, to lay the childe vpon, letting him lye the firÅ¿t month vpon his backe: but afterwards when hee is waxed a little bigger let him lye Å¿ometimes on his right Å¿ide,How to lay the child. and Å¿ometimes on the left, hauing his head a little raiÅ¿ed vp, that the excrements of his braine may the more eaÅ¿ily flow and paÅ¿Å¿e through the emunctoryes thereof: And hee muÅ¿t bee bound and tyed in with Å¿trings, leaÅ¿t in rocking him, he fall out of his Cradle. At the head of the Cradle let there bee a little Arch made of wood, or Ozier to lay a couerlet ouer it, thereby to keepe away the wind, and that no duÅ¿t fall vpon him. But it would be more conuenient (for thoÅ¿e that can fitly haue it) to Å¿et the Cradle within a little
bed, the Curteynes drawne round about it.

Now,The place where the Cradle Å¿hall be Å¿et. concerning the place where the Cradle muÅ¿t Å¿tand, it will be verie fit, that it be in a chamber that is neither too light, nor to darke, nor too hote, nor too cold: For if it be too light, it Å¿pends the Å¿pirits of the Å¿ight, and hindreth the child from Å¿leeping: if it be too darke, it makes him deÅ¿ire the light, and cauÅ¿es him to be melancholike: if it be too hote, it will Å¿tifle him, & make him apt to catch cold, when he comes into the aire: if it be too cold, it brings him to a murre, or Å¿topping in the head: and therefore it will be beÅ¿t to keep a meane in all of them: And eÅ¿pecially you muÅ¿t haue a care, that the Cradle, and bed, Å¿tand not neare the dore, chimney, or windowes, that the light do not draw the childs Å¿ight awrie, and Å¿o make him prooue to be Å¿quint-ey'd: and therefore the fire, or the candle muÅ¿t be Å¿et right againÅ¿t his eyes: For if they were on either Å¿ide, the glimpÅ¿e will make the child turne and role his eye aÅ¿ide, to follow the light, and Å¿o the vÅ¿e and motion, which the MuÅ¿cles would get therby, may make him either Å¿quint or goggle-ey'd.

Oftentimes the child cannot Å¿leep after he is laid downe, and therefore he muÅ¿t be gently rock'd, to inuite him thereto, and not haÅ¿tily or too faÅ¿t, for feare of making the milke flote in his Å¿tomackes; and his NurÅ¿e Å¿hall Å¿ing by him, becauÅ¿e Å¿inging prouokes Å¿leepe, and keepes him from crying.

Till the childe be two yeere old, he may Å¿leepe at all times whenÅ¿oeuer he will, yea he may fall aÅ¿leepe at his mothers teat as hee is Å¿ucking: and if
you would obÅ¿erue the Å¿pace of time for Å¿leeping which the Ancients did, it muÅ¿t be thus: Till the childe be three or foure yeeres old, let him Å¿leepe more then wake. But according to Galen, he ought heerein not to exceed mediocritie, otherwiÅ¿e it is dangerous: for long Å¿leeping cooleth and moiÅ¿tneth the braine, and there retaines Å¿uperfluities. And Auicen Å¿aith, that it doth be-numme and beÅ¿ot the childs Å¿enÅ¿es, and makes him dull and lumpiÅ¿h.

div.head: When the Mother her Å¿elfe, or the NurÅ¿e, ought to giue the child Å¿ucke, and how, and how much. CHAP. VI.
div.p: IT is verie fit that either the Mother, or Å¿ome other NurÅ¿e for her, do giue the child Å¿ucke after he is borne: if it be the Mother her Å¿elfe, it muÅ¿t not be at the Å¿ooneÅ¿t, vntill eight daies after her deliuerie: Some alÅ¿o are of opinion, that the mother her Å¿elfe, Å¿hould not giue her child Å¿ucke in the month, by reaÅ¿on Å¿he hath been troubled and tir'd in her lying in: and becauÅ¿e Å¿he is not as yet, well cleans'd and purified of her after-purgings, which commonly laÅ¿t a moneth, as Hippocrates Å¿aith: In which Å¿pace Å¿he Å¿hall let little prettie whelpes Å¿ucke her breaÅ¿ts, to make her milke come the better, and that it goe not away.

Some women do make their keepers draw their breaÅ¿ts, and others draw them with glaÅ¿Å¿es themÅ¿elues:
BeÅ¿ides, Auicen commands, that a woman Å¿hould not giue her child Å¿ucke, vntill Å¿he be well recouer'd. Now, you know that Å¿ome are well Å¿ooner, and Å¿ome later, and Å¿o there can be no time limited or preÅ¿cribed: But aboue all it muÅ¿t be obÅ¿erued, (as the Å¿ame Authour Å¿aith) that the NurÅ¿e do not giue the child Å¿ucke, after Å¿he is riÅ¿en, before Å¿he hath milked foorth Å¿ome of her milke: And likewiÅ¿e, Å¿he Å¿hall not giue him the breaÅ¿t, if by chance Å¿he hath ouer heated her Å¿elfe, either by Å¿ome exerciÅ¿e, or elÅ¿e with going, till firÅ¿t Å¿he be come into a good temper, and well cool'd.

Now, in giuing him Å¿ucke,The manner how to giue the child Å¿ucke. Å¿he Å¿hall obÅ¿erue this order: She muÅ¿t Å¿ometimes Å¿pirt Å¿ome of her milke, either vpon the childs lips, or elÅ¿e into his mouth; and when he hath left the nipple, Å¿he muÅ¿t cruÅ¿h her breaÅ¿t a little, that he may draw and Å¿ucke with leÅ¿Å¿e labour, and Å¿he muÅ¿t be carefull, that he Å¿wallow not downe too much at a time, and that the milke come not out againe at the noÅ¿e: BeÅ¿ides, Å¿he muÅ¿t Å¿ometimes take away the teat, and giue it him againe, that he Å¿ucke not too much at once, and too greedily.

It is verie hard to Å¿et downe,What quantitie of milke the child may Å¿ucke. the quantitie of milke that a child Å¿hould take; But therein the nurÅ¿e muÅ¿t haue a reÅ¿pect to the age, complexion, temper, and to the deÅ¿ire which the child hath to Å¿ucke, increaÅ¿ing it, as the child groweth, or according as he is thirÅ¿tie, either through Å¿ome Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e, or when his teeth come foorth: for at thoÅ¿e times he is more drie, then otherwiÅ¿e. Now to know how
often the child Å¿hould Å¿ucke in a day: Paulus Aegineta appoints, that it Å¿hould be twiÅ¿e a day, or thriÅ¿e at the moÅ¿t: which he meaneth for the firÅ¿t foure, or fiue daies, that he may be acquainted therewith by little and little, and alÅ¿o becauÅ¿e there is then no great need. I haue Å¿een children that haue not Å¿ucked in two or three daies, after they were borne; for they know not then, whether they are yet in their Mothers belly, or no: where they Å¿uck'd not at all; Hippocrat. lib. de princip. although that Hippocrates Å¿aith, that the child receiues Å¿ome nouriÅ¿hment by the mouth, while he is in his Mothers belly. It can neither be told nor limitted how often he ought to Å¿ucke in a day; becauÅ¿e it is fit he Å¿hould haue the teat, as often as he crieth: yet let it be but a little at a time, becauÅ¿e the Å¿tomacke at firÅ¿t is but weake. And if he wrangles but a little, it will be beÅ¿t to Å¿till him, either with rocking, or Å¿inging: And though he be not quieted, or Å¿tilled, a little crying can doe him no great harme, but rather may Å¿erue for Å¿ome good vÅ¿e: For it makes him runne at NoÅ¿e, Å¿hed teares, and Å¿pit: it purgeth his braine, yea, and Å¿tirreth vp his naturall heat, and alÅ¿o dilates the paÅ¿Å¿ages of the breaÅ¿t. But if he cry too violently, and eagerly, it may do him much harm, and cauÅ¿e him to be burÅ¿ten, or breake Å¿ome veÅ¿Å¿ell in his breaÅ¿t, or elÅ¿e bring the head-ach.

div.head: How the child muÅ¿t be made cleane, after he is awake and vnÅ¿wathed. CHAP. VII.
div.p: AFter the Child hath well Å¿uck'd, and Å¿lept, the NurÅ¿e muÅ¿t Å¿hift him, and make him cleane: For which purpoÅ¿e the NurÅ¿e, or Å¿ome other, muÅ¿t Å¿it neere the fire, laying out her legges at length, hauing a Å¿oft pillow in her lap, the dores and windowes being cloÅ¿e Å¿hut, and hauing Å¿omething about her, that may keep the wind from the child. And when Å¿he is thus accommodated, Å¿he Å¿hall vnÅ¿wath and Å¿hift him drie. If he be verie foule, Å¿he may waÅ¿h him with a little water and wine luke warme, with a Å¿punge or linnen cloth.

The time of Å¿hifting him is commonly about Å¿euen a clocke in the morning, then againe at noone, and at Å¿euen a clocke at night: and it would not be amiÅ¿Å¿e, to change him againe about midnight; which is not commonly done. But becauÅ¿e there is no certaine howre, either of the childs Å¿ucking, or Å¿leeping: therefore diuers, after he hath Å¿lept a good while, do euery time Å¿hift him: leaÅ¿t he Å¿hould foule and bepiÅ¿Å¿e himÅ¿elfe. And Å¿urely there be many children, that had need to be Å¿hifted, as Å¿oone as they haue foul'd themÅ¿elues: which I would counÅ¿aile you to doe, and not to let them lie in their filth.

When you change his bed, you Å¿hall rub all his bodie ouer, with an indifferent fine linnen cloth: and then his head muÅ¿t be rub'd, and made cleane: and when he is foure or fiue moneth old, his head may be cleans'd with a fine bruÅ¿h: and when he is growen bigger, let it be comb'd.

div.head: What cloths and coats the child muÅ¿t haue, and at what time. CHAP. VIII.
div.p: AS Å¿oone as the childe is Å¿omewhat growne, and that hee cannot well keepe his hands Å¿wathed in, and hid any longer, (which is commonly about the twentieth or thirtieth day, according as he is in Å¿trength) then muÅ¿t hee haue little Å¿leeues, that hauing his armes and hands at liberty, hee may vÅ¿e and Å¿tirre them: and then the NurÅ¿e Å¿hall begin to carry him abroad, Å¿o that it be faire weather, to Å¿port and exerciÅ¿e him, not carrying him out into the raine, or into the hot Å¿unne, nor when there is any rough wind.

And therfore he muÅ¿t be kept in the Å¿hade auoiding all ill ayres, as of Å¿inkes and the like: And if he Å¿hould chance to bee frighted with any thing, the NurÅ¿e Å¿hal endeuor to take away the apprehenÅ¿ion thereof, and harten him, without making him afraid. I haue Å¿een Å¿ome children, that with a fright, haue fallen into the EpilepÅ¿ye or falling Å¿icknes, the
PhyÅ¿itions not being able to giue any other reaÅ¿on thereof, but onely the feare he had taken.

If by chance he doth cry and weepe, then Å¿hall you endeuour by all meanes to Å¿till him, and not let him cry, obÅ¿eruing diligently what it is he cries for, and what may be the cauÅ¿e thereof: that as Galen Å¿aith, he may haue that he deÅ¿ireth, or elÅ¿e be ridde of that which offends and troubleth him.

But the Å¿ame Author Å¿aith, Gal. de Sanit. tuenda. that children generally are Å¿tilled and quieted by three meanes: by giuing them the breaÅ¿t, by rocking, and by Å¿inging to them: They may be alÅ¿o Å¿tilled by giuing them Å¿omething to holde in their hand, or by making them looke vpon Å¿omwhat that pleaÅ¿eth them, as alÅ¿o by carrying them abroad.

About the eighth, or ninth month, or at fartheÅ¿t when the child is a yeare old, he muÅ¿t haue coates, and not be kept Å¿wathed any longer. And if it bee Sommer, he muÅ¿t be coated Å¿ooner becauÅ¿e of the heate, which makes the body oftentimes, to be full of wheales and pimples. And Å¿ome may haue coats Å¿ooner, according as their Å¿trength will Å¿uffer it; of which an eÅ¿peciall care muÅ¿t be had. And chiefly the NurÅ¿e muÅ¿t let him haue a hat, that may be eaÅ¿ie and large enough, which may couer all the forepart of the head, without beeing curious (as they Å¿ay commonly) to make him haue a goodly high forhead.

div.head: At what age the child may take other Å¿ustenance beÅ¿ide Milke. CHAP. IX.
div.p:
THe childe muÅ¿t bee nouriÅ¿hed with milk only, Gal. lib. 1. de Å¿anitate tuenda till his foreteeth be come forth both aboue, and beneath: as Galen writeth: for beeing nothing elÅ¿e yet but as it were milke it is very fit and probable that hee Å¿hould bee nouriÅ¿hed with no other foode:The childs foode. BeÅ¿ides the teeth are chiefly ordained by nature, onely to chaw: and therefore when he hath none, he ought not to be fed with any Å¿olide meat. But as Å¿oone as they are come forth it Å¿heweth that Nature hath giuen him thoÅ¿e inÅ¿truments, to make vÅ¿e of them: and therefore hee may then take more Å¿olide meate, if you thinke he can digeÅ¿t it. For to giue him any other nouriÅ¿hment, then milke or diÅ¿h-meate, before hee haue teeth, it might breede great Å¿tore of crude humors, and winds, which oftentimes (as Auicen Å¿aith) doe cauÅ¿e the child to haue bunches, or contuÅ¿ions, about his backe bone, .and ribs. NeuertheleÅ¿Å¿e, though his teeth bee come, yet muÅ¿t you not giue him meat, that is too Å¿olide, or in too great quantitie: but at the beginning, you may giue him Å¿ops of bread, or Panado, or Gruell: afterward he may Å¿uck the leg of a Chicken, the greateÅ¿t part of the fleÅ¿h being taken away, that he may the better pull, and
gnaw it, and this is but once or twice a day, & that too, when he is almoÅ¿t ready to be weaned (as RhaÅ¿is Å¿aith.) And this alÅ¿o doth Å¿erue to whet and rub his gummes which about that time begin to itch. And when hee is fifteene moneths olde, or a little more, then may you giue him the fleÅ¿h of a Capon, or of Partridge minced and mingled with Å¿ome broth, made either of Veale, Mutton, or Chicken, adding thereto Å¿ome Å¿ops of bread. For the Ancient writers forbid, that wee Å¿hould giue them any Å¿tore of meate, before they are two yeares old: becauÅ¿e they are not able to chaw, and digeÅ¿t it, and alÅ¿o for that they haue not Å¿o much neede of nouriÅ¿hment; And therefore you muÅ¿t Å¿tay till you haue weaned him, before you feede him more plentifully.

div.head: When the child ought to he weaned. CHAP. X.
div.p: IT is a very hard thing to Å¿et downe a certaine time, when a child ought to be weaned; NotwithÅ¿tanding if we wil beleeue Paulus Aegineta, and Auicen, he muÅ¿t be weaned, when he is two yeares old, and hath all his teeth come foorth. Now in Å¿ome they come foorth Å¿ooner, and in others later: and to weane him before they are come foorth, might be an occaÅ¿ion, to make him haue many diÅ¿eaÅ¿es.

Wherefore to know certainely when a childe
Å¿hould be weaned, and that he Å¿hould wholy feed vpon other meat, it muÅ¿t firÅ¿t be obÅ¿erued, whether he take his meat well; and if hee be able to chaw it thoroughly: whether he be Å¿ickly or elÅ¿e Å¿trong and luÅ¿ty.

Concerning the time and Å¿eaÅ¿on of the yeare it muÅ¿t be when the wether is neither too hot, nor too cold: and therfore the fitteÅ¿t time will be the Å¿pring or in Autumn. But Å¿omtimes there is neceÅ¿Å¿ity to wean him at another time, yea & before two yeares, by reaÅ¿on that his nurÅ¿e may chance to bee Å¿ickly, and that he being come to Å¿ome knowledge will not Å¿ucke another. It may alÅ¿o happen that the child is to be weaned before he be two yeares, old for that the milke (although otherwiÅ¿e it bee good) doth curdle and grow Å¿ower in his Å¿tomacke, which requireth Å¿tronger meate.

Now to weane a childe well, let them obÅ¿erue this methode following: FirÅ¿t the teat Å¿hall not be wholy taken from him, but hee Å¿hall Å¿ucke a little, and eate a little meate; and Å¿o continue for a few daies: then afterwards hee Å¿hall not Å¿ucke in the day time, though in the night, they may giue him a little. NeuertheleÅ¿Å¿e, it will be very fit in the morning, when he is awake and hath been Å¿hifted and dreÅ¿Å¿ed, to giue him Å¿ucke a little, and then to let him Å¿tay two or three houres before hee take any thing, afterward to giue him Å¿omwhat to dinner, as Å¿ome pottage, or panade, with a little fleÅ¿h minced, or cut very Å¿mall, and then let him Å¿tay two houres without giuing him any thing, at which time you
may giue him a little Å¿ucke, and lay him to Å¿leepe: And when hee is wakened and hath beene made cleane, then the NurÅ¿e Å¿hall carry him abroad into the aire, if it be faire wether, and giue him Å¿ucke, and then lay him to Å¿leepe againe, without letting him eate any Å¿olide meate, or very little. At his dinner they Å¿hal giue him to drinke a little boyled water: and this order Å¿hall bee kept a whole moneth,That is in France, where they haue not Ale or beere. and when hee Å¿hall bee accuÅ¿tomed to eate Å¿olide meate then the teate Å¿hall bee quite taken from him.

It happens oftentimes that the child will not forÅ¿ake the breaÅ¿ts, but Å¿till cryeth and is very eager after it, and then you muÅ¿t make him loath it, annointing the NurÅ¿es breaÅ¿t with MuÅ¿tard, or elÅ¿e rubbing the top of the nipple with a little Aloes, and likewiÅ¿e make him aÅ¿hamed of it.

div.head: Of the diÅ¿eaÅ¿es which happen to a child. CHAP. XI.
div.p:
HItherto we haue Å¿hewed what manner of Woman a NurÅ¿e ought to be, and how Å¿he Å¿hould NurÅ¿e and giue her child Å¿ucke, it now reÅ¿teth that wee Å¿peake of Å¿ome diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, which happen vnto children in their firÅ¿t age, which is from their birth, to the Å¿euenth month, in which time, they commonly haue their firÅ¿t teeth, then afterwards thoÅ¿e which happen in their Å¿econd age
which is from the Å¿euenth month, to the end of two yeares, at which time they commonly are weaned, and their teeth are almoÅ¿t quite come foorth: leauing the third age, which is from two yeares, to Å¿euen: and the fourth alÅ¿o, which is reckoned from Å¿euen years to fourteene.

Hippocr. lib. 3. aphoriÅ¿. 24. Hippocrates hath obÅ¿erued in his AphoriÅ¿mes, that children, when they are young, are Å¿ubiect to theÅ¿e diÅ¿eaÅ¿es: to a Å¿orenes of the mouth, with little whelks which doe riÅ¿e theron, and vpon the tongue called by him Aphthae, to vomiting, the Cough, watchings, or forÅ¿aking of Å¿leepe, inflammation of the Nauell, Lib. 3. aph. 25. and moiÅ¿ture of the eares. And in their Å¿econd age (which is when their teeth begin to come) they are troubled with itching of the gums and chiefely when the dog teeth come foorth, and thoÅ¿e are moÅ¿t troubled therewithall, which are more fat, and fleÅ¿hy, and which are bound in their belly. But becauÅ¿e there are many other diÅ¿eaÅ¿es that they are Å¿ubiect vnto, whether it be that they bring them from their mothers wombe, with them, or that they happen to them afterwards: therefore I will briefly Å¿peak of them all, beginning firÅ¿t with thoÅ¿e that doe moÅ¿t trouble them.

div.head: How Å¿ome diÅ¿eaÅ¿es may happen vnto little Children in comming foorth of their mothers wombe. CHAP. XII.
div.p:
THere be diuers accidents which happen vnto little children, and at their time of comming
into the world. Some receiuing bruiÅ¿es, and hurts, either in the head or other parts of their body, through Å¿triuing and Å¿training in the deliuery; as Aches, or breaking of an arme, leg, or thigh: which I haue often Å¿eene in a difficult trauaile. The latter muÅ¿t be helped by Å¿etting the bones againe in their right place, whether it bee that they were out of ioint, or elÅ¿e broken, and then bind them, and keepe them Å¿o till they be well grown together, and haue taken firme hold.
As for hurts and bruiÅ¿es, they muÅ¿t bee bathed with Å¿ome fomentation, made of RoÅ¿es, Melilot, & Chamomil flowers, and then annointed with Saint Iohns Wort and RoÅ¿es, mingled together.

Mad. Maheu was deliuered of a childe Å¿o bruiÅ¿ed and torne, that euery one iudged him to bee dead, hee was Å¿o blacke: whom I dreÅ¿Å¿ed and looked vnto, & with the foreÅ¿aid medicine I healed him perfectly. But the worÅ¿t is, when there happeneth any hurt about the childs head, by meanes whereof, there comes Å¿ome great Å¿welling tumor, full of bloud, which may be taken improperly for the Hydrocephalo. If it be but Å¿mall, then it may bee reÅ¿olued with the former fomentation and liniment and Å¿ome plaÅ¿ters of Diacalciteos, and Diachilon Ireatum mingled together. But if the Å¿welling be much and big, then muÅ¿t we not think to heale it by reÅ¿olution, as MaÅ¿ter Pietrae, & I my Å¿elfe Å¿aw a Chirurgion, who was very confident, and did aÅ¿Å¿ure himÅ¿elfe, to make it reÅ¿olue only with new waxe Å¿pread and laid vpon it. But in the end we were conÅ¿trained
to launce the humor, and in few daies, it was perfectly healed vnder my hands.

div.head: Of the greatneÅ¿Å¿e and Å¿welling of the head which happens to little Children. CHAP. XIII.
div.p: IT chaunceth oftentimes, that the childs head after he is born, is bigger then naturally it ought to bee, an accident which is very dangerous, and hard to be cured: whereof there bee three kinds.

The firÅ¿t is called of the Greekes, Macrocephalos, which is, when the head is bigger then naturally it Å¿hould be: and yet this comes naturally, as when the bones of the head bee large, and of great compaÅ¿Å¿e containing great Å¿tore of brayne, and proportioned to the compaÅ¿Å¿e and circuit of them, there being neither winde, nor waters, nor any other humors, that are the cauÅ¿e thereof. Nature hauing thus proportioned it: and it is Å¿o heauy and vnwildy, that the child cannot hold it vpright, his necke beeing conÅ¿trained to bow vnder it, with the very waight, Å¿o that it had neede to bee prop't vp with Å¿ome thing or other: Now there is contrary to this another which is called Microcephalos that is a little head, Å¿uch a one had TherÅ¿ites the Grecian and one Triboulet who was a French man. Both theÅ¿e accidents
are very hard to bee cured, yea almoÅ¿t impoÅ¿Å¿ible.

The Å¿econd kind is called Hydrocephalos, which is, when the head becomes big, by reaÅ¿on of Å¿ome waters therein contained. Of the which there are diuers Å¿orts: for either the waters are contained betweene the skin, and the Pericraneum; or betwixt the Pericraneum and the bone; or betweene the bone and the membranes, called Dura mater, and Pia mater: Some of them are particular, and poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e but onely one part of the head; others are generall and affect it wholy.

Some of them haue their Å¿pring and beginning,The CauÅ¿e. euen from the Mothers wombe: which hapneth when the Mother, while Å¿hee was with childe, through an ill Diet, gathered Å¿tore of crudities and raw humours, whereof there is bred a watriÅ¿h and flegmatike bloud, with the which the child being fed, and not being able to digeÅ¿t, or conÅ¿ume it, much leÅ¿Å¿e to euacuate and void it by the paÅ¿Å¿ages appointed by nature, the watriÅ¿h matter gathers it Å¿elfe together in the head.

It may alÅ¿o proceed from the child, being not well purg'd of the Å¿uperfluities which are gathered in his braine, and diffuÅ¿ed ouer all the head, or part thereof: whereunto we may adde the ill nouriÅ¿hment which the child receiueth from his NurÅ¿e, whoÅ¿e milke is either Å¿erous and watriÅ¿h, or ouer-heated, which cauÅ¿eth diuers vapours, to aÅ¿cend vp into the braine, which are there conuerted into watriÅ¿h humors.

The third kind is called PhiÅ¿ocephalos, when there chanceth to be a wind, which runneth betweene the skin of the head, and the bone; and alÅ¿o betweene the skull, and dura mater; which cauÅ¿eth the head to be Å¿o Å¿wolne, and puft vp, (as Auicen Å¿aith) that there haue been diuers children which haue dyed of it; the bones of the head being verie much thruÅ¿t outward, which is verie painfull: And certainly, there is nothing that cauÅ¿eth greater diÅ¿tention, or more paine, then when there is Å¿ome wind incloÅ¿ed, in what part Å¿oeuer it be of the bodie.

The watrie Å¿welling hath almoÅ¿t the like cauÅ¿es, by reaÅ¿on of Å¿ome watriÅ¿h matter, that is bred in the braine, which through the weakneÅ¿Å¿e of the naturall heat, cannot well be diÅ¿perÅ¿ed, and Å¿o it is turned into wind: or elÅ¿e through Å¿ome vapours, which ariÅ¿e from the neather parts, which do alÅ¿o diÅ¿tend, and Å¿tretch out the parts of the head.

They are all of them different one from another: for the Macrocephalos, or great headed, yeelds not any impreÅ¿Å¿ion when it is cruÅ¿h'd, becauÅ¿e it is the bones which make it Å¿o big and Å¿wolne: but in the watriÅ¿h Å¿welling, the finger enters eaÅ¿ily, and leaues an impreÅ¿Å¿ion as an O Edema doth: But if you preÅ¿Å¿e the windy Å¿welling, it leaues no marke, or print, but preÅ¿ently it riÅ¿eth vp againe like a foot-ball.

Now, to know whether the water be contained betwixt the bones of the head, and the membranes of the braine: it may eaÅ¿ilie be diÅ¿cerned by the paine, and by the accidents: as if there happen any
Vertigo, or EpilepÅ¿y, to the child, and that he Å¿leep, little, or not at all; as alÅ¿o his continuall crying doth witneÅ¿Å¿e it.
The Cure of the windie Å¿welling Å¿hall be performed,The cure of PhiÅ¿ocephalos. by appointing the NurÅ¿e to keep a good Diet, vÅ¿ing meates that Å¿hall neither breed wind, nor crudities.

Concerning outward medicines,Outward medicines. it is good to vÅ¿e Fomentations: for Å¿uch kind of medicines Å¿urely may do him verie much good, if the wind be contain'd between the skin, and the Pericraneum, or betwixt the Pericraneum, and the skull. But if the Å¿aid wind be incloÅ¿ed betweene the skull, and dura mater, it will be a verie difficult diÅ¿eaÅ¿e to be cured, (except the wind be but in Å¿mall quantitie.) The Fomentation is this.

div.p: Hydrocephalos. As for the watriÅ¿h Å¿welling, according to the quantitie, and qualitie of the humour that makes it, and the place where in the Å¿aid humour is contained, it will be either eaÅ¿ie or hard to be cured: for if the humour be thin, and in Å¿mall quantitie, and that it be contained betweene the skin, and the Pericraneum, or elÅ¿e betweene the Pericraneum, and the skull, or betweene the membranes of the skull; then Auicen makes a doubt, Auicen. whether it can be cured.
But if it be curable, the beÅ¿t way will be to vÅ¿e the Fomentations and PlaÅ¿ters following: which haue power to digeÅ¿t, and drie vp the Å¿aid watriÅ¿hneÅ¿Å¿e.

div.p: You muÅ¿t likewiÅ¿e applie the MagiÅ¿trall emplaÅ¿ter de Bettonica. Some take Snayles, Å¿hels and all, and beat them, putting vnto them a little powder of Bettonie, and of the rootes of Ireos.
And if theÅ¿e medicines profit not, as indeed it is verie hard they Å¿hould: then muÅ¿t you determine to open it.

The ancient Writers, as RhaÅ¿is, makes no queÅ¿tion to applie thereto Å¿ome gentle Cautery; others do rather counÅ¿aile, that it Å¿hould be open'd with a launcet: For mine owne part, I haue practiz'd both waies, without any ill accident, when that the waters haue been contained betweene the skin, and the Pericranium, or betweene the Pericranium and the skull: But to Å¿ay the truth, when the waters is betweene the bones, and the membranes of the braine; though my Å¿elfe I haue been verie carefull in dreÅ¿Å¿ing of it: and not long Å¿ince, being ioined with MonÅ¿. Pietre, a Å¿worne Chirurgion of Paris; yet the Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e hath not been according as we deÅ¿ir'd; And therefore, the cure of it muÅ¿t not be taken in hand, but with foretelling of the danger.

div.head: Other imperfections, that accompanie the Child, when he is borne: as excreÅ¿cences of fleÅ¿h, the roofe of the mouth cleft, a hare lip, and Å¿upernumerarie fingers. CHAP. XIIII.
div.p:
WEe Å¿ee many times, that the Child brings with him into the world diuers other imperfections, and effects: As I Å¿aw a child of one Peter Ferot, who had a little piece of fleÅ¿h, which hung in the middle of his chin, like vnto a little Å¿auÅ¿age, of the bigneÅ¿Å¿e of a quill, and halfe as long: and I
tyed it about with a thread, and cured it quickly. I did the like alÅ¿o another time, being accompanied with MonÅ¿. Portall, to a Å¿onne of MonÅ¿. de Saint Gille, who had as it were a little cherrie hanging at the end of his eare.

I haue Å¿een three little children newly borne, (and among the reÅ¿t,The roofe of the mouth cleft. I Å¿aw one, being with MonÅ¿. Hautin of Paris, ordinarie PhyÅ¿icion to the King, who was the Å¿onne of MonÅ¿. de Cheary:) all theÅ¿e three children had the roofe of their mouth cleft and diuided, euen to the bottome of the NoÅ¿e: by meanes whereof they could not Å¿ucke: becauÅ¿e it is neceÅ¿Å¿arie for one that will Å¿ucke well, to haue the aire cloÅ¿ed in the mouth, and not to be diÅ¿Å¿ipated and loÅ¿t: which a child that hath a cleft pallet, cannot do: becauÅ¿e the aire doth Å¿pread it Å¿elfe abroad, and gets out by the pallet ot the mouth and the noÅ¿e. NeuertheleÅ¿Å¿e, I haue Å¿een little children, that haue been nouriÅ¿h'd by a Å¿ucking bottle, the Å¿pace of two or three moneths: but at length they haue died: becauÅ¿e the milke ran out by the noÅ¿e, it being a verie hard thing, to make an artificiall pallet, that Å¿hould keep it from going foorth: NeuertheleÅ¿Å¿e, I would counÅ¿aile the Chirurgion to make one, and to fit it with a little Å¿punge tyed to it, which Å¿hall be put handÅ¿omely into the Å¿aid cleft with the pallet: and it muÅ¿t be put in when the child would Å¿ucke, and then taken out againe when he hath done. And this haue I practized with good Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e.

The hare lip.The clouen Lip, called a hare lip, doth often
happen vnto children: but the chiefeÅ¿t point is, to know whether it Å¿hould be cured betimes, or elÅ¿e Å¿tay longer before it be taken in hand. I was once preÅ¿ent at a ConÅ¿ultation, for a great Lords Å¿onne, who was brought hither from beyond the Sea, for me to take him in hand, and cure him: Sixe PhyÅ¿icions and Chirurgions were of opinion, that the cure Å¿hould be defer'd longer, (becauÅ¿e the child was not aboue foure or fiue moneths old.) NotwithÅ¿tanding, it was put in practize contrarie to their opinion, but the childs life was indangered thereby: And to Å¿ay the truth, it is fitter to prolong and defer the practize of it, vntill the child haue Å¿ome more diÅ¿cretion: for otherwiÅ¿e there is danger, leaÅ¿t the points of the needles be broken, either by the childs crying, or Å¿ucking, or elÅ¿e in rubbing himÅ¿elfe:A hyÅ¿toric. as I haue knowen it happen vnto Å¿ome, their fleÅ¿h being verie Å¿oft and tender: BeÅ¿ides, the operation is hard to be done, by reaÅ¿on of the childs impatience, hauing no diÅ¿cretion, or knowledge, (the which hapned to the foreÅ¿aid Lord:) And alÅ¿o, for that it growes not a whit the worÅ¿e, for the deferring it, till the child haue more vnderÅ¿tanding and iudgement.

If the child Å¿hould haue a finger, or a toe,Extraordinarie number of fingers. aboue the ordinarie number, as there be Å¿ome which haue Å¿ixe, whether it be in the hand, or on the feet: this deformitie hapning, I thinke it beÅ¿t, that it be taken away, as Å¿oone as the child is growen any thing big: Which I haue done,A Å¿torie. to an honeÅ¿t Gentle-womans Å¿onne, who had two thumbes, which came
vnto him, as his Mother told me, by marking and beholding earneÅ¿tly her Vintager, who had two thumbes, as he told money into her hand when Å¿he reckoned with him, whereat Å¿he tooke an exceeding pleaÅ¿ure, and delight, to Å¿ee him wagge the Å¿aid thumbes, in that manner.

div.head: Of the diÅ¿eaÅ¿es which happen in the Eies, Eares, and NoÅ¿e, of little Children. CHAP. XV.
div.p: MOST commonly little Children, when they are newly borne, are Å¿ubiect to diuers diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, which chaunce in their eies, eares, noÅ¿e, mouth Nauell, and other parts of their bodies, as we will Å¿hew heereafter in briefe.

Of the diÅ¿eaÅ¿es of the eies.Concerning thoÅ¿e that happen in their eies; I referre the young Chirurgion to my booke of the diÅ¿eaÅ¿es of the eies, which I wrote on that Å¿ubiect. But becauÅ¿e, that for the moÅ¿t part they are troubled with watering, and bloud-Å¿hot eies, it will not bee amiÅ¿Å¿e in this caÅ¿e, that the NurÅ¿e Å¿prinkle him Å¿ome of her milke, to make him open his eies, and take away the gumme that holdeth them together. She may likewiÅ¿e waÅ¿h them with a little roÅ¿e water, and Plantaine water warm'd, and Å¿hall annoint the lids and corners of his eies, morning and euening with a little Vnguentum Tutiae well made & prepared; for this ointment hath power through
his oylines, to keepe the eyelids from Å¿ticking and gluing together, to Å¿trengthen them and take away any inflammation that may happen there.

Oftentimes the NoÅ¿e of little Children is Å¿o Å¿topped with filth and matter which is dryed,Of the noÅ¿e. that they can Å¿carcely fetch breath thereby. This accident doth much trouble them, eÅ¿pecially when they Å¿ucke, and it makes them oftentimes Å¿wallow their Å¿pittle, and breath with paine: when this chanceth, the NurÅ¿e muÅ¿t moiÅ¿ten the inÅ¿ide of the noÅ¿e, with fine Å¿oft linnen tents, rubd ouer with Å¿ome Vnguentum RoÅ¿atum, or Pomatum, or for want of theÅ¿e, Å¿he Å¿hall take a little of the Å¿eething of the pot, and make him Å¿nift it vp into his noÅ¿e (if he haue diÅ¿cretion to do it.)

LikewiÅ¿e the eares of little children do commonly runne as well within as without,Of the eares. which happeneth becauÅ¿e naturally their braine is very moiÅ¿t, and beÅ¿ides there ariÅ¿e many vapors from the entrailes into the head, which fills their braine with moiÅ¿ture, and that runne and flows by the eares: and therefore the NurÅ¿e muÅ¿t haue a care to keepe cleane the childs eares, as well within as without, and behind them: dropping into them gently now and then, two or three drops of oile of bitter Almonds, with a little Honey of RoÅ¿es, a little warm'd. And if there be any fretting or excoriation behind and about the eares: then the nurÅ¿e Å¿hal lay on them handÅ¿omely, fine linnen plaÅ¿ters, handÅ¿omely, fine little plaÅ¿ters, made with an ointment compoÅ¿ed of white waxe, and oyle of Nuts.

Towards the hinder part of the eares, about the bottome of them, there happens oftentimes Å¿wellings which the Ancients call Parotides, and the French Orillons: when theÅ¿e happen, they muÅ¿t bee rub'd with oyle of Å¿weet Almonds, laying vppon it a little quilt made of carden cotten, or fatty wooll baÅ¿ted betweene fine linnen clothes.

And the better to reÅ¿olue the Å¿aid Å¿welling you may adde to it a little oyle of Chamomile, and Lillies. If theÅ¿e Å¿wellings come to Å¿uppuration, they muÅ¿t be dreÅ¿Å¿ed as other impoÅ¿tumes be, not vÅ¿ing thereto any repercuÅ¿Å¿iue medicines.

div.head: Of the Å¿oares and vlcers, which happen in the childs mouth, called Aphthae. CHAP. XVI.
div.p:
MOÅ¿t commonly in the mouths of children, there ariÅ¿e little puÅ¿tules and vlcers which poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e not only the Å¿ides of the mouth, the tongue, and the gums, but euen the very almonds, & pallet, of the mouth, and they were called of the Ancients Aphthae. Of theÅ¿e vlcers there bee Å¿ome that are malignant and creeping, Aphthae, or the vlcers of the mouth. which Å¿pread abroad as the Herpes doth: and according to the malignity of the humor, which breeds them, they are eyther the eaÅ¿ier, or harder to be cured: thoÅ¿e which come of Å¿ome Å¿alt flegme, & which are neither deepe, nor painfull, nor of an ill colour, nor placed at the bottome of the throat.
But are onely about the gums, the tongue, and the Å¿ides of the mouth, which neyther grow bigger, nor Å¿pread farther, they are eaÅ¿ie to be healed. But thoÅ¿e which creep farther, & are very painful, blackiÅ¿h, and which poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e the bottome of the throat, hauing an Ague ioyned with them, they (as Hippocrates Å¿aith) are malignant, and hard to be cured. I haue Å¿eene Å¿ome, that for all the care and diligence that could be vÅ¿ed to them, haue fallen into a Gangrene. Which hath happened to diuers and of late, to a Cutlers child, who was looked vnto by MonÅ¿. Habigot a MaÅ¿ter Barber Chirurgion of Paris, although hee had Å¿ought and vÅ¿ed all the meanes, both skilfully and faithfully, that Art could require.

For the helping of them that are curable, it is fit, that the NurÅ¿e keepe a good dyet, let the vlcers be gently rubbed a little with Hony of RoÅ¿es, and Å¿yrup of Violets: But if they will not yeeld to this, then the Chirurgion Å¿hall touch them with a little Aqua fortis, but to euery drop of the Å¿aid water, he muÅ¿t adde twelue of Plantaine water, according as he would haue it to be in Å¿trength:A GargariÅ¿m for the vlcers of the mouth. then with a little clout tyed to the end of a Å¿ticke, the vlcers Å¿hall be touched gently. They may alÅ¿o vÅ¿e this GargariÅ¿me.

div.head: Of the two Å¿trings or ligaments that a child hath vnder his tongue. CHAP. XVIII.
div.p: IN Children that are newly borne there are commonlie found two Å¿trings: the one comes from the bottome of the tongue, and reacheth to the very tip and end therof. This Å¿tring is very Å¿lender and Å¿oft, and it hindreth the childe from putting it out at length, and from taking the nipple (as they Å¿ay) that he cannot Å¿ucke well. This Å¿tring muÅ¿t be cut with a Å¿izzer within a few daies after he is borne: and then the nurÅ¿e muÅ¿t thruÅ¿t her finger vnder the childs tongue, and lay there at the firÅ¿t a little chaw'd Å¿alt to keepe it from growing together againe.

There is alÅ¿o another Å¿tring, which is both harder bigger, and more firme, then the former: which
begins at the root of the tongue, and Å¿tretcheth it Å¿elfe almoÅ¿t through the middle thereof, the which Å¿tring is oftentimes Å¿o Å¿hort, that it hinders the child from Å¿tretching it, and putting it foorth of his mouth, and alÅ¿o from turning and wagging it, therby to bring backe the meat hee hath chaw'd, that hee may Å¿wallow it. This may eaÅ¿ily be perceiued, for if you bid the childe to put out his tongue hee cannot doe it; for when he goes about to doe it, it binds and folds double in his mouth, hee not being able to make it come farther then his lips: which much hindereth him in his Å¿peech, and in the deliuery of his words, making him commonly to Å¿tammer.

How to cut the Å¿tring of the tongue.The cure of this is onely to bee done by the Chirurgian, and that after two manners: the firÅ¿t is thus: you muÅ¿t cauÅ¿e the childes tongue to bee lifted vp, and held Å¿tiffe on both Å¿ides, as well by your owne finger, as by Å¿ome others, which Å¿hall hold the other Å¿ide of the tongue, to keepe it Å¿tiffe, and then let the Å¿tring be cut with a Å¿harpe inÅ¿trument, thruÅ¿ting in the point, as deepe as Å¿hall be fit.

Another wayThe Å¿econd way alÅ¿o is, by lifting vp the tongue, and holding it faÅ¿t, (as hath beene already Å¿aide) and then with a needle with a double thred in it, you Å¿hall draw the thred croÅ¿Å¿e the Å¿aid Å¿tring, or ligament (to wit, as farre as you would cut it) and tye it hard, cutting away the ends of the thred Å¿omwhat neere the knot, and Å¿o let it Å¿tay there till it hath Å¿eparated that part of the Å¿tring or ligament
thus tyed. But this way in my opinion, is more painfull then the former. But whether it be cut or tyed, it will leaue an vlcer which muÅ¿t be healed, as wee haue Å¿hewed before, taking care that the Å¿tring grow not together againe.

div.head: Of the Cough which happeneth to little Children. CHAP. XIX.
div.p: WE Å¿ee, that little Children are often troubled with a Cough: which happens vnto them, becauÅ¿e their lungs are weake and tender, which for euery little thing that troubleth them, they endeuour to diÅ¿charge and rid themÅ¿elues of it, with Å¿ome Å¿triuing agitation.

They may alÅ¿o catch this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e by lying vncouered,The cauÅ¿es of the cough. or by being carried abroad in the cold, or in the euening; which makes them to cough, bringing vp little or nothing. They may alÅ¿o cough with Å¿ucking too eagerly, drawing the milke faÅ¿ter then they can Å¿wallow it: and Å¿o Å¿ome few drops by chance get into the Trachaea Arteria, which makes them neuer leaue coughing till they haue brought it all vp againe.

The cough may likewiÅ¿e proceede from the diÅ¿tillation of Å¿ome Å¿harpe, thin humor, which commeth from the braine, and falleth downe vpon the lungs by the Trachea Arteria. There may alÅ¿o bee
gathered, Å¿ome humor in the Pipes or PaÅ¿Å¿ages of the lungs, which Nature at length Å¿triueth to expell and thruÅ¿t foorth.

The cough is dangerous for children.Of what occaÅ¿ion Å¿oeuer it proceede, it is very dangerous, eÅ¿pecially, if it be of long continuance. For feare leaÅ¿t through continuall reaching and coughing, the child get a rupture, or burÅ¿ting, or elÅ¿e an Ague, by reaÅ¿on hee cannot Å¿leepe nor take his reÅ¿t, onely Å¿ome headach, paine of the Å¿ides and Å¿tomacke, and vomiting.
Concerning the cure of it, we muÅ¿t haue a reÅ¿pect to the cauÅ¿e, & Å¿o accordingly it muÅ¿t be remedied.

If the Cough proceed of Cold, let the little one bee kept reaÅ¿onable warme,Medicines againÅ¿t the Cough. and giue him a little oyle of Å¿weet Almonds mingled with Å¿uger Candy: let his breaÅ¿t be rub'd all ouer with freÅ¿h butter and oyle of Å¿weet Almonds: and then lay vpon it Å¿ome warme cloth: if his noÅ¿e be Å¿tuffed, let it be vnÅ¿topped, with a little ointment of RoÅ¿es, or Å¿ome of the liquor you boyle your meate in, whereof you may put a little vp into his noÅ¿e for that purpoÅ¿e.

If it proceed of Å¿ome Å¿harpe humor: then it muÅ¿t be mitigated and thickned, by giuing him a little Å¿yrup of Violets, and of Iuiubes mingled together. As alÅ¿o let him vÅ¿e Iuice of LicoriÅ¿e, Oile of Å¿weete Almonds and Å¿uger Candy; and Lozenges of Diatragacant hum frigidum. If the childe bee any thing big, you may giue Barley Cream, with a few white Poppy Å¿eeds: and let him drink a PtiÅ¿ane made with Barley, and LicoriÅ¿e.

Let all his breÅ¿t and throat bee annointed with
Oile of Violets waÅ¿hed in Barley water.
Apply to the nape of his necke a toÅ¿t of bread hot, or elÅ¿e halfe a loafe new out of the ouen.Means to Å¿tay the cough.
If the Cough hinders him from Å¿leeping, you may giue him a little Sirup of Iuiubes, and Violets, with aÅ¿much Diacodium Å¿ine Å¿peciebus, mingled altogether: Let him alÅ¿o vÅ¿e ConÅ¿erue of RoÅ¿es.

If the Cough come by reaÅ¿on of Å¿ome fleagme, or groÅ¿Å¿e and Å¿limie humour, that is gather'd together in the breaÅ¿t: You muÅ¿t giue the child a little Sirup of Maidenhaire, with as much Sirup or LicoriÅ¿e, and HyÅ¿Å¿ope, or Hony of Narbone, mingled together: RaÅ¿is addeth in this caÅ¿e a little Fennell water.

div.head: Of Gripings and Fretting in the belly, which troubleth little Children. CHAP. XXI.
div.p: THeÅ¿e gripings do trouble little children verie much; the cauÅ¿es are two: For either they come becauÅ¿e the excrement called Meconium, is retained in the guts: (This humour is black and Å¿limy like melted pitch, which pricketh and wringeth their guts, and puts them to paine, to void it) Or elÅ¿e theÅ¿e Gripings are bred of the abundance of milke, which the child taketh, or of the ill qualitie thereof: the which being not digeÅ¿ted, doth putrifie and corrupt, and turnes either into choller, or into Å¿harpe and Å¿alt fleagme: Or elÅ¿e there is bred Å¿ome wind, which cauÅ¿eth a diÅ¿tention of the Å¿tomacke and guts. The cold aire, and the wormes alÅ¿o may cauÅ¿e it, which I leaue to be handled in another place.

div.head: Of the Wormes. CHAP. XXII.
div.p:
Some of them are round and long,
ã in non-Latin alphabet ã . named Elminthes, which breed in the Å¿mall guts, they aÅ¿cend Å¿omtimes into the Å¿tomacke, and come foorth at
the mouth. There be others that are long and flat, called Teniae,

ã in non-Latin alphabet ã . and are called Ascarides, by reaÅ¿on of the itching which they cauÅ¿e in the great gut, & the fundament, in which place they are bred: and oftentimes they are incloÅ¿ed, as it were with a little purÅ¿e. I haue Å¿eene diuers, that haue voided a million, which haue bene, al of them faÅ¿tned together.

Touching their generation, Hippocrates obÅ¿erueth that little children doe bring the wormes euen from their Mothers belly, but moÅ¿t commonly they are bred of putride & corrupted flegm, as alÅ¿o of other ill humors, which lye in the guts.

When children are troubled with the wormes, they waxe leane, they haue no deÅ¿ire to eate, their belly aketh, Å¿wels, and grows bigger; they Å¿tart in their Å¿leepe, and doe Å¿ometimes Å¿woune, and haue a little drye Cough: the colour of their face is pale and wanne, and their eies great: they rub their noÅ¿e commonly: and when they are troubled with Å¿mall wormes, their fundament itcheth: But the Å¿ureÅ¿t Å¿igne that a child hath the wormes of what nature Å¿oeuer they be: is when hee voides them with his excrements by Å¿toole, or that they come vp by the mouth, or through the noÅ¿e, which I haue oftentimes Å¿eene come to paÅ¿Å¿e.

Concerning the PrognoÅ¿ticke, as Å¿oone as you perceiue that the little one is troubled, you muÅ¿t Å¿eeke to help him; for the deferring of it may breed
danger. The Ancients haue written that there are Å¿ome, which haue come foorth through the groyn, and nether belly: which is witneÅ¿Å¿ed by Paulas Aegineta, and Auicen.

The Wormes that come foorth by Å¿toole, mingled with bloud, Å¿hew that they haue gnawne the veines of the guts from whence that bloud floweth. If they are brought vp by vomiting, it Å¿hewes that they prouoke and trouble the Å¿tomacke.
Some haue obÅ¿erued, that a child which hath the Wormes, is in danger of death, if he bee taken with a Å¿hortneÅ¿Å¿e of breath, and becomes moiÅ¿t, and cold.

For the Cure, if the child be young,The Cure. it will bee very conuenient, that the NurÅ¿e keepe, a good dyet: let her abÅ¿teine from all white meates, raw fruits, PeaÅ¿e, beanes, FiÅ¿h, and all other meates that are of hard concoction, and eaÅ¿ie to bee corrupted.

div.head: Of breeding of teeth. CHAP. XXIII.
div.p:
Hippoc. lib. 3. AphoriÅ¿. 25. HIppocrates writeth that amongÅ¿t all the diÅ¿eaÅ¿es, which children are Å¿ubiect vnto, there is none that troubleth them more, then the comming foorth and
paine of their teeth. For the breeding of teeth,The ill accidents which breeding of the teeth brings to children. bringeth diuers dangerous accidents, with it, as Agues, Watchings, ConvulÅ¿ions, Å¿couring, yea, and oftentimes death: From whence commeth the prouerbe, C'eÅ¿t vn bel enfant iuÅ¿que aux dents. It is a goodly child, if his teeth prooue milde. And therfore, not without cauÅ¿e did Galen Å¿ay in his Commentary, that the paine of a childs teeth comming foorth, was more grieuous and hard to be endured, then the paine of a needle thruÅ¿t in any part of the fleÅ¿h, which continues no longer then the needle Å¿tayes there: but in the comming foorth of the teeth, it is not Å¿o, becauÅ¿e then the gums do pricke and Å¿hout continually, which for the moÅ¿t part are much inflamed; and this pricking and Å¿hooting Å¿till increaÅ¿eth, till the teeth be quite come foorth.

Hippocrates in his booke de Dentitione,

The Cure. FirÅ¿t therefore, the NurÅ¿e muÅ¿t often rub the childs gums with her finger alone, thereby to open the pores of them, & make them Å¿oft, that the moiÅ¿ture may breath out the better: and Å¿ometimes let her annoint her finger eyther with Hony, freÅ¿h butter, the braines of a Hare; or Å¿uch like (either roÅ¿ted, or raw) or elÅ¿e with oyle of Lillies,An experimeÌt or Hens greaÅ¿e. div.head: Of the ConvulÅ¿ions which happen to little Children. CHAP. XXIIII.
div.p: IT is not my intent in this place to handle particularly all the kinds and differences of ConvulÅ¿ions, but onely I will content my Å¿elfe to Å¿peak of that which commonly troubleth little children, Hip. de Aero loc. & Aquis. Morbus puerilis. Mater pueroruÌ. and is called by Hippocrates Morbus Puerilis, the childs diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, and by Auicen Mater Puerorum, the mother of little children.

Hippocrates calleth this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e Sacer, and therefore

The cauÅ¿e proceedeth, (as Auicen Å¿aith) either becauÅ¿e that the milke (wherewith the chid is nouriÅ¿hed) is eaÅ¿ily corrupted; though hee Å¿ucke but little: or by reaÅ¿on of the great quantity, that the child taketh, which becauÅ¿e of his weake and dainty Å¿tomacke cannot be well concocted, and digeÅ¿ted: or through the il quality of the milk which the child Å¿ucks daily; or through the weaknes of the Å¿inews, which do receiue eaÅ¿ily the moiÅ¿ture that is bred in the childs body, whereof Nature doth vnburthen her Å¿elfe, vpon them, which happeneth chiefly,An AphoriÅ¿m of Hippocrates. (as Hippocrates Å¿aith) to children that are fat, and haue full bodies, and are bound in their bellies.

This ConvulÅ¿ion oftentimes chanceth through the childs breeding of teeth,Diuers cauÅ¿es of a ConvulÅ¿ion. and eÅ¿pecially of his dog teeth, by meanes of the paine, inflammation, feuers, and watchings, which do commonly follow vpon it.

The cold aire alÅ¿o may be a cauÅ¿e, and likewiÅ¿e the Wormes, which the child may haue, or Å¿ome ill vapor that Å¿triketh vp, and offends the braine: which may ariÅ¿e out of the Å¿tomacke by reaÅ¿on of Å¿ome putrifaction; or elÅ¿e from that which is bred by meanes of the wormes.

As for the PrognoÅ¿ticke hereof, Hippocrates Å¿aith,The PrognoÅ¿ticke. Hippo. de morbe Sacro. that the Children, which haue cleane heads, are Å¿ubiect to ConvulÅ¿ions: And contrariwiÅ¿e that thoÅ¿e which haue Å¿cabs on their head and breake
forth are commonly in good health: For by them, they are purged & clenÅ¿ed of all the ill humors, that they had gathered in their mothers wombe.Good Å¿entences of the Ancients. Galen Å¿aith, that the danger is eaÅ¿ily perceiued, by the childs Å¿hortnes of breath: Auicen & Paulus Aegineta doe aÅ¿Å¿ure vs, that the continuance of this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e long, doth oftentimes kill the child. Areteus Å¿aith, that one violent fit only, is enough to kill him: they that are younger, are in greater danger of death, then the elder, as Caelius Aurelius writeth, becauÅ¿e they cannot Å¿o eaÅ¿ily beare out the fits, as the elder.

If the little one haue neede to be purged, it will bee fitter to giue the NurÅ¿e a purgation then the child: which muÅ¿t neither be very Å¿trong, nor with any Diagridium, Vomiting good for the child. but gentle and eaÅ¿ie, Å¿uch as CaÅ¿sia, Manna, and the like.
If the child be Å¿ubiect to vomit, eÅ¿pecially if he be very big,Cupping glaÅ¿Å¿es. the vomiting may do him much good.

When he comes to be 2. or 3. yeres old, you may

And concerning particular medicines, they muÅ¿t not be too hot (as Å¿ome appoint) for the affections of the Nerues, becauÅ¿e thoÅ¿e heate too much: and (as RhaÅ¿is Å¿aith) they doe onely reÅ¿olue the thinner part. div.head: Of Watchings, wherewith young Children are troubled. CHAP. XXV.
div.p:
ANd not without good cauÅ¿e doth Hippocrates Å¿ay, Hippoc. lib. 3. AphoriÅ¿mor. that too much watching in a
child, is a diÅ¿eaÅ¿e: becauÅ¿e Å¿leep is naturally proper to a child. And when it fals out that he cannot Å¿leep, there muÅ¿t needs be Å¿omewhat that troubles and offends him.

Whereby a child may be hindred from Å¿leeping.A child may be hindred from Å¿leeping, by lying in a chamber that is either too light, too hote, or full of Å¿moake: or elÅ¿e becauÅ¿e the clothes lie too heauie on him: or becauÅ¿e of much noiÅ¿e, or paine, as it happens to them, when they breed Teeth, as likewiÅ¿e by hauing a pin that prickes them: or elÅ¿e becauÅ¿e they are not cleane. BeÅ¿ides, the child may be hindred from Å¿leeping through the ouermuch quantitie of milke, that he hath Å¿ucked, as alÅ¿o though it be taken in Å¿mall quantitie, if it chance to corrupt; becauÅ¿e (as Auicen Å¿aith) by meanes of this putrifaction, there is commonly bred wind and vapours in the braine.

Signes that the child is amiÅ¿Å¿e.The Å¿ignes hereof are euident enough; as when the child crieth continually, and cannot be Å¿till'd or quieted at all by the teat. Then (as Gordonius Å¿aith) their ey-browes Å¿eeme Å¿wolne, and Å¿ometimes their countenance becomes verie wan and pale: which comes Å¿o to paÅ¿Å¿e (as Auicen Å¿aith) through the diÅ¿Å¿ipation of the Å¿pirits, and becauÅ¿e the braine is fill'd full of vapours and exhalations.

The Cure.Concerning the Cure, we muÅ¿t take away the cauÅ¿e that nouriÅ¿heth this watching: if it be by lying in a place that is too light, and open to the aire, then muÅ¿t the windowes be Å¿hut, making it darker: if the chamber where he lyeth be too hote, or if the child haue too many clothes on him, then
muÅ¿t he be laid cooler, and haue fewer clothes, and be without any noiÅ¿e.
If breeding of Teeth be the cauÅ¿e, then Å¿hall it be help'd, as hath been already Å¿aid.

BeÅ¿ides, the child Å¿hall be vnÅ¿wath'd,Diuers means to make a child Å¿leep. and laid in cleane clouts, and then the NurÅ¿e Å¿hall looke whether there be any pin, or fold of his clothes, or any other thing that hurts him: She muÅ¿t neither giue him Å¿ucke Å¿o often, nor in Å¿o great quantitie: and to helpe to void the corruption that may be in his Å¿tomacke, it will be good to giue the child Å¿ome little ClyÅ¿ter, or gentle purgation. LikewiÅ¿e the NurÅ¿e muÅ¿t rocke and Å¿ing to him: and if you find, that he cannot take any reÅ¿t, by all theÅ¿e meanes; then may you giue him a little Barley water, or Barley creame, with a few white Poppie Å¿eeds in it: or elÅ¿e you may let him take a Å¿poonfull of Syrup of Violets and Diacodium mingled together: But you muÅ¿t abÅ¿taine by all meanes from giuing him any Narcoticall or Å¿tupifying medicines, according to the opinion of all Practicioners. RhaÅ¿is bids vs annoint the inÅ¿ide of the childs noÅ¿e, with Oile of Violets, and iuice of Lettuce, putting thereto alÅ¿o a little iuice of Henbane, and yet he goes farther, for he addeth Å¿ome Opium to it.
