div.head: Of the affrightings, Å¿tartings, and raging, which happens to young Children. CHAP. XXVI.
div.p: ALl children are naturally very greedy, and gluttenous, and therefore many times, and eÅ¿pecially when they grow Å¿omwhat big, and are wained, they doe fill them Å¿elues with much milke, or with Å¿tore of diuers other victuals. BeÅ¿ide, they are Å¿ubiect to breed wormes, which dying, abide Å¿till in their guts, by reaÅ¿on of which there grows much corruption both in the Å¿tomack and guts, and alÅ¿o in the meÅ¿enterie, and this corruption growing hot by the heat and moiÅ¿ture of the child, it Å¿ends vp vapors to the brain, from the aforeÅ¿aid parts, which mingling themÅ¿elues with the Å¿pirits, which are there placed, doe cauÅ¿e dreames, frights and Å¿tartings in the Å¿leepe, and (as Auicen witneÅ¿Å¿eth) makes children afraide of things which are not at all to be feared.

Gal. in Hip. lib. 3. AphoriÅ¿. 24.
Galen teacheth vs, that this feare happens then when the Å¿tomacke of the child is weake, and the meate which he taketh corrupts in it: which cauÅ¿eth vapors, and fumes to riÅ¿e to the head, and Å¿o bring theÅ¿e terrors.

This may alÅ¿o happen to thoÅ¿e which are more in yeares, by the vÅ¿e of bad meates: eÅ¿pecially if the mouth of the Å¿tomacke be weake and feeble. And
therefore Auicen Å¿aith, that bad concoction, makes bad dreames.

As for the Å¿ignes that belong heere-unto,The Å¿ignes to know whether a childe be frighted in his Å¿leepe. there can none be obÅ¿erued in children that can not Å¿peak but onely (as Pliny Å¿aith) that as Å¿oone as they bee awake, they wil Å¿creech and cry out, as if they were out of their wits, and vtterlye caÅ¿t away: and commonly you Å¿hall finde them all of a water, and quaking euery part of them: And if you aske them, why they cry, they which can Å¿peake will Å¿ay, that they were made afraide, and that they Å¿aw Å¿ome thing in their Å¿leepe. Moreouer they that are thus frighted are much giuen to vomiting, they are pale of countenance and Å¿omtimes very red: and alÅ¿o they doe hide their faces, and if anyone come neare them they cry out, and are afraid of him.

Thus may we eaÅ¿ily obÅ¿erue that Å¿uch dreames, and frights happen not to young children, but when they bee ill at eaÅ¿e, and full of bad humors. AriÅ¿tot. de hiÅ¿t â¢ r. anim. lib. 4. cap. 10. And this is witneÅ¿Å¿ed by AriÅ¿totle, who Å¿aith; that young infants are not Å¿ubiect to dreames: experience teaching vs, that thoÅ¿e who as yet haue not diÅ¿cretion to know good from bad, are not feared with terrible and fearefull Å¿ights, but contrariwiÅ¿e, doe laugh at them, and are well pleaÅ¿ed.

For the Cure of this accident,The Cure. both the NurÅ¿e and alÅ¿o the child (when he comes to eate) muÅ¿t auoide all meates, which do corrupt the Å¿tomacke, and Å¿uch as are apt to breede groÅ¿Å¿e and malignant vapors, Å¿uch as PeaÅ¿e, Beanes, Leekes, Onions, Coleworts, which (as DioÅ¿corides reporteth) doe
procure Å¿adde and Melancholike dreames.

The diet, that the NurÅ¿e, & the child muÅ¿t keepe.Let them feede vpon good meates, and in a moderate quantity, that Å¿o the Å¿tomacke may not bee ouercharged, and that the concoction may bee the more eaÅ¿ie. RhaÅ¿is wiÅ¿heth the NurÅ¿e to drink a cup of good wine.

After that the child hath Å¿ucked, and the NurÅ¿e hath eaten, they muÅ¿t not (according to the precept of Auicen) go to Å¿leepe preÅ¿ently,They muÅ¿t not Å¿leepe preÅ¿ently after meate. becauÅ¿e the meate can not deÅ¿cend Å¿o Å¿oone to the bottome of the Å¿tomacke, there to bee embraced and perfectly concocted: And when part thereof Å¿tayes at the vpper Orifice of the Å¿tomacke, then the fumes and vapours thereof doe eaÅ¿ily riÅ¿e, and aÅ¿cend to the braine.

If there be any bad humors abiding within the Å¿tomacke,Medicines for the child. guts, or meÅ¿entery, let them be purged out. Auicen giueth to the child a little hony faÅ¿ting. If hee bee Å¿omwhat big, you may giue him a little CaÅ¿sia, a Å¿poonefull of Å¿irup of Cichory, and Å¿irup of Damaske roÅ¿es, or Å¿ome Manna in broth.
If his Å¿tomacke be weake, let it be Å¿trengthened with this Liniment.

div.head: Of the rupture, or falling downe of the gut, in young Children. CHAP. XXVII.
div.p: CHildren, and chiefly male-Children are much troubled at this day with the rupture, of which though there be many kinds,The diuers kinds of ruptures. yet will I treat at this preÅ¿ent onely of the falling downe of the gut, and caule, and of the watery and windie rupture: for thoÅ¿e which are called CamoÅ¿a and VaricoÅ¿a doe Å¿eldome or neuer happen to young children. I haue obÅ¿erued, that many children are born with theÅ¿e ruptures, which happen becauÅ¿e the child beeing in the Mothers wombe, doth often Å¿triue in turning and winding himÅ¿elfe, or elÅ¿e doth Å¿o Å¿traine himÅ¿elfe, that the guts and caule do beare downe vppon the production of the Peritonaeum: which beeing inlarged giueth occaÅ¿ion of a rupture.

As for thoÅ¿e which are called Hydrocele, and PhyÅ¿ocele, which is the watery and windy rupture, it cannot be denied, but that the child before hee be borne (if he draw bad humors from the mother, breedes theÅ¿e waters and winds, which may flow downe into the purÅ¿es of the cod.

div.head: Of the difficultie of making of Water, wherewith young Children are troubled. CHAP. XXVIII.
div.p:
IT happens oftentimes,The cauÅ¿e why children can hardlie piÅ¿Å¿e. that young Children can not make water, and that vpon diuers occaÅ¿ions, but chieflie through the fault of vrine, which offends either in quantitie, or qualitie. The ill qualitie of the Vrine is, when it is hote, Å¿harpe, and pricking, which makes the child afraid to piÅ¿Å¿e: becauÅ¿e of the paine which they feele when their water comes. The Vrine offends in quantitie, when it is in Å¿o great abundance, and doth Å¿o ouer-charge the bladder, that the Fibres being ouer-Å¿tretched, can not draw themÅ¿elues together, to expect the vrine: which happens to them which haue kept their water too long.Children muÅ¿t be often held out to piÅ¿Å¿e. And for this cauÅ¿e, children muÅ¿t oft be called vpon to piÅ¿Å¿e,
both when they awake, and when they are changed, to be laid downe to Å¿leep. And when they grow bigger, let them make water both before and after they eate: for Å¿ince they abound with moiÅ¿tures, and haue their bladder but Å¿mall, they muÅ¿t in no wiÅ¿e keep their water long: and therefore if Å¿ome-times they bepiÅ¿Å¿e themÅ¿elues in their Å¿leep, they muÅ¿t not be much chidden, or beaten, for feare leaÅ¿t if they hold their water by force, they fall into this difficultie of voiding it.

If there be any fleagme, or Å¿lime, or bloud mingled with the water: or if there breed any Å¿and, or Å¿tone, this may be the cauÅ¿e to hinder the childs vrine. And this may happen to young children, as Hippocrates noteth:Hippocr. lib. 3. AphoriÅ¿. 26. becauÅ¿e they eat much, which procures much cruditie, and breeds the matter of the Stone.

The Cure.For the Cure heerof; you muÅ¿t proceed according to the cauÅ¿e: which if it be, becauÅ¿e the vrine is Å¿harpe, and pricking, or too hote; then if it be a Å¿ucking child, it will be good to preÅ¿cribe the NurÅ¿e a dyet,A Diet for the NurÅ¿e. to temper her bloud, which it may be is too hote. Let her alÅ¿o be purged, let bloud, and bathed; and let her vÅ¿e broaths made with coole herbes.

If the bladder of the child be too full of vrine, his bellie will be hard, and Å¿trout out; and then let the NurÅ¿e Å¿ucke the end of his yard, and preÅ¿Å¿e downe his bellie a little, toward the bladder: lay to his bellie water CreÅ¿Å¿es, and Pellitorie of the wall fried. If this do no good, you muÅ¿t put vp finely
an hollow probe: and if there be any grauell, Å¿tone, or phlegme, the probe depiction of probe will diÅ¿couer it.
If the child be Å¿omewhat big, you may giue him this medicine.

div.p: Set him alÅ¿o in a little bath. Galen, and Auicen do much commend the water of Rapes, or Turneps, which you may giue with a little decoction of ParÅ¿ley roots, Dogs tooth, and Dandelion.

But it happens oftentimes, that the child can not piÅ¿Å¿e, by reaÅ¿on of Å¿ome Å¿lime that Å¿tickes in the paÅ¿Å¿age of the yard, which makes it Å¿well, and puffe vp, and Å¿hew as cleare as a bladder.
For the help heerof, you muÅ¿t bring foorth the Å¿tone, by the help of a little inÅ¿trument, like to this heere deÅ¿cribed, in the faÅ¿hion of an eare-picker; which you Å¿hall vÅ¿e in this maner.

You muÅ¿t hold downe the child faÅ¿t, that he Å¿tir not; and then the Chirurgion muÅ¿t take the yard betweene the fore-finger and the thumbe with his left hand, by that part, which is next toward the groine, that is beyond the Å¿tone: for feare, leaÅ¿t in the performance of the worke, it Å¿lip vp, and goe backe againe: Then holding the little inÅ¿trument in his right
hand, let him put it vp into the paÅ¿Å¿age of the the vrine, Å¿o far till he meete with the Å¿tone: which when he hath found, let him beare downe the inÅ¿trument, to make it Å¿lip vnder the Å¿tone, for to catch hold of it, behind; and when he hath hold of it, let him draw it foorth in Å¿uch maner, as Å¿hall be needfull. And it will be neceÅ¿Å¿arie to draw it out Å¿omewhat Å¿trongly, becauÅ¿e oftentimes it Å¿tickes verie hard.
Sometimes it happens, that the Stone is Å¿o big, that it cannot be taken away by this meanes; and then we are conÅ¿trained to make an inciÅ¿ion in the yard; which muÅ¿t be done in this manner.

You muÅ¿t hold the yard faÅ¿t with the left hand, taking it by the midÅ¿t, Å¿o that halfe the thickneÅ¿Å¿e of it may be betweene you finger and thumbe, and the other halfe out, that Å¿o the Stone may riÅ¿e and Å¿well vp the more, on that Å¿ide: Then on that Å¿ide that the Stone Å¿wels vp, right ouer and againÅ¿t the Stone, let an inciÅ¿ion be made, Å¿o deep, till you come to the Stone; which when you find, you Å¿hal put vnder it Å¿uch a Å¿mall inÅ¿trument, as hath been before deÅ¿cribed, therewith to draw it foorth. And afterward let the wound be healed, as an other ordinarie wound: taking care, that there grow no little excreÅ¿cence of fleÅ¿h in the paÅ¿Å¿age of the water.An experience of the Author. I haue practized this with verie good Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e: and amongÅ¿t others, vpon the Å¿onne of MonÅ¿. Robert of Chartres.

div.head: The meanes to helpe children that piÅ¿Å¿e in their bed in the night, and cannot holde their water. CHAP. XXIX.
div.p: LIttle children doe commonly piÅ¿Å¿e a bed, & that for many reaÅ¿ons: As becauÅ¿e they breed and abound (as wee haue already Å¿hewed) with Å¿tore of Vrine which commeth downe into the bladder, and that is Å¿o little, that it is not able to retaine and keepe it, being in Å¿o great quantity, beÅ¿ides the Sphincter muÅ¿cle is very Å¿oft, and weake, by reaÅ¿on of the childs tenderneÅ¿Å¿e: Againe, they doe Å¿o go about all the day long, that when are laid to bed, they Å¿leepe Å¿o Å¿oundly, that they cannot eaÅ¿ily be wakened: wherto may be added, that they vÅ¿e to dreame often in the night, which makes them piÅ¿Å¿e, thinking that they are awake. Some thinke that wenches are more Å¿ubiect heereto then boyes.

Now for the deliuering and freeing them of this accident: diuers PhiÅ¿icions are of opinion, that it is beÅ¿t to let them alone, til they are grown bigger, and not to trouble them with many medicines: For the fibers of the Sphincter muÅ¿cle, which keepe the necke of the bladder Å¿hut together, grow dry, and Å¿tronger, and beÅ¿ides then the child abounds not Å¿o much with moiÅ¿ture, and by conÅ¿equence neither with vrine: but yet they muÅ¿t be hindred from drinking
Å¿o much (as they vÅ¿e in France) cleere water and alÅ¿o kept from eating Å¿o much raw fruite, and moiÅ¿t meats, and the like, which prouoke Vrine.

You muÅ¿t alÅ¿o endeuour to keepe children alwaies looÅ¿e bellied, which will make them piÅ¿Å¿e the leÅ¿Å¿e, as well in the night time, as in the day. And you muÅ¿t warne them to make water before they go to bed, and Å¿omtimes alÅ¿o you may waken them out of their Å¿leepe, to put them in minde thereof.

The childe muÅ¿t bee put in minde to make water.You muÅ¿t alÅ¿o threaten them, that you wil whip them, and likewiÅ¿e make them aÅ¿hamed, of doing it. But yet for all this, you muÅ¿t not correct them too much: for I haue knowne Å¿ome children (fearing to bee beaten, if they piÅ¿Å¿ed a bed) that haue tyed their yard themÅ¿elues, whereof hath followed a Gangrene: which hapned to MonÅ¿. Paraeus, when he was a child, as he himÅ¿elfe hath told me.
When the child is growne Å¿omwhat big, let him eate roÅ¿ted CheÅ¿tnuts Filberds and A cornes: and drinke Å¿til'd water, and a little Claret wine well allayed.
Medicines of the Ancient PhiÅ¿icions. Auicen commendeth the braines of a hare boyled with thicke Wine.

Some hold that the inner skin of a Capons gizzard dryed, and made into pouder, is Å¿ingular good. RhaÅ¿is Å¿ets it downe for a Å¿ecret, that the combe of a Cocke, dryed, and made into powder: as alÅ¿o the bladder of a Bull, or a Goat is very good, which Gordonius approoueth of.

You may giue him a little water of Mirtills,
with ConÅ¿erue of RoÅ¿es, and Å¿irup of drie RoÅ¿es.
It wil be very fit to bath the part of the child called Perinaeum with aÅ¿tringent Fomentations,Fomentations for the Perinquin. Å¿uch as we haue Å¿et downe for the Rupture or Hernia.

div.head: Of the Gallings and fretting of the skin, which happens in the groine, and betweene the thighs of little Children. CHAP. XXX.
div.p: LIttle children,The cauÅ¿e of excoriation, or galling. by reaÅ¿on of the Å¿harpneÅ¿Å¿e of their vrine, and lying in their excrements are much troubled with galling and fretting, which weares away the thinne skin, called Epidermis and chiefly about their thighs, and groyne, which vnleÅ¿Å¿e the nurÅ¿e take the better heede, may grow to Å¿ome foule and malignant vlcer.

Which that it may be the better helped,The Cure. it will bee very fit, that the NurÅ¿e keepe the little one as cleane as Å¿hee can, and that in making him cleane and Å¿hifting him, Å¿he waÅ¿h his buttocks and thighs gently, with a little water of Plantaine, RoÅ¿es, or NightÅ¿hade. I vÅ¿e to preÅ¿cribe a little Pomatum, wherewith I mingle Å¿ometimes a little Lime well quenched and powdered: Vnguentum Refrigerans Galeni, wel waÅ¿hed in Plantaine, and RoÅ¿e water is much commended.
Both theÅ¿e medicines, by reaÅ¿on of their oylines, doe hinder the Vrine, and excrements from making the place to Å¿mart.

div.head: Of the accidents which happen to the childs yard, either before or after his birth. CHAP. XXXI.
div.p:
THere may happen Å¿euen accidents about the top and end of the childs yard, euen from his birth:Diuers imperfections of the PraeputiuÌ. to witte, three in the Praputium or foreskin: and foure in the Glans or top thereof. Touching thoÅ¿e of the Praeputium, the firÅ¿t is when it is Å¿o Å¿traight, and the hole Å¿o little, that the vrine beeing come foorth of the Glans, cannot paÅ¿Å¿e through the skinne, but drop by drop, by reaÅ¿on it is Å¿hut Å¿o cloÅ¿e together; which makes part of the Vrine remaine betwixt the top of the yard and the Preputium. The Å¿econd is when the paÅ¿Å¿age of the Preputium is not altogether Å¿o narrow, but yet it
cannot be put backe neither can the Glans bee vncouered;PhimoÅ¿is. which the Ancients haue called PhimoÅ¿is. The third is when the Praeputium cannot couer the Glans, becauÅ¿e it is Å¿lipped ouer,ParaphimoÅ¿is and drawne backward; called by the Ancients ParaphimoÅ¿is.

Concerning theÅ¿e of the Glans: the firÅ¿t is, when there is no paÅ¿Å¿age at all, in the end thereof: the Å¿econd is, when there is a paÅ¿Å¿age, but the hole is too little. The third is, when the hole is not in the place where it ought to be, which is at the end, but is placed at the bottom or lower part of the Glans. The fourth is, when the top of the yard bendeth downward and makes the yard Å¿tand crooked and awry.

Aristotle hath obÅ¿erued another kinde more Å¿trange then thoÅ¿e, where he Å¿aith,An obÅ¿eruation of AriÅ¿totle. lib. 4. cap. 4. de generatione Animalium. that there haue beene Å¿ome male children, which naturally haue had no paÅ¿Å¿age made at the end of the yard, but the hole hath bene lower in the Perinaeum, Å¿o that they were conÅ¿trained to piÅ¿Å¿e, as it were Å¿itting, & when they held vp their Cods, or Scrotum, they Å¿eemed to be both man, and woman.

I haue heeretofore, for all the other accidents aboue named aduiÅ¿ed the NurÅ¿e to haue a care, and looke to them: But becauÅ¿e the cure of theÅ¿e belong properly to the Chirurgion to haue Å¿et it downe more at large,, and Å¿pecified it more particularly in this place that they may the better helpe it, conÅ¿idering the inconueniences, that may follow, as we will Å¿hew you.

For the firÅ¿t,What happens when the Praeputium is cloÅ¿ed. which is when the skin of the yard is Å¿o Å¿traight that the water cannot come foorth,
but drop by drop, this imperfection cauÅ¿eth a great deale of filth to be gatherd betwixt the Praeputium and the Glans, whereof proceedeth many troubleÅ¿ome and dangerous vlcers, yea, and Å¿ometimes a Gangrene. I haue obÅ¿erued it, in Å¿ome young children, that the top of the yard, hath become blacke and blew with piÅ¿Å¿ing, through the very paine they endured.

The beÅ¿t way to remedie it, is to cut off the verie top and end of the Praeputium, thereby to take away a piece of it, as they doe in the CircumciÅ¿ion. For the performance whereof, there be diuers meanes, but the Å¿afeÅ¿t and leaÅ¿t painfull way, is this.

The order of cutting the Praeputium. FirÅ¿t, it is to be conÅ¿ider'd, that the Praeputium is double, Å¿o that when one thinks to cut both the skins, he cuts but one; for the Å¿econd leaps away eÅ¿pecially from betweene the Sizzers. BeÅ¿ides, in cutting them both together, oftentimes you may cut more of the vppermoÅ¿t skin, then of the nethermoÅ¿t which is next to the Glans, which cauÅ¿eth it to remaine bare, and vncouered, whereof followeth great paine: it being fitter (for that occaÅ¿ion) to cut away leÅ¿Å¿e, of the firÅ¿t, then of the Å¿econd.

The manner of doing it.Wherefore to preuent theÅ¿e accidents, the Chirurgion with his right hand muÅ¿t Å¿lide backward, ouer the Glans, the outward skinne or membrane of the Praeputium: and with the nails of his other hand hee muÅ¿t draw downward towards him the inner skinne, which is next to the Glans, then Å¿ome other Chirurgion, or Å¿tander by, with a paire of pincers
made like vnto theÅ¿e, Å¿hall take depiction of pincers hold of both the Membranes, Å¿o placed with the forkes of the Å¿aid Pincers, holding them very faÅ¿t, taking vp with them, neither more nor leÅ¿Å¿e of the skinne then hee would haue cut off, leauing the Glans or Nut behind, and then with a very Å¿harpe Razer, he muÅ¿t cut away all that is without the forkes of the Pincers: when hee hath done Å¿o, let him looÅ¿en his inÅ¿trument, and let it bleed a little: by which meanes, hee Å¿hall haue both the membranes euen: and not Å¿tanding out one more then the other, onely the outmoÅ¿t (it may bee) will a little come ouer, and couer the Å¿econd: This being done, the wound muÅ¿t be healed, as an ordinary wound.

I haue learned this manner of practiÅ¿e, of MonÅ¿. de Maverne, the Kings PhyÅ¿ition in Ordinary, who hath cauÅ¿ed it to bee done after this faÅ¿hion: and it is the order and Methode, which the Iewes at this day, doe obÅ¿erue, in their circumciÅ¿ion: If you haue not Å¿uch an inÅ¿trument, you may take two little flat peeces of wood, and tye them
both together at one end, and then put the Praeputium betweene them, as we haue Å¿hewed, afterwards tying both the other ends together, reaÅ¿onable hard, & then cut away Å¿o much of the Praeputium as is without the wood, after the Å¿ame manner, as you Å¿ee Å¿miths cut off the tops of horÅ¿e eares.

This method may be alÅ¿o obÅ¿erued, when the Praeputium is too much enlarged, though it hinder not the vrine from comming foorth, which is commonly done, for feare leaÅ¿t it Å¿hould Å¿lip ouer the Glans in Å¿uch Å¿ort that it could not come backe againe, and leaÅ¿t it might cauÅ¿e a ParaphimoÅ¿is, which is more dangerous then the PhimoÅ¿is, & often hapneth to thoÅ¿e that are Å¿omwhat bigge. NeuertheleÅ¿Å¿e we follow an other courÅ¿e in curing the PhimoÅ¿is more eaÅ¿ily than the former, which is to Å¿lit the Praeputium at the bottom: & we do it in this manner. Another way of curing the PhimoÅ¿is. FirÅ¿t we Å¿tretch the Praeputium of al Å¿ides drawing it a little towards vs, & then wee Å¿lip in Å¿uch an inÅ¿trument as you Å¿ee heere, depiction of medical instrument between
the Glans and the Praeputium, euen to the Å¿tring at the bottome of it, and there Å¿uddenly we deuide all the Praeputium below, hard by the Å¿tring, which I haue done very often, and not long Å¿ince for an honeÅ¿t Gentleman, MonÅ¿. Riolan the Chirurgion being with me. For with Å¿uch an inÅ¿trument you Å¿hall cut aÅ¿under both the skinnes euen, which you cannot do Å¿o well with the Å¿izzers, becauÅ¿e the vpper membrane cannot be wholly cut that way, which hath deceiued Å¿ome, and myÅ¿elfe alÅ¿o at the firÅ¿t, beeing conÅ¿trained to go to it againe, the Å¿econd time, which made me deuiÅ¿e this inÅ¿trument.

As for the ParaphimoÅ¿is of little children,The ParaphimoÅ¿is of little children. it is of two Å¿orts: For the Praeputium being Å¿lipped vp ouer the Glans, it either Å¿tickes and Å¿tayes Å¿o, or elÅ¿e it is onely too Å¿hort, and will eaÅ¿ily be brought ouer it againe and couer it, but not Å¿taying Å¿o, it goes backe againe Å¿traight: To that which doth cleaue and Å¿tick to it, it is not fit to do any thing, by reaÅ¿on of the youngeÅ¿Å¿e of the child: And for the other, which is onely too Å¿hort,The Authors opinion. becauÅ¿e it breedes no inconuenience, I would aduiÅ¿e the Chirurgion not to meddle with it, but rather to defer the practiÅ¿e of it, till the child be grown bigger, and be able to endure it, which Å¿hall bee done in this Å¿ort.

You muÅ¿t firÅ¿t of all,The method of doing it. turne backe all the Praeputium, that you may the better come at the inner membrane, which you muÅ¿t hold very faÅ¿t; & make an inciÅ¿ion round about it, the which inciÅ¿ion muÅ¿t goe no deeper then the Å¿aid inner membrane: then letting it bleed well, you muÅ¿t make Å¿uch another
inciÅ¿ion round about the vppermoÅ¿t membrane, which muÅ¿t go no deeper then to the nethermoÅ¿t: and preÅ¿ently as Å¿oone as you haue made theÅ¿e two inciÅ¿ions, you muÅ¿t pul out the Praeputium at length which will eaÅ¿ily Å¿tretch, becauÅ¿e both the membranes by reaÅ¿on of the foreÅ¿aid inciÅ¿ions, wil yeeld. Afterwards you muÅ¿t haue a care, that the Å¿aid inciÅ¿ions grow not together again, and that the innermoÅ¿t membrane bee not glued, and Å¿ticke to the Glans, or top of the yard: which you may hinder by laying betwixt them, fine little linnen rags, Å¿pread ouer with Å¿ome ointment, which may Å¿erue alÅ¿o to heale the Å¿aid inciÅ¿ion.

An other waySome after they haue made theÅ¿e inciÅ¿ions, pull the Praeputium quite ouer the Glans, and tye it reaÅ¿onable hard, that the vrine may haue a paÅ¿Å¿age, as alÅ¿o by this meanes to keepe it from going backe againe, and then afterwards they vntie it, when they would dreÅ¿Å¿e the inner inciÅ¿ion.

Cornelius CelÅ¿us appointeth this kind of Cure.Some do onely pull ouer the Praeputium, and tie it as we haue Å¿hewne: then they make an inciÅ¿ion round about the skin of the yard neare vnto the groine, being verie carefull, that they neither cut any veine that is in thoÅ¿e parts, nor of going Å¿o deep, as to the paÅ¿Å¿age of the vrine: When they haue done thus, they draw the skin, toward the ligature, and lay Å¿ome lint in the inciÅ¿ion, to dilate it, and breed Å¿ome fleÅ¿h therein. And it is to be obÅ¿eru'd, that the Praeputium muÅ¿t be alwaies tyed at the end, otherwiÅ¿e it would turne back againe, and the inciÅ¿ion would grow together.

But, Aeginetas opinion. (as Paulus Aegineta Å¿aith) Å¿ince theÅ¿e two accidents of the Praeputium, doe neither trouble them much, nor hurt any action: I would not counÅ¿aile them, to make the party Å¿uffer Å¿uch paine, whether he be young or old, nor to haue him trie the torment of Å¿uch experiments.

When it happens that there is no paÅ¿Å¿age at the end of the yard, then muÅ¿t the Chirurgion verie cunningly make an hole there, that the vrine may haue free paÅ¿Å¿age to come foorth: which being done, it muÅ¿t be kept open, and skinn'd ouer with little cearing candles put therein, which muÅ¿t be bow'd at the top, for feare leaÅ¿t they Å¿hould get whole into the bladder;A good obÅ¿eruation. which I haue Å¿een happen vnto Å¿ome: The Å¿aid cearing candle muÅ¿t be gently rub'd ouer with a little powder of Bole, and Tutia, and vpon it Å¿hall be laid a little plaÅ¿ter of Refrigerans Galeni.

If it chance, that the hole be not big enough, it muÅ¿t be widened with fine little cearing candles, fitted to the paÅ¿Å¿age, and made with medicines that are Å¿omewhat corroÅ¿iue, thereby to fetch away the vpper skin of the hole: Taking great heed, that the candle go but a little way in; becauÅ¿e the paÅ¿Å¿age is narrow and Å¿traite onely at the end, the reÅ¿t being commonly large enough: And when the hole is wide enough, it muÅ¿t be cicatriz'd with the like cearing candles, as we haue Å¿hewne already, obÅ¿eruing the Å¿ame methode as before.

When the hole of the yard is at the bottome, and not at the end, where it ought to be naturally:
If it may bee done poÅ¿Å¿iblie, that the bottome of the Glans muÅ¿t be Å¿topp'd vp, and an other made in the end of it: For thoÅ¿e that haue the hole Å¿o low, cannot piÅ¿Å¿e Å¿traight, but downeward, or elÅ¿e they are conÅ¿trained to hold vp their yard toward their bellie. And when they grow to be men, their Å¿eed cannot be carried Å¿traight, as it ought: which may be a meanes to hinder them from hauing children.

For the performance of the Cure, it will be verie needfull to excoriate the Å¿ides of the Å¿aid paÅ¿Å¿age, and to breed a little fleÅ¿h there, and afterwards to confirme and skin it: hauing firÅ¿t of all made another little hole at the end of the Å¿aid Glans, which muÅ¿t be dreÅ¿s'd and skinn'd with little cearing candles, as we haue Å¿hewne alreadie.

BeÅ¿ides all the other accidents heretofore mentioned, I haue Å¿een the yard of Å¿ome children Å¿o crooked, that when it roÅ¿e and grew Å¿tiffe, the Glans or top of it was drawne, and bow'd quite downeward, which made them, that they could not piÅ¿Å¿e Å¿traight. This fault proceedeth from the Å¿hortneÅ¿Å¿e of the Å¿tring, which holds the Glans Å¿o Å¿traitely tyed, that it cannot Å¿tretch it Å¿elfe foorth when the yard growes Å¿tiffe.

The Cure.As touching the Cure, both the Chirurgion and the Parents muÅ¿t be content to let it alone for a while, till the child be growne a little older, and bigger. And when they would put it in practize, they muÅ¿t watch their time to doe it, when the childs yard doth Å¿tand, and is Å¿tiffe: Then the Chirurgion
turning backe the Praeputium, Å¿hall vncouer the Glans, as gently as he can: and as he finds the ligament or Å¿tring to be too Å¿hort, he Å¿hall cut it in the middle, and preÅ¿ently bring the Praeputium ouer it againe, that the Glans be not left bare: hauing firÅ¿t laid vpon the inciÅ¿ion, a little chaw'd Å¿alt, as they doe to the Å¿tring of the Tongue, leaÅ¿t it Å¿hould grow together againe, and then he Å¿hall lay a little EmplaÅ¿ter of Refrigerans Galeni round about the yard.

div.head: Of Wenches, that haue their naturall paÅ¿Å¿age cloÅ¿ed vp, euen from their birth. CHAP. XXXII.
div.p: THere be Å¿ome Maides, that are borne with their wombe quite Å¿hut vp, or that haue no naturall paÅ¿Å¿age: which hapneth by means of Å¿ome membrane, that is placed in that part, which cloÅ¿eth and Å¿hutteth vp the entrance, (for certainly there is none which naturally hath not a paÅ¿Å¿age.) But becauÅ¿e there is Å¿omething found, that Å¿tops vp the entrance of it, therefore we Å¿ay, that they haue none at all. This membrane is not alwaies Å¿eated in the Å¿ame place, neither is it of the Å¿ame forme, and compoÅ¿ition, nor of the Å¿ame matter: For in Å¿ome, it is placed in the verie edge of the paÅ¿Å¿age, and is eaÅ¿ilie perceiued: and in others it lies deeper, neare vnto the inner orifice of the wombe.
Difference in figure.In reÅ¿pect of the figure, Å¿ome are pierced through the middle: Others haue holes, like vnto a Sieue, and Å¿ome haue none at all.
Matter.Concerning the matter, Å¿ome are membranous, and others are fleÅ¿hy: but thoÅ¿e which come euen from the birth, are rather membranous, then fleÅ¿hy children.

The Cure.ThoÅ¿e that trouble little children, are cured in this Å¿ort. FirÅ¿t, we muÅ¿t diligently conÅ¿ider, and take good heed, where abouts the membrane is Å¿eated, or placed: for vndoubtedly, the deeper it is, the more dangerous and difficult will be the Cure.

But when it is at the brim, and edges of the outward necke of the wombe,The order to do it. and is plainly Å¿een: the Chirurgion (after he hath placed the child, as is fit) Å¿hall cut aÅ¿under the Å¿aid membrane, with his inÅ¿trument directly in the middle, without going any farther: As Å¿oone as he hath made the inciÅ¿ion, he Å¿hall lay vpon it, a little drie lint, that it come not together again: and Å¿ome daies following, let him vÅ¿e Å¿ome drying Ointment, which muÅ¿t bee laid on with fine linnen clouts, as hath bin Å¿hewed before.

To defer the Cure of it, till the child were growne elder, it might prooue more dangerous with the time: AriÅ¿tot. lib. 4. cap. 4. de gene ra â¢ Animal. which hath been well obÅ¿eru'd by AriÅ¿totle, where he Å¿aith.

There bee Å¿ome women, that haue euen from their birth, the necke of their wombe, as it were cloÅ¿ed, and incorporated together: which hath continued Å¿o with them till the time they Å¿hould haue
their courÅ¿es, but when they haue beene ready to haue them, with the very paine, in Å¿ome the Å¿aide necke hath broken open of it Å¿elfe, in others it hath beene opened by the Chirurgions, and when they haue beene conÅ¿trained to open it by force, or that it could not be opened, there haue very many died of it.

This accident hath happened vnto diuers, and amongÅ¿t others to an honeÅ¿t maid who being ready to haue her courÅ¿es, fell very Å¿ick, her belly Å¿welled, with great prickings and Å¿hootings downward, and continuall vomiting, that troubled her, by the keeping backe of the Å¿aid courÅ¿es, which could not come away by reaÅ¿on of the membrane that Å¿topped vp the paÅ¿Å¿age. Which was very hard; for all the PhyÅ¿icions and Chirurgions, that looked vnto her, to find it out, who had appointed her diuers medicines, to bring downe her courÅ¿es: But when they Å¿aw, that all their medicines did her no good, they were of opinion to marry her, which was a meanes, that her husband found out her diÅ¿eaÅ¿e Å¿ooner then any PhiÅ¿icion could. I was Å¿ent for to helpe her, but by reaÅ¿on of the badnes, and danger of the way in trauaile, MonÅ¿. le Fort, and M. Collo Å¿worne Chirurgions of Paris, were Å¿ent thither: who after they had perceiued the diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, they cut the Å¿aid membrane, and made Å¿uch an inciÅ¿ion, that there came out of it aboue three pound of congeled and clotted bloud, and as black as melted pitch which eaÅ¿ed the patient very much. But whether it were, that the inciÅ¿ion was but halfe made, or that
it had growne together againe, about a yeere afterward Mr. Pineau, and I were called to finiÅ¿h the Cure, which wee did with very good Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e after this manner.

The manner of doing it.Hauing well conÅ¿idered the membrane (which was hard and glewie, and had a hole in the middle of it, whereinto you might haue put a large quill) wee were of opinion to inlarge it, by making three inciÅ¿ions; which was done with Å¿uch an inÅ¿trument as hath beene Å¿et downe before to cut the Praeputium; and then preÅ¿ently we put in a Dilatory, Å¿uch a one as they vÅ¿e to dilate the wound with, when they would take a Å¿tone out of the bladder) therby to dilate and teare aÅ¿under the reÅ¿t of the membrane, and to make the paÅ¿Å¿age big enough for her to haue the vÅ¿e of her husband: and as Å¿oone as we had Å¿tretched it, wee preÅ¿ently put into it a PeÅ¿Å¿ary made of Å¿iluer, of a conuenient bignes, which Å¿tayed there three daies together, and was neuer taken foorth, that the parts which had beene cut and torne aÅ¿under, might not grow together againe, as it had done before.

At the three daies end, the Å¿aid peÅ¿Å¿ary was taken foorth, and others put in, made of linnen cloth, and couered with digeÅ¿tiue,A peÅ¿Å¿ary of Lead. and Å¿uppurating medicines: And when the Å¿aide vlcer was ready to heale, it was skinned with PeÅ¿Å¿aries of Lead, applied as they ought to bee, and with others made of cloth, couered with cicatrizing medicines. The Å¿aid Gentlewoman was perfectly healed in three weekes.

div.head: Of the fundament that is cloÅ¿ed and Å¿topped. CHAP. XXXIII.
div.p: AS the yard of a boy, and the naturall paÅ¿Å¿age of a wench, are oftentimes found to bee cloÅ¿ed and Å¿topped vp, when they come into the World: So in like manner there are Å¿ome of both Å¿exes, whoÅ¿e fundament is naturally cloÅ¿ed & Å¿topped alÅ¿o, which commeth thus to paÅ¿Å¿e by meanes of a Membrane, which hinders this paÅ¿Å¿age.The fundament that is Å¿hut vp muÅ¿t be Å¿peedily remedied. Wherfore, conÅ¿idering the accidents, yea and the danger of death, which doth often attend it, it will be very needfull to remedy it Å¿peedily. For if the child bee not quickly purged of a certaine matter, and excrement, called Meconium, which he hath gathered together in his guts, all the while he hath beene in his mothers wombe, he is in danger to haue great and intollerable paines and gripings, and alÅ¿o to die in a Å¿hort Å¿pace: For the child cannot liue except he haue the benefit of nature that way.

The meanes to helpe it is this:The Cure. The Chirurgion muÅ¿t firÅ¿t open the childs buttocks, & then let him conÅ¿ider, whether there be a hole in the fundament or whether it be Å¿topped by Å¿ome membrane. If he perceiue, that the membrane is thinne, Paulus Aegineta counÅ¿elleth vs to teare it. But if it bee tough and Å¿trong, the beÅ¿t way will bee for him to cut it
with a fine little inÅ¿trument, and to go as deepe as the very fundament:How the euen Cure muÅ¿t be performed. which hee may know by putting gently into the fundament, after hee hath made the inciÅ¿ion, a little fine probe, with Å¿ome lint at the end of it: or elÅ¿e a peece of cearing Candle. Then the vlcer muÅ¿t be dreÅ¿'t with little linnen tents, couered ouer with Å¿ome drying medicine, which muÅ¿t bee put into the fundament, leaÅ¿t the brims and edges therof, being raw and excoriated, Å¿hould grow together againe. And it would not be amiÅ¿Å¿e, to let the child take a gentle CliÅ¿ter, to help to vnburthen him of the excrements that haue bin retained. And Å¿ince that the Å¿taying or Å¿topping of them, as I Å¿aide before, is oftentimes cauÅ¿e of the childs death, it wil not be from the matter to relate this Å¿tory.

A Å¿tory.Not long Å¿ince, the wife of MonÅ¿. de Cugy, Mr. of the Munition in the Arcenal of Paris, was deliuer'd of a little Daughter, which had the paÅ¿Å¿age of her fundament Å¿hut vp. After Å¿he was born, Å¿he was deliuered vnto the NurÅ¿e to be carried into the country, where Å¿he continued Å¿euen or eight daies, without voiding any thing by Å¿towle, which made her belly Å¿wel extreamely. Wherupon Å¿he was brought vnto this Citty, and MonÅ¿. Rabigois, a MaÅ¿ter Barber Chirurgion and Å¿worn at Paris, a very diligent and painfull man was Å¿ent for, to Å¿ee what might be the cauÅ¿e of this Å¿welling: and he inquiring whether the child went to Å¿toole or no: it was anÅ¿wered him by the nurÅ¿e Å¿he had neuer purged her Å¿elfe as yet that way, Å¿ince Å¿he was born: then by & by he Å¿earched
the fundament, and found it to be cloÅ¿ed and Å¿topped vp, and therefore he did counÅ¿ell the childs father to let him make an inciÅ¿ion of the membrane, that Å¿topped vp the paÅ¿Å¿age: whereunto the Father and Mother would not conÅ¿ent, till the morrow. But while the matter was debated and argued vpon, the child dyed: And Å¿he was opened by the Å¿aide MaÅ¿ter Rabigois, who found all her guts filled, with the humor, called Meconium, and other filthie matter.

div.head: Of the Å¿cabbe which comes on the childs head and face. CHAP. XXXIIII.
div.p:
OFtentimes there commeth vppon the childs head and face a hard cruÅ¿ty Å¿cab, which couereth all the head quite ouer (and therefore it is called the Cappe) and Å¿ometimes the face alÅ¿o: Å¿o that you can Å¿ee nothing but the childs eyes, as though hee had a maske on. The Latines call this Å¿cabbe Lactumen,
Lactumen. Lactitium. or Lactitium, as being an excrement of the Milke: And becauÅ¿e it is of a yellow colour, like vnto waxe, it is alÅ¿o called Cerium. The cauÅ¿e heereof, Cerium. is two fold, for eyther it is engendred of the reliques of the womens courÅ¿es or purgings:The CauÅ¿e. or elÅ¿e of the NurÅ¿es milke, which being of an ill quality, doth eaÅ¿ily corrupt in the childs Å¿tomacke, and cannot bee turned into good iuice, and much leÅ¿Å¿e bee corrected
by the Liuer, it being Å¿ent thither to bee turned into bloud: which makes it, that being carried vnto the head and face, it cannot be aÅ¿Å¿imilated in thoÅ¿e parts.
LeaÅ¿t this Å¿cab might corrode, and eat into the skinne, and afterwards the very bone of the head and face, and at length Gangrene the eies: it will be very good to remedy it.
For which purpoÅ¿e, the NurÅ¿e muÅ¿t keepe a good dyet, as we haue formerly Å¿hewne.
The Cure.Concerning Topicall or outward medicines, you muÅ¿t haue an eÅ¿peciall care, that you vÅ¿e none that do repell, and driue backe, but rather Å¿uch as gently draw.

You may bath the cruÅ¿ts, eÅ¿pecially thoÅ¿e of the face, with gentle Fomentations made of Mallowes, Althaea, Violet leaues, Chamomile and Melilot flowers and LinÅ¿eed, boyled in milke: and with this decoction you may foment the cruÅ¿ts, and afterwards annoint them with Oile of Å¿weet Almonds, FreÅ¿h Butter well beaten with Parietary water, and Oile of Violets waÅ¿hed with Barley water.
I am wont to vÅ¿e an Ointment of Lard melted, and then well beaten and waÅ¿hed with Parietary water, and Å¿o annoint the cruÅ¿ts with it.

If there be any vlcer, and that the Å¿cabs are fallen off; you may lay vpon it a Cabbidge, or a Beete leafe, a little heated on a Gridyron. The Ointment made of white Waxe, and oile of Å¿weet Almonds, is very good, when there is any rawneÅ¿Å¿e, or excoriation.

div.head: Of the Meazels, and the Å¿mall Pockes, what they are, and how they doe differ. CHAP. XXXV.
div.p: IT remaineth now, that we Å¿peake of the MeaÅ¿ells, and the Å¿mall Pockes: and becauÅ¿e there bee few children but haue them eyther firÅ¿t or laÅ¿t,Few children eÅ¿cape the Å¿mall pocks. I haue thought good, heere to Å¿ay a word or two of them briefly.

The MeaÅ¿els and the Pocks,What the meaÅ¿els and the pocks are. are little riÅ¿ings or puÅ¿tules, which appeare moÅ¿t commonly in great number, vpon the outÅ¿ide of the skinne: and at the firÅ¿t, they are Å¿o like one another, that you can hardly diÅ¿cerne whether of them it is. But yet the MeaÅ¿els come more Å¿uddenly, and the face and skinne of the whole body lookes redder: and the redneÅ¿Å¿e continues longer without riÅ¿ing; there beeing ioined with it moÅ¿t commonly a greater itching and pricking.Difference. But the Å¿mall pockes comes not foorth Å¿o Å¿uddenly, neither is the skinne Å¿o red: nor doth the colour Å¿tay Å¿o long: the puÅ¿tules or pimples riÅ¿e higher, neither itching nor pricking Å¿o much, and at length grow white.

The cauÅ¿e of both of them,CauÅ¿e. are the reliques of the impurer part of the bloud, wherewith the child was nouriÅ¿hed in his Mothers wombe; which now is Å¿eparated and thruÅ¿t to the skin, through the help and Å¿trength of nature, becauÅ¿e the childs bloud
boileth in the veines of euery part of the bodie: (as Auicen Å¿aith) No otherwiÅ¿e then new wine doth in a veÅ¿Å¿ell,A good compariÅ¿on. which boyleth, caÅ¿ting vp his froath, or Å¿cum, and Å¿eparating it from it Å¿elfe. And, (as Auenzoar Å¿aith) though the child be nouriÅ¿hed, with the beÅ¿t part of the menÅ¿truall bloud, yet there remaines Å¿ome little portion behind, which is of an ill qualitie; and after the child is borne, and is growne Å¿trong, he gathering together his forces and naturall heat, thruÅ¿ts it foorth by the pores of the skin, nature being willing to acquite and rid her Å¿elfe of this Å¿uperfluitie.

BeÅ¿ides, there is a certaine diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of time, cauÅ¿ed through the malignitie of the aire, which raiÅ¿eth and Å¿tirreth vp the reliques of the Å¿aid menÅ¿truall bloud in the childs bodie, wherewith he hath been nouriÅ¿hed: vnto which the corrupt aire (that we breath, and which we cannot auoide) doth adde an impreÅ¿Å¿ion, of a Å¿econd bad qualitie, wherewith nature being ouer-charg'd and offended, Å¿he thruÅ¿ts them out to the skin, which receiueth the filth and vncleanneÅ¿Å¿e of the bodie.

Now, the fuller the bodie is, of this menÅ¿truall bloud, the deeper impreÅ¿Å¿ion doth the outward aire make in it: which is the reaÅ¿on, that Å¿ome haue them in greater quantitie, and are fuller of them, then others: And Å¿o according to the malignitie of the humour, it is alÅ¿o more, or leÅ¿Å¿e dangerous to Å¿ome, then to others.

Signes.The marks and Å¿ignes whereby you may know that the child will haue the Pockes, are theÅ¿e:
Headach, together with an Ague, redneÅ¿Å¿e of the eyes, which water verie often, itching of the noÅ¿e, a drie Cough, gaping, wearineÅ¿Å¿e of the bodie, paine of the Hart, deÅ¿ire to vomit, the vrine red, a pricking, and Å¿hiuering through all the bodie, and Å¿ometimes convulÅ¿ions, and rauings. When it is the MeaÅ¿els, the face growes red, and ariÅ¿eth all at once: but when it is the Pocks, neither the face, nor the reÅ¿t of the bodie looke Å¿o red: but you may perceiue Å¿ome little riÅ¿ings here and there, in the face, backe, breaÅ¿t, and thigh's, which afterwards increaÅ¿e, and grow bigger.

And when the Pocks begin to Å¿hew themÅ¿elues, then there happens heauineÅ¿Å¿e of the head, the face Å¿welleth, the eyes are Å¿etled, all the bodie becomes as it were puff'd vp, the voice growes hoarÅ¿e, with difficultie of fetching breath, and Å¿oreneÅ¿Å¿e of the throat: For it is the propertie of this vile diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, to take hold of the Lungs; and yet we Å¿ee oftener then we would, that the Å¿mall Pocks do fall euen vpon the bones, and corrupt them.

The Å¿igneÅ¿ to iudge of the euent of them,Good Å¿ignes. are theÅ¿e: If the Ague be but little, and diminiÅ¿heth as the Pocks come foorth: if they be but few in number, and thoÅ¿e Å¿cattered here and there: if they come foorth eaÅ¿ily, without much paine, and that the child is not much diÅ¿quieted, if they grow white and ripen quickly: theÅ¿e are Å¿ignes of recouerie. But if the Ague continue, and increaÅ¿e at the comming foorth of them,Bad Å¿ignes. if they thruÅ¿t foorth in great quantitie, one vpon another; and if they run as it
were all into one Å¿cab, not ripening Å¿peedily; if the child be verie hoarÅ¿e, and not able to Å¿peake; or fall into a bloudie flixe, theÅ¿e are ill Å¿ignes. The firÅ¿t Å¿heweth, that it hath Å¿eized vpon the Lungs: and the Å¿econd, that it fretteth the guts.

Againe, the Å¿mall Pocks is verie dangerous, when it comes foorth with paine and griefe, though they be white. When they be Å¿mall, greene, blewiÅ¿h, or blacke, and that they Å¿inke downe, and grow drie on the Å¿uddaine, not comming to maturation and Å¿uppuration: if the child piÅ¿Å¿e bloud, and then by and by after his vrine turnes to be blacke, it is Å¿igne of death.

The Å¿ignes of the MeaÅ¿els.Concerning the MeaÅ¿els, if they be but reaÅ¿onable red, and haue no ill accidents ioined with them, but go away Å¿uddainly, they are not to be feared: But when they are high colour'd, or if they be blewiÅ¿h, or greeniÅ¿h, accompanied with vomiting, paine of the heart, weakneÅ¿Å¿e, the bloudie Flixe, and the like, they are verie dangerous.

div.head: Of the cure of the MeaÅ¿els, and Å¿mall Pockes. CHAP. XXXVI.
div.p:
IN all diÅ¿eaÅ¿es that happen vnto little Children, and eÅ¿peciallie in the cure of this preÅ¿ent Å¿ickneÅ¿Å¿e, the Chirurgion muÅ¿t not be too haÅ¿ty, nor do any thing raÅ¿hly: For there be many oftentimes deceiued, which think that the child will not haue the Pocks,
or MeaÅ¿els, becauÅ¿e at the firÅ¿t they haue but a little Ague, or Head-ach, or Å¿ome other light Å¿igne of it: Å¿eeing, that this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e lyeth long in the bodie, before it makes any Å¿hew.

But as Å¿oone as the Chirurgion perceiueth,How the Pocks muÅ¿t be help'd. that the child is taken with an Ague, and that he hath the Å¿ignes heretofore mentioned, he muÅ¿t proceed in this manner to the cure of them.

FirÅ¿t he muÅ¿t haue a care,The Cure. in what place the child is laid, Å¿eeing that this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e doth partly proceed of a maligne and contagious aire, which after that it hath beene drawne and carried by the Lungs, to the hart, and other parts of the body, it leaues there an impreÅ¿Å¿ion of his bad quality, in that part of the menÅ¿truall bloud, wherewith the child was nouriÅ¿hed in the mothers womb, wherefore let the child be kept in good aire, that is neither too hot, nor too cold. For being too hot, it may cauÅ¿e the childe to haue faintings and Å¿wounings, and being too cold, as the Pockes, or MeaÅ¿els are comming foorth,The Place. it may keepe them backe, and driue them in againe, and Å¿o hinder nature from expelling and putting
foorth the impurities, that are in the body. And therefore he muÅ¿t be kept warme in his bedde, and reaÅ¿onably well couered. Such as are more nice and curious, doe hang the bed round with red couerlets: If it be winter, it will be good to haue a fire in the Chamber, to rectifie the Ayre, which perhaps is of the coldeÅ¿t, and alÅ¿o to correct Å¿ome ill quality, which it may haue, as RhaÅ¿is and Auicen write. If it bee in heate of Summer it will not bee needfull to make Å¿o much fire, nor to keep the child couered Å¿o warme.

Concerning his meate and drinke: if the childe Å¿ucke,His Diet. then muÅ¿t the NurÅ¿e keepe a good diet, as wee haue heeretofore preÅ¿cribed, and as if Å¿he her Å¿elfe had an Ague. If the child be weaned, he muÅ¿t abÅ¿teine from eating all manner of fleÅ¿h, no not Å¿o much as of a little Chicken, till the pocks be whollie come foorth. But (as Auicen Å¿aith) he may vÅ¿e Broths made with Capons or Chickens wherein you muÅ¿t put good Å¿tore of Sorrel,Broths. Cichory, BugloÅ¿Å¿e, Borage, and Lettuce: Hee may alÅ¿o vÅ¿e the Å¿trained broth of PeaÅ¿e, Lentils, and Barley waters made with Figs, Dates, RayÅ¿ings of the Å¿unne alÅ¿o, Gelly Prunes, and roÅ¿ted apples, well Å¿ugred. For his drinke let him vÅ¿e a PtiÅ¿ane,His Drinke. made of Barley and LicoriÅ¿e, adding thereunto Å¿ome RayÅ¿ings of the Å¿unne, Figs, and Dates, but in Å¿mall quantity. If that drinke pleaÅ¿e him not, then let him vÅ¿e this drinke following.

An excellent Drinke. Take of French Barley a handfull, Å¿hauings of Iuory, and Harts horne tied in a little linnen cloth, of
each two drammes. Boyle them in a quart of water, and when it is almoÅ¿t Å¿odden, put to it halfe an ounce of LicoriÅ¿e, halfe a Citron peal'd and cut in Å¿lices: then Å¿traine it, and let him drinke of it at his Meales, and when hee is thirÅ¿ty. When the Pockes are quite come foorth, and begin to looke white, and that the Ague grows leÅ¿Å¿e & leÅ¿Å¿e, then he may eate a little Å¿tronger meate, and drinke a little water and Wine: his meate and drinke muÅ¿t not be actually cold.

And becauÅ¿e the pockes do come in the mouth, tongue, and throat,A lenifying and Å¿oupling Drinke. as alÅ¿o all along the wind-pipe you may put to his drinke, a little Å¿uger, or Å¿irup of Violets, Iuiubes or Cherries, and chiefly to that he drinketh betweene meales. This drinke lenifieth & Å¿uppleth the roughneÅ¿Å¿e and excoriations, it is good for the Lungs, and the hoarÅ¿eneÅ¿Å¿e wherewith they are troubled, and alÅ¿o it cleanÅ¿eth gently.

div.p:
THe Å¿mall Pockes, and the MeaÅ¿els do much annoy, and bring many inconueniences vnto children: For dailie experience Å¿heweth vs, that many die thereof, and thoÅ¿e which eÅ¿cape, do oftentimes beare the marks and badges of this vile diÅ¿eaÅ¿e. I haue Å¿eene diuers children, that haue been lame and

Others haue loÅ¿t their eyes: or at the leaÅ¿t there hath remayned Å¿ome pearle, or Å¿pot vpon them: Others haue had their eyes Å¿taring, red, or watring: Some haue been deafe, and dull of hearing: Others haue had their noÅ¿e and mouth Å¿hrunke together, or elÅ¿e puffed vp: and Å¿ome haue been hoarÅ¿e afterwards all their life time: The leaÅ¿t accident of all is, that many haue remained disfigured with pits and holes in their faces.

Now, as this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e is cauÅ¿ed (as we haue Å¿aid) of the reliques of the menÅ¿truall bloud, wherewith the child hath been nouriÅ¿hed, Å¿tirr'd vp by the malignitie of the aire (which it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible to Å¿hun or auoid:) So to go about to preÅ¿erue a child from it, we muÅ¿t do two things; The firÅ¿t Å¿hall be, to Å¿hun and auoid this corrupted Aire, and to rectifie it the beÅ¿t we can poÅ¿Å¿iblie: The Å¿econd is, to euacuate and purge away the reliques of this humour, and to make them leÅ¿Å¿e hurtfull.

Wherefore, both the NurÅ¿e and the child muÅ¿t liue in a houÅ¿e, that Å¿tands in a good aire, far from any Å¿inkes, priuies, or Church-yards, from whence there ariÅ¿e many vnholÅ¿ome vapours, and exhalations: Her chamber muÅ¿t haue a good aire, rather Å¿tanding high, then low: Let the window looke

div.head: Of the breeding, and comming foorth of Haires on childrens backes and raines, called in Languedocke MaÅ¿quelon, and of the Latins, Morbus pilaris. CHAP. XXXV.
div.p: IT had been more agreeable and conuenient, to haue Å¿et downe this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, in the Chapter of the VnquietneÅ¿Å¿e and Crying of little children: But as this booke was euen almoÅ¿t printed, Mr Toignet, a Barber Chirurgion of Paris, put me in mind of this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, that happens vnto little Children, which is verie common in Languedocke, and is called in their language MaÅ¿quelon. Hauing enquired of diuers PhyÅ¿icions, about this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, and amongÅ¿t the reÅ¿t, of MonÅ¿. Riollan, Doctour of PhyÅ¿icke in Paris, and the Kings ProfeÅ¿Å¿or in Chirurgerie, a verie learned and painfull gentleman; he told me, that Montanus had written of it, Morbus Pilaris. and that he called it Pilaris affectio.

As Å¿oone as little Children are taken with this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e, they crie and take on extreamely, and yet one can not perceiue any cauÅ¿e, why they Å¿hould do Å¿o; which brings them oftentimes euen to their graue, for that this diÅ¿eaÅ¿e drawes along with it Epylepticall convulÅ¿ions: becauÅ¿e the Sinewes

The Å¿ame Montanus counÅ¿elleth the woman, to rub her hand firÅ¿t with Å¿ome new Milke: which being done, and the Haires pull'd away, the child preÅ¿ently recouers his health, and leaueth his ordinarie cries and laments.
